1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Gross margins on our automotive/mobile products have been declining and are expected to decline in 2011 due to price reductions in the increasingly competitive market for personal navigation devices (PNDs) that are not fully offset by material cost reductions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S1	In addition, our overall gross margin may fluctuate from period to period due to a number of factors, including product mix, competition and unit volumes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S2	In particular, the average selling prices of a specific product tend to decrease over that product s life.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S3	To offset such decreases, we intend to rely primarily on component cost reduction, obtaining yield improvements and corresponding cost reductions in the manufacture of existing products and on introducing new products that incorporate advanced features and therefore can be sold at higher average selling prices.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S4	However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain any such yield improvements or cost reductions or introduce any such new products in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P9_S5	To the extent that such cost reductions and new product introductions do not occur in a timely manner or our products do not achieve market acceptance, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Changes in our United States federal income tax classification or in applicable tax law could result in adverse tax consequences to our shareholders.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We do not believe that we (or any of our non-United States subsidiaries) are currently a passive foreign investment company for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P11_S1	We do not expect to become a passive foreign investment company.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P11_S2	However, because the passive foreign investment company determination is made annually based on whether the company s income or assets meet certain thresholds as determined under United States federal tax principles which are based on facts and circumstances that may be beyond our control, we cannot assure that we will not become a passive foreign investment company in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P11_S3	If we are a passive foreign investment company in any year, then any of our shareholders that is a United States person could be liable to pay tax on their pro rata share of our income plus an interest charge upon some distributions by us or when that shareholder sells our common shares at a gain.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Further, if we are classified as a passive foreign investment company in any year in which a United States person is a shareholder, we generally will continue to be treated as a passive foreign investment company with respect to such shareholder in all succeeding years, regardless of whether we continue to satisfy the income or asset tests mentioned above.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We do not believe that we (or any of our non-United States subsidiaries) are currently a Controlled Foreign Corporation (CFC) for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We do not expect to become a CFC.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The CFC determination is made daily based on whether the United States shareholders own more than fifty percent of the voting power or value of the Company.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Only United States persons that own ten percent or more of the voting power of the Company s shares qualify as United States shareholders.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P13_S2	If the Company were to be classified as a CFC for an uninterrupted thirty day period in any year, the Company s shareholders that qualify as United States shareholders could be liable to pay US income tax at ordinary income tax rates on their pro-rata share of certain categories of the Company s income for the period in which the Company is classified as a CFC.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P13_S3	As the Company cannot control the ownership of the Company s stock nor can the Company control which shareholders participate in the Company s stock buyback program, ownership changes could result that create United States shareholders which increase the risk of Garmin being treated as a CFC.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Legislative proposals have been considered in the United States within the past year that could increase the United States tax burden of corporations with international operations and could broaden the circumstances under which foreign corporations could be considered resident in the United States Our tax position could be adversely impacted by changes in United States or foreign tax laws, tax treaties or tax regulations or the interpretation or enforcement thereof by any tax authority.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We cannot predict the outcome of any specific legislative proposals.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	If we are not successful in the continued development, introduction or timely manufacture of new products, demand for our products could decrease.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We expect that a significant portion of our future revenue will continue to be derived from sales of newly introduced products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The market for our products is characterized by rapidly changing technology, evolving industry standards and changes in customer needs.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P16_S2	If we fail to introduce new products, or to modify or improve our existing products, in response to changes in technology, industry standards or customer needs, our products could rapidly become less competitive or obsolete.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P16_S3	We must continue to make significant investments in research and development in order to continue to develop new products, enhance existing products and achieve market acceptance for such products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P16_S4	However, there can be no assurance that development stage products will be successfully completed or, if developed, will achieve significant customer acceptance.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	If we are unable to successfully develop and introduce competitive new products, and enhance our existing products, our future results of operations would be adversely affected.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Our pursuit of necessary technology may require substantial time and expense.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S2	We may need to license new technologies to respond to technological change.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S3	These licenses may not be available to us on terms that we can accept or may materially change the gross profits that we are able to obtain on our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S4	We may not succeed in adapting our products to new technologies as they emerge.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S5	Development and manufacturing schedules for technology products are difficult to predict, and there can be no assurance that we will achieve timely initial customer shipments of new products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S6	The timely availability of these products in volume and their acceptance by customers are important to our future success.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P17_S7	From time to time we have experienced delays in shipping certain of our new products and any future delays, whether due to product development delays, manufacturing delays, lack of market acceptance, delays in regulatory approval, or otherwise, could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	If we are unable to compete effectively with existing or new competitors, our resulting loss of competitive position could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	The markets for our products are highly competitive, and we expect competition to increase in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Some of our competitors have significantly greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S2	These competitors may be able to respond more rapidly to new or emerging technologies or changes in customer requirements.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S3	They may also be able to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Increased competition could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Our failure to compete successfully against current or future competitors could seriously harm our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We rely on independent dealers and distributors to sell our products, and disruption to these channels would harm our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Because we sell a majority of our products to independent dealers and distributors, we are subject to many risks, including risks related to their inventory levels and support for our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	In particular, our dealers and distributors maintain significant levels of our products in their inventories.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	If dealers and distributors attempt to reduce their levels of inventory or if they do not maintain sufficient levels to meet customer demand, our sales could be negatively impacted.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Many of our dealers and distributors also sell products offered by our competitors.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P22_S1	If our competitors offer our dealers and distributors more favorable terms, those dealers and distributors may de-emphasize or decline to carry our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P22_S2	In the future, we may not be able to retain or attract a sufficient number of qualified dealers and distributors.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P22_S3	If we are unable to maintain successful relationships with dealers and distributors or to expand our distribution channels, our business will suffer.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Our quarterly operating results are subject to fluctuations and seasonality.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Our operating results are difficult to predict.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Our future quarterly operating results may fluctuate significantly.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P24_S2	If such operating results decline, the price of our stock would likely decline.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P24_S3	As we expand our operations, our operating expenses, particularly our advertising and research and development costs, may increase as a percentage of our sales.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P24_S4	If revenues decrease and we are unable to reduce those costs rapidly, our operating results would be negatively affected.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Historically, our revenues have been weaker in the first quarter of each fiscal year and have recently been lower than the preceding fourth quarter.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Our devices are highly consumer-oriented, and consumer buying is traditionally lower in these quarters.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Sales of certain of our marine and automotive products tend to be higher in our second fiscal quarter due to increased consumer spending for such products during the recreational marine, fishing, and travel season.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P25_S3	Sales of our automotive/mobile products also have been higher in our fourth fiscal quarter due to increased consumer spending patterns on electronic devices during the holiday season.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P25_S4	In addition, we attempt to time our new product releases to coincide with relatively higher consumer spending in the second and fourth fiscal quarters, which contributes to these seasonal variations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Our quarterly financial statements will reflect fluctuations in foreign currency translation.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	The operation of Garmin s subsidiaries in international markets results in exposure to movements in currency exchange rates.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We have experienced significant foreign currency gains and losses due to the strengthening and weakening of the U.S. dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	The potential of volatile foreign exchange rate fluctuations in the future could have a significant effect on our results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The currencies that create a majority of the Company s exchange rate exposure are the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Garmin Corporation, headquartered in Sijhih, Taiwan, uses the local currency as the functional currency.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P30_S1	The Company translates all assets and liabilities at year-end exchange rates and income and expense accounts at average rates during the year.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	In order to minimize the effect of the currency exchange fluctuations on our net assets, we have elected to retain most of our Taiwan subsidiary s cash and investments in marketable securities denominated in U.S. dollars.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Nonetheless, U.S. GAAP requires the Company at the end of each accounting period to translate into Taiwan Dollars all such U.S. Dollar denominated assets held by our Taiwan subsidiary.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P32_S1	This translation is required because the Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of the subsidiary.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P32_S2	This U.S. GAAP-mandated translation will cause us to recognize gain or loss on our financial statements as the Taiwan Dollar/U.S. Dollar exchange rate varies.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P32_S3	Such gain or loss will create variations in our earnings per share.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P32_S4	Because there is minimal cash impact caused by such exchange rate variations, management will continue to focus on the Company s operating performance before the impact of the foreign currency translation.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	If we do not correctly anticipate demand for our products, we may not be able to secure sufficient quantities or cost-effective production of our products or we could have costly excess production or inventories.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We have generally been able to increase production to meet this increasing demand.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	However, the demand for our products depends on many factors and will be difficult to forecast.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P34_S2	We expect that it will become more difficult to forecast demand as we introduce and support multiple products, as competition in the market for our products intensifies and as the markets for some of our products mature to the mass market category.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P34_S3	Significant unanticipated fluctuations in demand could cause the following problems in our operations:
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	If demand increases beyond what we forecast, we would have to rapidly increase production.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P35_S1	We would depend on suppliers to provide additional volumes of components and those suppliers might not be able to increase production rapidly enough to meet unexpected demand.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	Rapid increases in production levels to meet unanticipated demand could result in higher costs for manufacturing and supply of components and other expenses.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	These higher costs could lower our profit margins.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P36_S2	Further, if production is increased rapidly, manufacturing quality could decline, which may also lower our margins and reduce customer satisfaction.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	If forecasted demand does not develop, we could have excess production resulting in higher inventories of finished products and components, which would use cash and could lead to write-offs of some or all of the excess inventories.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P37_S1	Lower than forecasted demand could also result in excess manufacturing capacity or reduced manufacturing efficiencies at our facilities, which could result in lower margins.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	We have benefited in the past from Taiwan government tax incentives offered on certain high technology capital investments that may not always be available.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Our effective tax rate is lower than the U.S. federal statutory rate, in part because we have benefited from incentives offered in Taiwan related to our high technology investments in Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P39_S1	The loss of these tax benefits could have a significant effect on our financial results in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	We may experience unique economic and political risks associated with companies that operate in Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Relations between Taiwan and the People s Republic of China, also referred to as the PRC, and other factors affecting the political or economic conditions of Taiwan in the future could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations and the market price and the liquidity of our shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P41_S1	Our principal manufacturing facilities where we manufacture all of our products, except our panel-mounted aviation products, are located in Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Taiwan has a unique international political status.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P42_S1	The PRC asserts sovereignty over all of China, including Taiwan, certain other islands and all of mainland China.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P42_S2	The PRC government does not recognize the legitimacy of the Taiwan government.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P42_S3	Although significant economic and cultural relations have been established during recent years between Taiwan and the PRC, the PRC government has indicated that it may use military force to gain control over Taiwan in certain circumstances, such as the declaration of independence by Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P42_S4	Relations between Taiwan and the PRC have on occasion adversely affected the market value of Taiwanese companies and could negatively affect our operations in Taiwan in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Our intellectual property rights are important to our operations, and we could suffer loss if they infringe upon other s rights or are infringed upon by others.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	We rely on a combination of patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets, confidentiality provisions and licensing arrangements to establish and protect our proprietary rights.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P44_S1	To this end, we hold rights to a number of patents and registered trademarks and regularly file applications to attempt to protect our rights in new technology and trademarks.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P44_S2	However, there is no guarantee that our patent applications will become issued patents, or that our trademark applications will become registered trademarks.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P44_S3	Moreover, even if approved, our patents or trademarks may thereafter be successfully challenged by others or otherwise become invalidated for a variety of reasons.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P44_S4	Thus, any patents or trademarks we currently have or may later acquire may not provide us a significant competitive advantage.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P45_S0	Third parties may claim that we are infringing their intellectual property rights.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Such claims could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P46_S0	From time to time we receive letters alleging infringement of patents, trademarks or other intellectual property rights.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Litigation concerning patents or other intellectual property is costly and time consuming.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P46_S2	We may seek licenses from such parties, but they could refuse to grant us a license or demand commercially unreasonable terms.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P46_S3	We might not have sufficient resources to pay for the licenses.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P46_S4	Such infringement claims could also cause us to incur substantial liabilities and to suspend or permanently cease the use of critical technologies or processes or the production or sale of major products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P47_S0	We may become subject to significant product liability costs.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P48_S0	If our aviation products malfunction or contain errors or defects, airplane collisions or crashes could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Malfunctions or errors or defects in our marine navigational products could cause boats to run aground or cause other wreckage, personal injury or death.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P48_S2	If our automotive or marine products contain defects or errors in the mapping supplied by third-party map providers or if our users do not heed our warnings about the proper use of these products, collisions or accidents could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P48_S3	If any of these events occurs, we could be subject to significant liability for personal injury and property damage and under certain circumstances could be subject to a judgment for punitive damages.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P49_S0	We maintain insurance against accident-related risks involving our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P49_S1	However, there can be no assurance that such insurance would be sufficient to cover the cost of damages to others or that such insurance will continue to be available at commercially reasonable rates.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P49_S2	In addition, insurance coverage generally will not cover awards of punitive damages and may not cover the cost of associated legal fees and defense costs, which could result in lower margins.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P49_S3	If we are unable to maintain sufficient insurance to cover product liability costs or if our insurance coverage does not cover the award, this could have a materially adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We depend on our suppliers, some of which are the sole source for specific components, and our production would be seriously harmed if these suppliers are not able to meet our demand and alternative sources are not available, or if the costs of components rise.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We are dependent on third party suppliers for various components used in our current products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Some of the components that we procure from third party suppliers include semiconductors and electroluminescent panels, liquid crystal displays, memory chips, batteries and microprocessors.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S2	The cost, quality and availability of components are essential to the successful production and sale of our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S3	Some components we use are from sole source suppliers.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S4	Certain application-specific integrated circuits incorporating our proprietary designs are manufactured for us by sole source suppliers.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P51_S5	Alternative sources may not be currently available for these sole source components.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P52_S0	In the past we have experienced shortages of liquid crystal displays and other components.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P52_S1	In addition, if there are shortages in supply of components, the costs of such components may rise.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P52_S2	If suppliers are unable to meet our demand for components on a timely basis and if we are unable to obtain an alternative source or if the price of the alternative source is prohibitive, or if the costs of components rise, our ability to maintain timely and cost-effective production of our products would be seriously harmed.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We depend on third party licensors for the digital map data contained in our automotive/mobile products, and our business and/or gross margins could be harmed if we become unable to continue licensing such mapping data or if the royalty costs for such data rise.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P54_S0	We license digital mapping data for use in our products from various sources.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P54_S1	There are only a limited number of suppliers of mapping data for each geographical region.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P54_S2	The two largest digital map suppliers are NAVTEQ Corporation and Tele Atlas N.V. NAVTEQ Corporation is owned by Nokia Oyj and Tele Atlas N.V. is owned by TomTom N.V. Nokia and TomTom are both competitors of Garmin.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P55_S0	Although we do not foresee difficulty in continuing to license data at favorable pricing due to the long term license extension signed between Garmin and NAVTEQ in November 2007 (extending our NAVTEQ license agreement through 2017 with an option to extend through 2021), if we are unable to continue licensing such mapping data and are unable to obtain an alternative source, or if the nature of our relationships with NAVTEQ changes detrimentally, our ability to supply mapping data for use in our products would be seriously harmed.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P56_S0	We may pursue strategic acquisitions, investments, strategic partnerships or other ventures, and our business could be materially harmed if we fail to successfully identify, complete and integrate such transactions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P57_S0	We intend to evaluate acquisition opportunities and opportunities to make investments in complementary businesses, technologies, services or products, or to enter into strategic partnerships with parties who can provide access to those assets, additional product or services offerings, additional distribution or marketing synergies or additional industry expertise.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P57_S1	We may not be able to identify suitable acquisition, investment or strategic partnership candidates, or if we do identify suitable candidates in the future, we may not be able to complete those transactions on commercially favorable terms, or at all.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P58_S0	Any past or future acquisitions could also result in difficulties assimilating acquired employees (including cultural differences with foreign acquisitions), operations, and products and diversion of capital and management s attention away from other business issues and opportunities.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P58_S1	Integration of acquired companies may result in problems related to integration of technology and inexperienced management teams.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P58_S2	In addition, the key personnel of the acquired company may decide not to work for us.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P58_S3	We may not successfully integrate internal controls, compliance under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other corporate governance matters, operations, personnel or products related to acquisitions we have made in previous years or may make in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P58_S4	If we fail to successfully integrate such transactions, our business could be materially harmed.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P59_S0	We may have additional tax liabilities.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S0	We are subject to income taxes in both the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our worldwide provision for income taxes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S2	In the ordinary course of our business, there are many transactions and calculations where the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S3	We are regularly under audit by tax authorities.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S4	Although we believe our tax estimates are reasonable, the final determination of tax audits and any related litigation could be materially different from our historical income tax provisions and accruals.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P60_S5	The results of an audit or litigation could have a material effect on our income tax provision, net income or cash flows in the period or periods for which that determination is made.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P61_S0	Failure to obtain required certifications of our products on a timely basis could harm our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S0	We have certain products, especially in our aviation segment, that are subject to governmental and similar certifications before they can be sold.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S1	For example, FAA certification is required for all of our aviation products that are intended for installation in type certificated aircraft.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S2	To the extent required, certification is an expensive and time-consuming process that requires significant focus and resources.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S3	An inability to obtain, or excessive delay in obtaining, such certifications could have an adverse effect on our ability to introduce new products and, for certain aviation OEM products, our customers ability to sell airplanes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S4	Therefore, such inabilities or delays could adversely affect our operating results.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S5	In addition, we cannot assure you that our certified products will not be decertified.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P62_S6	Any such decertification could have an adverse effect on our operating results.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P63_S0	Our business may suffer if we are not able to hire and retain sufficient qualified personnel or if we lose our key personnel.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Our future success depends partly on the continued contribution of our key executive, engineering, sales, marketing, manufacturing and administrative personnel.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S1	We currently do not have employment agreements with any of our key executive officers.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S2	We do not have key man life insurance on any of our key executive officers and do not currently intend to obtain such insurance.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S3	The loss of the services of any of our senior level management, or other key employees, could harm our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S4	Recruiting and retaining the skilled personnel we require to maintain and grow our market position may be difficult.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S5	For example, in some recent years there has been a nationwide shortage of qualified electrical engineers and software engineers who are necessary for us to design and develop new products, and therefore, it has sometimes been challenging to recruit such personnel.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P64_S6	If we fail to hire and retain qualified employees, we may not be able to maintain and expand our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P65_S0	There is uncertainty as to our shareholders ability to enforce certain foreign civil liabilities in Switzerland and Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P66_S0	We are a Swiss company and a substantial portion of our assets are located outside the United States, particularly in Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P66_S1	As a result, it may be difficult to effect service of process within the United States upon us.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P66_S2	In addition, there is uncertainty as to whether the courts of Switzerland or Taiwan would recognize or enforce judgments of United States courts obtained against us predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the securities laws of the United States or any state thereof, or be competent to hear original actions brought in Switzerland or Taiwan against us predicated upon the securities laws of the United States or any state thereof.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P67_S0	A shut down of U.S. airspace or imposition of restrictions on general aviation would harm our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P68_S0	Following the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, the FAA ordered all aircraft operating in the U.S. to be grounded for several days.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P68_S1	In addition to this shut down of U.S. airspace, the general aviation industry was further impacted by the additional restrictions implemented by the FAA on those flights that fly utilizing Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P68_S2	The FAA restricted VFR flight inside 30 enhanced Class B (a 20-25 mile radius around the 30 largest metropolitan areas in the USA) airspace areas.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P68_S3	The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association (AOPA) estimated that these restrictions affected approximately 41,800 general aviation aircraft based at 282 airports inside the 30 enhanced Class B airspace areas.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P68_S4	The AOPA estimates that approximately 90% of all general aviation flights are conducted VFR, and that only 15% of general aviation pilots are current to fly utilizing Instrument Flight Rules (IFR).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P69_S0	The shutdown of U.S. airspace following September 11, 2001 caused reduced sales of our general aviation products and delays in the shipment of our products manufactured in our Taiwan manufacturing facility to our distribution facility in Olathe, Kansas, thereby adversely affecting our ability to supply new and existing products to our dealers and distributors.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P70_S0	Any future shut down of U.S. airspace or imposition of restrictions on general aviation could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial results.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P71_S0	Many of our products rely on the Global Positioning System.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P72_S0	The Global Positioning System is a satellite-based navigation and positioning system consisting of a constellation of orbiting satellites.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P72_S1	The satellites and their ground control and monitoring stations are maintained and operated by the United States Department of Defense.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P72_S2	The Department of Defense does not currently charge users for access to the satellite signals.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P73_S0	These satellites and their ground support systems are complex electronic systems subject to electronic and mechanical failures and possible sabotage.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P73_S1	The satellites were originally designed to have lives of 7.5 years and are subject to damage by the hostile space environment in which they operate.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P73_S2	However, of the current deployment of satellites in place, some have been operating for more than 12 years.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P74_S0	If a significant number of satellites were to become inoperable, unavailable or are not replaced, it would impair the current utility of our Global Positioning System products and would have a material negative effect on our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P74_S1	In addition, there can be no assurance that the U.S. government will remain committed to the operation and maintenance of Global Positioning System satellites over a long period, or that the policies of the U.S. government that provide for the use of the Global Positioning System without charge and without accuracy degradation will remain unchanged.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P75_S0	Because of the increasing commercial applications of the Global Positioning System, other U.S. government agencies may become involved in the administration or the regulation of the use of Global Positioning System signals.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P75_S1	However, in a presidential policy statement issued in December 2004, the Bush administration indicated that the U.S. is committed to supporting and improving the Global Positioning System and will continue providing it free from direct user fees.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P76_S0	Some of our products also use signals from systems that augment GPS, such as the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P76_S1	WAAS is operated by the FAA.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P77_S0	Any curtailment of the operating capability of WAAS could result in decreased user capability for many of our aviation products, thereby impacting our markets.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P78_S0	Any of the foregoing factors could affect the willingness of buyers of our products to select Global Positioning System-based products instead of products based on competing technologies.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P79_S0	Any reallocation or repurposing of radio frequency spectrum could cause harmful interference with the reception of Global Positioning System signals.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P79_S1	This interference could harm our business.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P80_S0	Our Global Positioning System technology is dependent on the use of the Standard Positioning Service (SPS) provided by the U.S. Government s Global Positioning System satellites.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P80_S1	The Global Positioning System operates in radio frequency bands that are globally allocated for radio navigation satellite services.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P81_S0	International allocations of radio frequency are made by the International Telecommunications Union (ITU), a specialized technical agency of the United Nations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P81_S1	These allocations are further governed by radio regulations that have treaty status and which may be subject to modification every two to three years by the World Radio Communication Conference.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P81_S2	Each country also has regulatory authority on how each band is used.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P82_S0	In the United States, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration share responsibility for radio frequency allocations and spectrum usage regulations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P83_S0	Any ITU or national reallocation of radio frequency spectrum, including frequency band segmentation or sharing of spectrum, or other modifications of the permitted uses of relevant frequency bands, may materially and adversely affect the utility and reliability of our products and have significant negative impacts on our business and our customers.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P83_S1	For example, the FCC is currently considering a proposal by a private party, LightSquared, to repurpose spectrum adjacent to the GPS bands for terrestrial broadband wireless operations in metropolitan areas throughout the United States.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P83_S2	If the FCC were to permit implementation of LightSquared s proposal as is, terrestrial broadband wireless operations would create harmful interference to GPS receivers within range of such operations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P84_S0	Our business is subject to disruptions and uncertainties caused by war or terrorism.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P85_S0	Acts of war or acts of terrorism, especially any directed at the GPS signals, could have a material adverse impact on our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P85_S1	The threat of terrorism and war and heightened security and military response to this threat, or any future acts of terrorism, may cause a redeployment of the satellites used in GPS or interruptions of the system.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P85_S2	To the extent that such interruptions have an effect on sales of our products, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, and financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P86_S0	We may be exposed to certain regulatory and financial risks related to climate change.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P87_S0	Climate change is receiving increasing attention worldwide.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P87_S1	Some scientists, legislators and others attribute global warming to increased levels of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, which has led to significant legislative and regulatory efforts to limit greenhouse gas emissions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P88_S0	There are a number of pending legislative and regulatory proposals to address greenhouse gas emissions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P88_S1	For example, in June 2009 the U.S. House of Representatives passed the American Clean Energy and Security Act that would phase-in significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions if enacted into law.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P88_S2	The U.S. Senate is considering one or more different bills, and it is uncertain whether, when and in what form a federal mandatory carbon dioxide emissions reduction program may be adopted.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P88_S3	Similarly, certain countries have adopted the Kyoto Protocol.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P88_S4	These actions could increase costs associated with our operations, including costs for components used in the manufacture of our products and freight costs.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P89_S0	Because it is uncertain what laws and regulations will be enacted, we cannot predict the potential impact of such laws and regulations on our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P90_S0	The volatility of our stock price could adversely affect investment in our common shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P91_S0	The market price of our common shares has been, and may continue to be, highly volatile.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P91_S1	During 2010, the price of our common shares ranged from a low of $26.55 to a high of $39.94.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P91_S2	A variety of factors could cause the price of our common shares to fluctuate, perhaps substantially, including:
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P92_S0	any significant acts of terrorism against the United States, Taiwan or significant markets where we sell our products.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P93_S0	In addition, in recent years the stock market in general and the markets for shares of technology companies in particular, have experienced extreme price fluctuations which have often been unrelated to the operating performance of affected companies.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P93_S1	Any such fluctuations in the future could adversely affect the market price of our common shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P94_S0	Our officers and directors exert substantial influence over us.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P95_S0	As of January 14, 2011, members and former members of our Board of Directors and our executive officers, together with members of their families and entities that may be deemed affiliates of or related to such persons or entities, beneficially owned approximately 44.80% of our outstanding common shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P95_S1	Accordingly, these shareholders may be able to determine the outcome of corporate actions requiring shareholder approval, such as mergers and acquisitions.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P95_S2	This level of ownership may have a significant effect in delaying, deferring or preventing a change in control of Garmin and may adversely affect the voting and other rights of other holders of our common shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P96_S0	On June 27, 2010 we completed the redomestication of the place of our incorporation from the Cayman Islands to Switzerland (the Redomestication ).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P96_S1	As a result of increased shareholder approval requirements under Swiss law, we have less flexibility than we previously had as a Cayman Islands company with respect to certain aspects of capital management.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P97_S0	Swiss law allows our shareholders acting at a shareholders meeting to authorize share capital that can be issued by the board of directors without approval of a shareholders meeting, but this authorization is limited to 50% of the existing registered share capital and must be renewed by a shareholders meeting every two years.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P97_S1	Additionally, subject to specified exceptions, including the exceptions described in our articles of association, Swiss law grants preemptive rights to existing shareholders to subscribe for new issuances of shares and other securities.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P98_S0	Swiss law does not provide as much flexibility as Cayman Islands law in the various terms that can attach to different classes of shares either.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P98_S1	For example, while the board of directors of a Cayman Islands company can authorize the issuance of preferred stock without shareholder approval, we will not be able to issue preferred stock without the approval of 66 2/3% of the votes represented and a majority of the par value of the shares represented at a general meeting of our shareholders.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P98_S2	Swiss law also reserves for approval by shareholders many corporate actions over which our board of directors previously had authority under Cayman Islands law.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P98_S3	For example, dividends must be approved by shareholders at the general meeting of our shareholders.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P99_S0	The par value of our shares is higher following the Redomestication.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P99_S1	As a result, we have less flexibility than we previously had as a Cayman Islands company with respect to certain aspects of capital management.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P100_S0	The par value of our shares is 10 Swiss francs per share, compared to a par value of $0.005 per share when we were a Cayman Islands company.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P100_S1	Under Swiss law, we may not issue shares below par value.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P100_S2	In the event we need to raise equity capital at a time when the trading price of our shares is below the par value of the shares, we will be unable to issue shares.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P100_S3	In addition, we will not be able to issue options under our benefits plans with an exercise price below the par value, which would limit the flexibility of our compensation arrangements.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P101_S0	We are subject to various Swiss taxes following the Redomestication.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P102_S0	Although we do not expect Swiss taxes to materially affect our worldwide effective corporate tax rate, we are subject to additional corporate taxes in Switzerland following the Redomestication.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P102_S1	Switzerland imposes a corporate federal income tax for holding companies at an effective tax rate of 7.83%, although we should be entitled to a participation relief that in most cases will effectively eliminate any Swiss taxation on the profits of our subsidiaries paid by them to us as dividends as well as on capital gains related to the sale of participations.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P102_S2	We also are subject to a Swiss issuance stamp tax levied on our share issuances, other than in connection with qualifying restructurings, or increases of our equity at a rate of 1% of the fair market value of the issuance or increase.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P102_S3	In addition, we are subject to some other Swiss indirect taxes (e.g., VAT, Swiss issuance stamp tax on certain debt instruments and Swiss securities transfer stamp tax).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P103_S0	We may not be able to make distributions or repurchase shares without subjecting you to Swiss withholding tax.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P104_S0	If we are unable to make distributions, if any, through a reduction of par value or to pay dividends, if any, out of qualifying capital contribution reserves, then any dividends paid by us will generally be subject to a Swiss federal withholding tax at a rate of 35%.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P104_S1	The withholding tax must be withheld from the gross distribution and paid to the Swiss Federal Tax Administration.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P104_S2	A U.S. holder that qualifies for benefits under the Convention between the United States of America and the Swiss Confederation for the Avoidance of Double Taxation with Respect to Taxes on Income may apply for a refund of the tax withheld in excess of the 15% treaty rate (or in excess of the 5% reduced treaty rate for qualifying corporate shareholders with at least 10% participation in our voting stock, or for a full refund in case of qualified pension funds).
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P105_S0	Payment of a capital distribution in the form of a par value reduction is not subject to Swiss withholding tax.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P105_S1	However, there can be no assurance that our shareholders will approve a reduction in par value, that we will be able to meet the other legal requirements for a reduction in par value, or that Swiss withholding rules will not be changed in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P105_S2	In addition, over the long term, the amount of par value available for us to use for par value reductions will be limited.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P105_S3	If we are unable to make a distribution through a reduction in par value or to pay a dividend out of qualifying capital contribution reserves, we may not be able to make distributions without subjecting you to Swiss withholding taxes.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P106_S0	Under Swiss tax law applicable until December 31, 2010, repurchases of shares for the purposes of capital reduction have been treated as a partial liquidation subject to 35% Swiss withholding tax on the difference between the par value and the repurchase price.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P106_S1	On January 1, 2011, under Swiss laws the portion of the repurchase price that is attributed to the qualifying capital contribution reserves of the shares repurchased will not be subject to the Swiss withholding tax.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P107_S0	We may follow a share repurchase process for future share repurchases, if any, similar to a "second trading line" on the Swiss Stock Exchange in which Swiss institutional investors buy shares on the open market and sell these shares to us and are generally able to receive a refund of the Swiss withholding tax.
1121788_11_ITEM1A_P107_S1	However, if we are unable to use this process successfully, we may not be able to repurchase shares for the purposes of capital reduction without subjecting you to Swiss withholding taxes.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P0_S0	The following are the principal properties owned or leased by the Company and its subsidiaries:
1121788_11_ITEM2_P1_S0	Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc. occupy a facility of approximately 1,120,000 square feet on 42 acres in Olathe, Kansas, where the majority of product design and development work is conducted, the majority of aviation panel-mount products are manufactured and products are warehoused, distributed, and supported for North, Central and South America.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P1_S1	Garmin s subsidiary, Garmin Realty, LLC also owns an additional 46 acres of land on the Olathe site for future expansion.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P1_S2	In connection with the bond financings for the facility in Olathe and the previous expansion of that facility, the City of Olathe holds the legal title to the Olathe facility which is leased to Garmin s subsidiaries by the City.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P1_S3	Upon the payment in full of the outstanding bonds, the City of Olathe is obligated to transfer title to Garmin s subsidiaries for the aggregate sum of $200.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P1_S4	Garmin International, Inc. has purchased all the outstanding bonds and continues to hold the bonds until maturity in order to benefit from property tax abatement.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P2_S0	Garmin Corporation owns and occupies a 249,326 square foot facility in Sijhih, Taipei County, Taiwan, a 223,469 square foot facility in Jhongli, Tao-Yang County, Taiwan, and an approximately 580,000 square foot facility in LinKou, Tao-Yang County, Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P2_S1	In these three facilities Garmin Corporation manufactures all of Garmin s consumer and portable aviation products and warehouses, markets and supports products for the Pacific Rim countries.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P3_S0	Garmin AT, Inc. leases approximately 15 acres of land in Salem, Oregon under a ground lease.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P3_S1	This ground lease expires in 2030 but Garmin AT has the option to extend the ground lease until 2050.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P4_S0	Garmin AT, Inc. owns and occupies a 115,000 square foot facility for office, development and manufacturing use and a 33,000 square foot aircraft hangar, flight test and certification facility on this land.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P4_S1	Garmin AT, Inc. also leases 43,870 square feet of office space in a separate Salem, OR building for Garmin s newly-opened West Coast customer support call center.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P5_S0	Garmin International, Inc. leases 148,320 square feet of land at New Century Airport in Gardner, Kansas under a ground lease which expires in 2026.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P5_S1	Garmin International, Inc. owns and occupies a 47,254 square foot aircraft hangar, flight test and certification facility on this land which is used in development and certification of aviation products.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P6_S0	Garmin International, Inc. leases approximately 15,000 square feet of space at 669 North Michigan Avenue in Chicago, Illinois which is used as a retail store and showroom for Garmin products.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P6_S1	This lease expires in November 2016.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P7_S0	Garmin International, Inc. also leases an additional: (i) 18,392 square feet of office space in Kansas City, Missouri for a call center operation; (ii) 48,625 square feet of office space in Olathe, Kansas for a call center operation; (iii) 24,748 square feet of aggregate office space in two buildings in Tempe, Arizona for software development; (iv) 18,500 square feet of office space in Chanhassan, MN for its Digital Cyclone subsidiary; (v) 8,183 square feet of office space in Diamond Bar, California for software development; (vi) 5,952 square feet of office space (and 17,536 square feet of land on which the premises sits) in Wichita, Kansas for aviation development and support; and (vii) 5,700 square feet in Newport, Oregon for the former Nautamatic (now TR-1) marine autopilot operations.
1121788_11_ITEM2_P8_S0	Garmin (Europe) Ltd. owns and occupies a 155,000 square foot building located in Totton, Southampton, England, used as offices and a distribution facility.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P0_S0	TomTom N.V., TomTom International B.V., and TomTom, Inc.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P1_S0	On August 14, 2009, Ambato Media, LLC filed suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas against Garmin Ltd. and Garmin International, Inc. along with several codefendants alleging infringement of U.S. Patent No. 5,432,542 ( the 542 patent ).
1121788_11_ITEM3_P1_S1	On September 28, 2009, Garmin filed its Answer and Counterclaims asserting the 542 patent is invalid and not infringed.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P1_S2	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P2_S0	No. 508 681 ( the 681 Patent ).
1121788_11_ITEM3_P3_S0	Garmin has filed separate lawsuits in the German Federal Patent Court in Munich seeking declaratory judgments of invalidity of the 892 Patent and the 681 Patent.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P3_S1	On January 11, 2011, the District Court in D sseldorf issued decisions finding infringement of the 892 and 681 Patents.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P3_S2	Garmin intends to appeal these decisions.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P3_S3	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P4_S0	In the Matter of Certain Multimedia Display and Navigation Devices and Systems, Components Thereof, and Products Containing the Same.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S0	No. 6,122,592 ( the 592 patent ), and U.S. Patent No. 5,424,951 ( the 951 patent ).
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S1	On January 12, 2010, Garmin filed its Answer asserting the 448 patent, the 592 patent, and the 951 patent are invalid and not infringed.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S2	A hearing was held from September 13-21, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S3	The parties completed their post-hearing briefing on October 14, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S4	On December 16, 2010, the Administrative Law Judge issued an Initial Determination concluding there is no violation of Section 337 and finding that the 448, 592, and 951 patents are not infringed.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S5	On January 5, 2011 Pioneer filed a petition for review of the claim construction and non-infringement holdings of the Initial Determination.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S6	Garmin awaits final confirmation of the Initial Determination by the Commission.
1121788_11_ITEM3_P5_S7	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes these claims are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
