1121788_11_ITEM6_P5_S0	All prior period common stock and applicable share and per share amounts have been retroactively adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 split of the Company's common stock effective August 15, 2006.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations focuses on and is intended to clarify the results of our operations, certain changes in our financial position, liquidity, capital structure and business developments for the periods covered by the consolidated financial statements included in this Form 10-K. This discussion should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified by reference to, the other related information including, but not limited to, the audited consolidated financial statements (including the notes thereto), the description of our business, all as set forth in this Form 10-K, as well as the risk factors discussed above in Item 1A.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P1_S0	As previously noted, the discussion set forth below, as well as other portions of this Form 10-K, contain statements concerning potential future events.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P1_S1	Readers can identify these forward-looking statements by their use of such verbs as expects, anticipates, believes or similar verbs or conjugations of such verbs.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P1_S2	If any of our assumptions on which the statements are based prove incorrect or should unanticipated circumstances arise, our actual results could materially differ from those anticipated by such forward-looking statements.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P1_S3	The differences could be caused by a number of factors or combination of factors including, but not limited to, those discussed above in Item 1A. Readers are strongly encouraged to consider those factors when evaluating any such forward-looking statement.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P1_S4	We do not undertake to update any forward-looking statements in this Form 10-K.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P2_S0	Garmin s fiscal year is a 52-53 week period ending on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P2_S1	Fiscal years 2010, 2009, and 2008 contained 52 weeks.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P2_S2	Unless otherwise stated, all years and dates refer to the Company s fiscal year and fiscal periods.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P2_S3	Unless the context otherwise requires, references in this document to "we," "us," "our" and similar terms refer to Garmin Ltd. and its subsidiaries.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P3_S0	Unless otherwise indicated, dollar amounts set forth in the tables are in thousands, except per share data.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S0	We are a leading worldwide provider of navigation, communications and information devices, most of which are enabled by Global Positioning System, or GPS, technology.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S1	We operate in four business segments, which serve the marine, outdoor/fitness, automotive/mobile, and aviation markets.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S2	Our segments offer products through our network of subsidiary distributors and independent dealers and distributors.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S3	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the four segments can vary significantly.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S4	As such, the segments are managed separately.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S5	Our portable GPS receivers and accessories for marine, recreation/fitness and automotive/mobile segments are sold primarily to retail outlets.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P4_S6	Our aviation products are portable and panel-mount avionics for Visual Flight Rules and Instrument Flight Rules navigation and are sold primarily to retail outlets and certain aircraft manufacturers.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P5_S0	Since our first products were delivered in 1991, we have generated positive income from operations each year and have funded our growth from these profits.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our sales have increased at a compounded annual growth rate of 11% since 2006 and our net income has increased at a compounded annual growth rate of 3% since 2006.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P5_S2	The vast majority of this growth has been organic; only a very small amount of new revenue occurred as a result of the acquisition of Dynastream Innovations Inc. in 2006, Digital Cyclone, Inc. and the assets of Nautamatic Marine Systems, Inc. in 2007, eleven European distributors between 2007 and 2010, and MetriGear, Inc. in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P5_S3	These acquisitions had no significant impact on net income for those years.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P6_S0	Since our principal locations are in the United States, Taiwan and the U.K., we experience some foreign currency fluctuations in our operating results.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P6_S1	The table below provides a listing of our functional currency by subsidiary excluding the European subsidiaries that utilize the Euro.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	Approximately 77% of sales by our European subsidiaries are now denominated in British Pounds Sterling or the Euro.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	We experienced ($88.4) million, ($6.0) million, and ($35.3) million in foreign currency losses during fiscal years 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	The 2008 foreign currency loss includes a realized gain of $21.5 million due to the strengthening of the Euro between the date we purchased shares in Tele Atlas N.V. in October 2007 and the tender of shares in February, March, and June 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P7_S3	To date, we have not entered into hedging transactions related to any currency, and we do not currently plan to utilize hedging transactions in the future.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	Garmin s discussion and analysis of its financial condition and results of operations are based upon Garmin s consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	The presentation of these financial statements requires Garmin to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	On an on-going basis, Garmin evaluates its estimates, including those related to customer sales programs and incentives, product returns, bad debts, inventories, investments, intangible assets, income taxes, warranty obligations, and contingencies and litigation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P8_S3	Garmin bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P8_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	Garmin recognizes revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales price is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P9_S1	For the large majority of Garmin s sales, these criteria are met once product has shipped and title and risk of loss have transferred to the customer.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P9_S2	The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of hardware products and software bundled with hardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware in accordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P9_S3	The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific software accounting guidance for standalone sales of software products and sales of software bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality of the hardware.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P9_S4	The Company generally does not offer specified or unspecified upgrade rights to its customers in connection with software sales.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	Garmin introduced n Maps Lifetime in January 2009, which is a single fee program that, subject to the program s terms and conditions, enables customers to download the latest map and point of interest information every quarter for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The revenue and associated cost of royalties for sales of n Maps Lifetime products are deferred at the time of sale and recognized ratably on a straight-line basis over the currently estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	For multiple-element arrangements that include tangible products that contain software essential to the tangible product s functionality and undelivered software elements that relate to the tangible product s essential software, the Company allocates revenue to all deliverables based on their relative selling prices.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	In such circumstances, the accounting principles establish a hierarchy to determine the selling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables as follows: (i) vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value ( VSOE ), (ii) third-party evidence of selling price ( TPE ), and (iii) best estimate of the selling price ( ESP ).
1121788_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	VSOE generally exists only when the Company sells the deliverable separately and is the price actually charged by the Company for that deliverable.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	In addition to the products listed below, the Company has offered certain other products that involve multiple-element arrangements that are immaterial.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	In 2010, Garmin began offering PNDs with lifetime map updates (LMU) bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	Similar to n Maps Lifetime which was introduced in January 2009, this enables customers to download the latest map and point of interest information every quarter for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs including LMU.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the LMU.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined primarily using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P14_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P14_S4	Amounts allocated to the LMU are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	In addition, Garmin offers PNDs with premium traffic bundled in the original purchase price in the European market.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs including premium traffic.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the premium traffic service.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P16_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P16_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P16_S4	Amounts allocated to the premium traffic service are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	service, which provides direct links to certain online information.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of the n vi 1690.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the n Link service.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P18_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P18_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P18_S4	Amounts allocated to the n Link services are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the 24-month life of the service.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	Garmin records estimated reductions to revenue for customer sales programs returns and incentive offerings including rebates, price protection (product discounts offered to retailers to assist in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases), promotions and other volume-based incentives.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	The reductions to revenue are based on estimates and judgments using historical experience and expectation of future conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	Changes in these estimates could negatively affect Garmin s operating results.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	These incentives are reviewed periodically and, with the exceptions of price protection and certain other promotions, are accrued for on a percentage of sales basis.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P19_S4	If market conditions were to decline, Garmin may take actions to increase customer incentive offerings possibly resulting in an incremental reduction of revenue at the time the incentive is offered.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	Garmin records reductions to revenue for expected future product returns based on Garmin s historical experience.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	We sell our products to retailers, wholesalers, and other customers and extend credit based on our evaluation of the customer s financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	Potential losses on receivables are dependent on each individual customer s financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	We carry our trade accounts receivable at net realizable value.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	Typically, our accounts receivable are collected within 80 days and do not bear interest.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P23_S2	We monitor our exposure to losses on receivables and maintain allowances for potential losses or adjustments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P23_S3	We determine these allowances by (1) evaluating the aging of our receivables; and (2) reviewing our high-risk customers.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P23_S4	Past due receivable balances are written off when our internal collection efforts have been unsuccessful in collecting the amount due.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Garmin s products are generally covered by a warranty for periods ranging from one to three years.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	Garmin accrues a warranty reserve for estimated costs to provide warranty services.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P24_S2	Garmin s estimate of costs to service its warranty obligations is based on historical experience and expectation of future conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P24_S3	To the extent Garmin experiences increased warranty claim activity or increased costs associated with servicing those claims, its warranty accrual will increase, resulting in decreased gross profit.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	Garmin writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-downs may be required.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	Investments are classified as available for sale and recorded at fair value, and unrealized investment gains and losses are reflected in stockholders equity.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P26_S1	Investment income is recorded when earned, and capital gains and losses are recognized when investments are sold.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P26_S2	Fair value of investments in auction rate securities are determined using third party estimates which followed an income approach valuation methodology.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P26_S3	Investments are reviewed periodically to determine if they have suffered an impairment of value that is considered other than temporary.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P26_S4	If investments are determined to be impaired, a capital loss is recognized at the date of determination.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	Testing for impairment of investments requires significant management judgment.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P27_S1	The identification of potentially impaired investments, the determination of their fair value and the assessment of whether any decline in value is other than temporary are the key judgment elements.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P27_S2	The discovery of new information and the passage of time can significantly change these judgments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P27_S3	Revisions of impairment judgments are made when new information becomes known, and any resulting impairment adjustments are made at that time.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	The economic environment and volatility of securities markets increase the difficulty of determining fair value and assessing investment impairment.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	Garmin provides deferred tax assets and liabilities based on the difference between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amount for financial reporting purposes as measured by the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	It is Garmin s policy to record a valuation allowance to reduce its deferred tax assets to an amount that it believes is more likely than not to be realized.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P29_S2	While Garmin has considered future taxable income and ongoing prudent and feasible tax planning strategies in assessing the need for the valuation allowance, in the event Garmin were to determine that it would not be able to realize all or part of its net deferred tax assets in the future, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would be charged to income in the period such determination is made.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P29_S3	Likewise, should Garmin determine that it would be able to realize its deferred tax assets in the future in excess of its net recorded amount, an adjustment to the deferred tax assets would increase income in the period such determination is made.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	In addition, the calculation of our tax liabilities involves dealing with uncertainties in the application of complex tax regulations.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	We recognize liabilities for tax audit issues in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on our estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P30_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves to be unnecessary, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P30_S3	If our estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate assessment, a further charge to expense would result.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Garmin awards stock options, stock appreciation rights ( SARs ), restricted stock units ( RSUs ) and/or performance shares each year as part of Garmin s compensation package for employees.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	Employees with certain levels of responsibility within Garmin are eligible for stock options, SAR grants, RSU grants and/or performance shares but the granting of options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares is at the discretion of the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors and is not a contractual obligation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	Stock-based compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized as expense over the requisite service period.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P32_S1	Determining the fair value of stock-based awards at the grant date requires judgment, including estimating expected dividends.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P32_S2	In addition, judgment is also required in estimating the amount of stock-based awards that are expected to be forfeited.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P32_S3	If actual results differ significantly from these estimates, stock-based compensation expense could be impacted.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P32_S4	Stock compensation plans are discussed in detail in Note 9 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	Our net sales are primarily generated through sales to our global dealer and distributor network and to original equipment manufacturers.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P33_S1	Refer to the Revenue Recognition discussion above.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	Our sales are largely of a consumer nature; therefore backlog levels are not necessarily indicative of our future sales results.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P34_S1	We aim to achieve a quick turnaround on orders we receive, and we typically ship most orders within 72 hours.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	Net sales are subject to seasonal fluctuation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	Typically, sales of our consumer products are highest in the second quarter, due to increased demand during the spring and summer season, and in the fourth quarter, due to increased demand during the holiday buying season.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	Our aviation products do not experience much seasonal variation, but are more influenced by the timing of the release of new products when the initial demand is typically the strongest.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	Raw material costs are our most significant component of cost of goods sold.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	In 2010, gross margin for our automotive/mobile segment declined 160 basis points as the average selling price declines outpaced raw material price declines.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S2	In addition, the deferral of high margin revenue and the related costs increased significantly as the product mix shifted toward products bundled with lifetime maps.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S3	See Note 2 for further information.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S4	This was partially offset by a positive refinement in the warranty reserve.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S5	In 2009, gross margin for our automotive/mobile segment increased 350 basis points as benefits from raw material price declines and operating efficiencies exceeded the average selling price decline.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S6	In 2008, gross margin for our automotive/mobile segment declined 310 basis points as the average selling price continued to decline and we experienced further shift in product mix to lower-margin product groups.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S7	These impacts were somewhat offset by raw material price declines, most significantly flash memory.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S8	Gross margins for the aviation, marine, and outdoor/fitness segments are more stable.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P36_S9	Our long-term gross margin targets are 65%, 55% and 55%, respectively, for these segments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	Our existing practice of performing the design and manufacture of our products in-house has enabled us to utilize alternative lower cost components from different suppliers and, where possible, to redesign our products to permit us to use these lower cost components.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	We believe that because of our practice of performing the design, manufacture and marketing of our products in-house, our Sijhih, Jhongli, and Lin-Kou manufacturing plants in Taiwan, our Olathe, Kansas, and Salem, Oregon manufacturing plants have experienced relatively low costs of manufacturing.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	In general, products manufactured in Taiwan have been our highest volume products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P37_S3	Our manufacturing labor costs historically have been lower in Taiwan than in Olathe and Salem.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	Sales price variability has had and can be expected to have an effect on our gross profit.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	In the past, prices of our devices sold into the automotive/mobile market have declined due to market pressures and introduction of new products sold at lower price points.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	The average selling prices of our aviation, outdoor/fitness, and marine products have been stable due to product mix and the introduction of more advanced products sold at higher prices.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P38_S3	The effect of the sales price differences inherent within the mix of GPS-enabled products sold could have a significant impact on our gross profit.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	Our advertising expenses consist of costs for both media advertising and cooperative advertising with our retail partners.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	As revenues grew in 2008, advertising expense also increased.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P39_S2	In 2009-2010, we reduced our advertising expense as revenues declined and the public became more aware of GPS technology.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P39_S3	The reduction did not have a negative impact on our market share.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P39_S4	We expect advertising costs to decrease in 2011 as revenues decline.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	Our selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of:
1121788_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses increased in 2010 due to legal costs, fees associated with the Swiss redomestication, and growth in product support and information technology to support our growing installed base of users.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	Due to the economic pressure on our consumer-oriented business, we decreased selling, general and administrative expenses in 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P41_S2	As revenues grew in 2008, selling, general and administrative expenses increased.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P41_S3	We expect selling, general and administrative costs, excluding advertising, to be stable or decline slightly in 2011 as revenues decline.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	The majority of our research and development costs represent salaries for our engineers, costs for high technology components and costs of test equipment used in product and prototype development.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	Approximately 87% of the research and development of our products is performed in North America.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	The remainder of our research and development activities is performed primarily by our Taiwan engineering group.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	We are committed to increasing the level of innovative design and development of new products as we strive for expanded ability to serve our existing consumer and aviation markets as well as new markets for GPS-enabled devices.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	We expect our research and development budget in absolute terms to be stable in 2011.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	Our top ten customers have contributed between 34% and 36% of net sales since 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	We have experienced average sales days in our customer accounts receivable of between 70 and 78 days since 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P44_S2	We have experienced an increase in the level of customer accounts receivable days due to changes in product mix, longer payment terms, and macroeconomic conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P44_S3	We expect to reduce the level of customer accounts receivable days as we negotiate shorter payment terms with our customers.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	We have experienced a relatively low effective corporate tax rate due to the proportion of our revenue generated by entities in tax jurisdictions with low statutory rates.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	In particular, the profit entitlement afforded our Swiss-based companies based on their intellectual property rights ownership of our consumer products along with substantial tax incentives offered by the Taiwanese government on certain high-technology capital investments have continued to reduce our tax rate.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S2	As a result, our consolidated effective tax rate was approximately (1.3%) during 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S3	The negative rate was due to the impact of one-time items booked in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S4	The one-time items of ($98.7) million include the release of uncertain tax position reserves from 2006 to 2008 related to our settlement with the IRS in the US, partially offset by the amount of the settlement for the 2007 tax year in the US and Taiwan surtax expense due to the release of reserves.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S5	Without one-time items, we would have reported an effective tax rate of 15.8% for 2010 compared to 12.9% for 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S6	This increase resulted from an unfavorable mix of taxable income among the tax jurisdictions in which the Company operates.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S7	We have taken advantage of the tax benefit in Taiwan since our inception and we expect to continue to benefit from lower effective tax rates at least through 2015.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S8	Management believes that due to lower operating margins predicted for fiscal 2011, there may be slightly less revenue recognized by entities in lower tax rate jurisdictions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S9	Therefore, the effective tax rate for fiscal 2011 is expected to be higher than fiscal 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P45_S10	The actual effective tax rate will be dependent upon the operating margins, production volume, additional capital investments made during fiscal 2011, and the composition of our earnings.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations as a percentage of net sales during the periods shown:
1121788_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations through income before income taxes for each of our four segments during the period shown.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	For each line item in the table the total of the segments amounts equals the amount in the consolidated statements of income data included in Item 6.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	Net sales decreased 9% in 2010 when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	The decrease occurred in automotive/mobile and was partially offset by revenue growth in outdoor/fitness, marine and aviation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	The outdoor/fitness segment experienced the greatest increase at 19%.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P48_S3	Automotive/mobile revenue remains the largest portion of our revenue mix, but declined from 70% in 2009 to 62% in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	Total unit sales decreased 4% to 16.0 million units in 2010 from 16.6 million units in 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	The declining unit sales volume in 2010 was attributable to a decline in automotive/mobile units due to increased saturation in the segment and competing technologies partially offset by increasing volumes in the outdoor/fitness, marine and aviation segments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	Automotive/mobile segment revenue declined 19% in 2010, as the average selling price and volumes declined 11% and 9%, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	Outdoor/fitness segment revenue increased 19% on the strength of recent product introductions that expand the addressable market and ongoing global penetration.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P50_S2	Marine revenues increased 12% due to product introductions, slight industry recovery and market share gains.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P50_S3	Aviation revenues increased 7% as the Company delivered into additional cockpits and the retrofit business began to recover.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	The Company anticipates ongoing revenue declines in 2011 driven by the automotive/mobile segment with partially offsetting growth in the outdoor/fitness, aviation and marine segments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	In general, management believes that continuous innovation and the introduction of new products are essential for future revenue growth.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P52_S0	Cost of goods sold decreased 11% in 2010 when compared to the year-ago period which was generally consistent with the change in revenue.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P52_S1	The absolute dollar decrease occurred in automotive/mobile and was partially offset by cost of goods increases in outdoor/fitness, marine and aviation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	Cost of goods sold in 2010 was positively impacted by 160 basis points due to a $42.8 million warranty adjustment related to refinement in the estimated warranty reserve.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	This adjustment impacted all segments with automotive/mobile, outdoor/fitness and marine having the largest benefits.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P53_S2	Cost per unit declined in all segments driving stable to improving margins in outdoor/fitness, marine and aviation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	Management believes that cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales will be stable in 2011 given current component pricing.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Gross profit dollars in 2010 decreased 7% while gross profit margin percentage increased 110 basis points compared to 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	Gross profit margins were stable to increasing in all segments excluding the automotive/mobile segment when compared to 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	The automotive/mobile segment gross profit margin percentage decrease of 160 basis points was driven by an 11% decrease in average selling price which was only partially offset by a decline in per unit costs including the warranty benefit.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	Gross profit dollars of the automotive/mobile segment declined to 50% of total gross profit dollars from 60% in 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	Gross profit dollars for marine increased 18% compared to 2009 due to product mix shifting toward higher margin units.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P56_S3	Gross profit dollars for outdoor/fitness increased by 19% to $364.5 million due to strong revenue growth in the segment.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	Management believes that total company gross margins will be stable in 2011 as growth occurs in segments with higher margin profiles offsetting continued margin pressure in the automotive/mobile segment due to price declines.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	Advertising expense decreased 7% in absolute dollars and was flat as a percentage of revenues when compared to 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P58_S1	As a percent of revenues, advertising expenses were 5% in both 2010 and 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P58_S2	The absolute dollar decrease occurred primarily in the automotive/mobile segment due to reduced cooperative advertising paid to our retail partners partially offset by mobile handset specific advertising.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P58_S3	Further offsetting the decline was increased advertising for outdoor/fitness where we continue to invest for growth.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	Management expects to maintain advertising as a percentage of sales constant in 2011.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense increased in both absolute dollars and as a percentage of revenues compared to 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	As a percent of revenues, selling, general and administrative expenses increased from 9% of revenues in 2009 to 11% of revenues in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	The expense increase was primarily driven by legal costs, fees associated with the Swiss redomestication, and growth in product support and information technology to support our growing installed base of users.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	Aviation costs declined year-over-year due to a 2009 bad debt accrual driven by cash collection risks associated with several of our customers that did not reoccur in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P61_S0	Management expects selling, general and administrative expenses to decline in absolute dollars but to increase as a percentage of sales in 2011 as revenue declines outpace cost reductions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P62_S0	Research and development expense increased 16% due to ongoing development activities for new products including the mobile handset initiative which has now been cancelled, and the addition of over 350 new engineering personnel to our staff during the period.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P62_S1	In absolute dollars, research and development costs increased $38.9 million primarily in the auto/mobile segment, when compared with the year-ago period and increased 220 basis points as a percent of revenue.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P63_S0	Management believes that one of the key strategic initiatives for future growth and success of Garmin is continuous innovation, development, and introduction of new products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P63_S1	Management expects that its research and development expenses will be stable during fiscal 2011 on an absolute dollar basis in order to deliver innovative new products and technologies.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P64_S0	Operating income decreased 300 basis points as a percent of revenue and 19% in absolute dollars when compared to the year-ago period as gross margin percentage improvements and reduced advertising expense were more than offset by declining revenues and increased selling, general and administrative and research and development expenses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P65_S0	The automotive/mobile operating margin declined from 22% in 2009 to 15% in 2010 due to a 160 basis point decline in gross margins and selling, general and administrative and research and development expense increases during a period of declining revenues.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P66_S0	Other income (expense) principally consists of interest income and foreign currency exchange gains and losses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P66_S1	Other income (expense) was lower in fiscal 2010 relative to fiscal 2009, with the majority of this difference caused by a large foreign currency loss in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P66_S2	Interest income for fiscal 2010 increased due to increasing cash and marketable securities balances during the year partially offset by decreasing interest rates.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P67_S0	Foreign currency gains and losses for the Company are primarily tied to movements by the Taiwan Dollar, the Euro, and the British Pound Sterling.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P67_S1	Due to the relative size of entities using other currencies, movements are not expected to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Euro is the functional currency of all subsidiaries excluding those shown below.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P69_S0	As subsidiaries have grown, currency moves generated material gains and losses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P69_S1	Additionally, Euro-based inter-company transactions in Garmin Ltd. can also generate currency gains and losses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P70_S0	The $88.4 million currency loss in 2010 was due to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, as well as the weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P70_S1	During 2010, the U.S. Dollar strengthened 8.8% and 3.3% compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, respectively, resulting in a loss of $51.0 million.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P70_S2	A loss of $38.7 million resulted due to the U.S. Dollar weakening 5.9% against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P71_S0	The movements of the Taiwan Dollar and Euro/British Pound Sterling have offsetting impacts due to the use of the Taiwan Dollar for manufacturing costs and cash held in non-functional currency while the Euro and British Pound Sterling transactions relate to revenue.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P71_S1	The remaining net currency gain of $1.3 million related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P72_S0	The $6.0 million currency loss in 2009 was due to the weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro, the British Pound Sterling and the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P72_S1	During 2009, the U.S. Dollar weakened 2.4% and 8.3% compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, respectively, resulting in a gain of $5.8 million.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P72_S2	A loss of $16.1 million resulted due to the U.S. Dollar weakening 2.3% against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P72_S3	The remaining net currency gain of $4.3 million related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P73_S0	Our earnings before taxes fell 29% when compared to 2009 and our income tax expense decreased by $112.0 million, to ($7.3) million, for fiscal year 2010 from $104.7 million for fiscal year 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P73_S1	The significant decline in income tax expense was due to the impact of one-time items booked in 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P73_S2	The one-time items of ($98.7) million include release of uncertain tax position reserves from 2006 to 2008 related to our settlement with the IRS in the US, partially offset by the amount of the settlement for the 2007 tax year in the US and Taiwan surtax expense due to the release of reserves.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P73_S3	Without one-time items, we would have reported an effective tax rate of 15.8% for 2010 compared to 12.9% for 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P74_S0	The increase in the adjusted effective tax rate as compared to 2009 is largely due to an unfavorable mix of income among taxing jurisdictions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income decreased 17% to $584.6 million for fiscal year 2010 compared to $704.0 million for fiscal year 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	Net sales decreased 16% in 2009 when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P76_S1	The decrease occurred across all segments, except outdoor/fitness, with the greatest decreases in the automotive/mobile and aviation segments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	Automotive/mobile revenue was the largest portion of our revenue mix, but declined from 73% in 2008 to 70% in 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	Total unit sales decreased 2% to 16.6 million in 2009 from 16.9 million in 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P78_S1	The lower unit sales volume was attributable to declining volumes across all segments, excluding outdoor/fitness, with the greatest percentage declines occurring in aviation and marine.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P78_S2	The lower volumes were driven primarily by the macroeconomic conditions and reduced inventory levels with many of our retail partners.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	Automotive/mobile segment revenue declined 19% in 2009 as the average selling price declined 18% and volumes declined 2%.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P79_S1	Average selling price declines continue to be attributable to the competitive environment in which our automotive/mobile products compete.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P79_S2	The aviation and marine segments declined 24% and 13%, respectively in 2009, as both industries experienced significant slowdowns associated with the macroeconomic conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P79_S3	Outdoor/fitness segment revenue increased 10% due to new product introductions, including the Dakota series, the Forerunner 405CX, the Forerunner 310XT and Edge 500, and increasing global penetration of the fitness category.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P79_S4	All segments showed improving trends in the second half of 2009 as the macroeconomic conditions improved.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	Cost of goods sold decreased 23% in 2009 when compared to 2008 due primarily to the 16% decline in revenue.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P80_S1	In addition, cost per unit declined in all segments driving cost of goods sold as a percentage of revenue lower due to material cost reductions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P80_S2	This savings was partially offset by inventory reserves associated with the mobile handset initiatives.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P81_S0	The decrease in gross profit dollars was primarily attributable to the automotive/mobile and aviation segments where the effects of revenue declines were partially offset by the improved gross margins earned.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P81_S1	Gross profit margin percentage for the Company overall increased 450 basis points as margins expanded in all segments.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P82_S0	The automotive/mobile segment gross profit margin percentage increase of 350 basis points was driven by material costs reductions partially offset by inventory reserves associated with the mobile handset initiative and price declines.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P82_S1	Outdoor/fitness gross margin increased principally due to a newer suite of higher margin products.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P82_S2	Gross profit margin percentage for marine and aviation increased compared to 2008 due to increased average selling price and decreases in per unit costs driven by product mix and material cost reductions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P83_S0	Advertising expense decreased both as a percentage of sales and in absolute dollars when compared to 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P83_S1	As a percent of sales, advertising expenses declined to 5% in 2009 compared to 6.0% in 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P83_S2	The decrease was a result of actions taken by the company to reduce costs as the macroeconomic conditions impacted sales across our segments and around the world combined with lower cooperative advertising which is tied to net sales levels.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P84_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense decreased 5% in 2009 while it increased as a percentage of sales compared to 2008 as costs throughout the Company were reduced but not as rapidly as the revenue declines.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P84_S1	The decline in costs was primarily related to a reduction in bad debt expense due to specific reserves recorded in 2008 as a result of vendor bankruptcies offset by increased costs for product support and information technology.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P84_S2	The increased expense for the outdoor/fitness segment and the decreased expense for the automotive/mobile segment were driven by the allocation of costs based on revenues.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P84_S3	As outdoor/fitness revenues have increased as a percentage of revenues, additional selling, general and administrative expenses are shifted to the segment.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P84_S4	As a percent of sales, selling, general and administrative expenses increased from 8% in 2008 to 9% of sales in 2009, as revenues declined.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P85_S0	The increase in research and development expense dollars was due to ongoing development activities for new products including the mobile handset initiative, the addition of 230 new engineering personnel to our staff during the period, and an increase in engineering program costs in 2009 as a result of our continued emphasis on product innovation.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P86_S0	Operating income increased 200 basis points as a percent of revenue but decreased 9% in absolute dollars when compared to the year-ago period as gross margin percentage improvements and reduced advertising expense were more than offset by declining revenues and increased research and development expenses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P87_S0	Other income (expense) principally consists of interest income and foreign currency exchange gains and losses.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P87_S1	Other income (expense) was lower in fiscal 2009 relative to fiscal 2008, with the majority of this difference caused by a large gain on sale of equity securities in 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P87_S2	Interest income for fiscal 2009 decreased due to lower interest rates, partially offset by higher cash and marketable securities balances.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P88_S0	The $6.0 million currency loss in 2009 was due to the weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro, the British Pound Sterling and the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P88_S1	During 2009, the U.S. Dollar weakened 2.4% and 8.3% compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, respectively, resulting in a gain of $5.8 million.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P88_S2	A loss of $16.1 million resulted due to the U.S. Dollar weakening 2.3% against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P89_S0	The relative weakness of the Taiwan Dollar and Euro/British Pound Sterling have offsetting impacts due to the use of the Taiwan Dollar for manufacturing costs while the Euro and British Pound Sterling transactions relate to revenue.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P89_S1	The remaining net currency gain of $4.3 million related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	The $35.3 million currency loss in 2008 was related to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar offset by a gain associated with the sales and tender of our Tele Atlas N.V. shares.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	During 2008, the Taiwan Dollar weakened 1.6% in comparison to the U.S. Dollar, resulting in a $20.8 million gain.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P91_S1	The Euro weakened 4.1% and the British Pound Sterling weakened 26.1% relative to the U.S. Dollar in 2008 which resulted in a $77.3 million loss.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P91_S2	Offsetting this net loss was a realized gain of $21.5 million due to the strengthening of the Euro between the date of purchase of the Tele Atlas N.V. shares in October 2007 to the dates of tender in February, March, and June 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P91_S3	Other net currency losses and the timing of transactions created the remaining loss of $0.3 million.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	Gain on sale of equity of securities of $50.9 million in 2008 was primarily generated from the sale of our equity interest in Tele Atlas N.V. which we acquired in 2007 in connection with our announced intent to make a cash offer for all outstanding shares, which was subsequently abandoned.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	Our fiscal 2009 earnings before taxes fell 12% when compared to 2008, while our income tax expense decreased 42%.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P93_S1	Income taxes fell $76.8 million, to $104.7 million, for fiscal year 2009 from $181.5 million for fiscal year 2008, due to a lower effective tax rate and the reduced earnings before taxes.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P93_S2	The effective tax rate was 12.9% for fiscal 2009 compared to 19.9% for fiscal 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P93_S3	The decrease in tax rate is due to the favorable mix of taxable income among the tax jurisdictions in which the Company operates and the release of income tax reserves for which the statute of limitations has expired.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income decreased 4% to $704.0 million for fiscal year 2009 compared to $732.8 million for fiscal year 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Net cash generated by operations was $770.6 million, $1,094.5 million, and $862.2 million for fiscal years 2010, 2009, and 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P95_S1	Primary drivers of the cash generation in 2010 included $584.6 million of net income with non-cash adjustments for depreciation/amortization of $94.7 million, foreign currency unrealized losses of $62.8 million, stock compensation expense of $40.3 million, $129.7 million related to decreased accounts receivable as sales levels have declined and $131.3 million of sales for which cash was received but revenue was deferred as required by our revenue recognition policies.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P95_S2	This cash generation was partially offset by uses of cash including a $144.5 million reduction in other current and noncurrent liabilities related primarily to the timing of royalty payments and the $146.4 million reversal of tax reserves associated with both release of uncertain tax position reserves from 2006 to 2008 related to our settlement with the IRS in the US and expiration of statute of limitations, a $81.4 million reduction in accounts payable primarily in our Taiwan manufacturing operations due to timing of payments, and a $77.1 million increase in inventories following a low inventory level exiting 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P95_S3	The decline in cash flow from operations over 2009 levels was due to reduced net income levels and the effect of the non cash income tax benefit realized from reduced tax reserves.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P95_S4	We expect to generate cash flow from operations in 2011 with ongoing net income, as well as working capital gains through reduced accounts receivable and inventory levels as sales decline.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	Cash flow used in investing activities was $72.9 million, $547.9 million and $56.3 million for fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S1	Cash flow used in investing activities principally relates to the net redemption of or investment in fixed income securities, capital expenditures and acquisitions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S2	Capital expenditures in 2010 totaled $32.2 million and related to business operations and maintenance activities.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S3	This has declined significantly from 2008 spending levels due to the completion of production and warehouse facility expansions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S4	We have budgeted approximately $50 million of capital expenditures during fiscal 2011 to include normal ongoing capital expenditures and maintenance activities.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S5	In 2010 and 2009, net investment in fixed income securities of our on-hand cash was $25.5 million and $491.0 million, respectively, as we invested excess cash.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S6	In 2008, the net sale of fixed income securities was primarily related to $239.3 million of cash generated from the tender of our shares of Tele Atlas N.V.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S7	It is management s goal to invest the on-hand cash consistent with Garmin s investment policy, which has been approved by the Board of Directors.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S8	The investment policy s primary purpose is to preserve capital, maintain an acceptable degree of liquidity, and maximize yield within the constraint of low credit risk.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S9	Garmin s average interest rate returns on cash and investments during fiscal 2010, 2009 and 2008 were approximately 1.3%, 1.7% and 3.4%, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P96_S10	In 2010, cash flow used in investing activities also included the acquisition of MetriGear, Inc.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	In 2008, cash flow used in investing for acquisitions related to the purchase of European distributors.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	Net cash used by financing activities in fiscal 2010 was $510.8 million resulting from the use of $298.9 million for payment of our declared dividend and $225.9 million for stock repurchased under our stock repurchase plan, partially offset by $14.0 million from the issuance of common stock related to our Company stock option plan and stock based compensation tax benefits.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	The 2010 dividend paid was significantly higher than prior years as the dividend was increased to $1.50 per share.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	Stock repurchases are made at the discretion of management under repurchase programs approved by the Board of Directors as business and market conditions warrant.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	In 2010, 2009 and 2008, the Company repurchased 7.4 million shares, 0.7 million shares and 17.1 million shares, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	We currently use cash flow from operations to fund our capital expenditures, to support our working capital requirements, to pay dividends and to repurchase shares.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	We expect that future cash requirements will principally be for capital expenditures, working capital, repurchase of shares, payment of dividends declared, and the funding of strategic acquisitions.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	We believe that our existing cash balances and cash flow from operations will be sufficient to meet our projected capital expenditures, working capital and other cash requirements at least through the end of fiscal 2011.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P102_S0	Future commitments of Garmin, as of December 25, 2010, aggregated by type of contractual obligation, are:
1121788_11_ITEM7_P103_S0	Operating leases describes lease obligations associated with Garmin facilities located in the U.S., Taiwan, Europe, and Canada.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P104_S0	We may be required to make significant cash outlays related to unrecognized tax benefits.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P104_S1	However, due to the uncertainty of the timing of future cash flows associated with our unrecognized tax benefits, we are unable to make reasonably reliable estimates of the period of cash settlement, if any, with the respective taxing authorities.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P104_S2	Accordingly, unrecognized tax benefits of $153.6 million as of December 25, 2010, have been excluded from the contractual obligations table above.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P104_S3	For further information related to unrecognized tax benefits, see Note 2, Income Taxes , to the consolidated financial statements included in this Report.
1121788_11_ITEM7_P105_S0	We do not have any off-balance sheet arrangements.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We have market risk primarily in connection with the pricing of our products and services and the purchase of raw materials.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Product pricing and raw materials costs are both significantly influenced by semiconductor market conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Historically, during cyclical industry downturns, we have been able to offset pricing declines for our products through a combination of improved product mix and success in obtaining price reductions in raw materials costs.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We do not believe that inflation has had a material effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	If our costs were to become subject to significant inflationary pressures, we may not be able to fully offset such higher costs through price increases.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P1_S2	Our inability or failure to do so could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The operation of Garmin s subsidiaries in international markets results in exposure to movements in currency exchange rates.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We have experienced significant foreign currency gains and losses due to the strengthening and weakening of the U.S. dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The potential of volatile foreign exchange rate fluctuations in the future could have a significant effect on our results of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The currencies that create a majority of the Company s exchange rate exposure are the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Garmin Corporation, headquartered in Sijhih, Taiwan, uses the local currency as the functional currency.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The Company translates all assets and liabilities at year-end exchange rates and income and expense accounts at average rates during the year.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	In order to minimize the effect of the currency exchange fluctuations on our net assets, we have elected to retain most of our Taiwan subsidiary s cash and investments in marketable securities denominated in U.S. dollars.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P7_S0	All European subsidiaries excluding Garmin (Europe) Ltd., Garmin Danmark, Garmin Sweden, Garmin Polska and Garmin Norge use the Euro as the functional currency .
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P7_S1	The functional currency of our largest European subsidiary, Garmin (Europe) Ltd. remains the U.S. dollar, and as some transactions occurred in British Pounds Sterling or Euros, foreign currency gains or losses have been realized historically related to the movements of those currencies relative to the U.S. dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P7_S2	The Company believes that gains and losses will become more material in the future as our European presence grows.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P8_S0	In 2010, the U.S. Dollar strengthened 8.8% relative to the Euro and 3.3% relative to the British Pound Sterling.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P8_S1	These currency moves resulted in a foreign currency loss of $51.0 million in Garmin Ltd. and our European subsidiaries.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P8_S2	A loss of $38.7 million resulted due to the U.S. Dollar weakening 5.9% against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P8_S3	The net result of these currency moves combined with other gains of $1.3 million, and the timing of transactions during the year was a net loss of $88.4 million for the Company and a cumulative translation adjustment of $61.7 million at the end of fiscal 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P9_S0	We have no outstanding long-term debt as of December 25, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P9_S1	We, therefore, have no meaningful debt-related interest rate risk.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P10_S0	We are exposed to interest rate risk in connection with our investments in marketable securities.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P10_S1	As interest rates change, the unrealized gains and losses associated with those securities will fluctuate accordingly.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P10_S2	A hypothetical change of 10% in interest rates would not have a material effect on such unrealized gains or losses.
1121788_11_ITEM7A_P10_S3	At December 25, 2010, cumulative unrealized losses on those securities were $4.6 million.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries (the Company) as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders' equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P0_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the index at Item 15(a)(2).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P0_S2	These financial statements and schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P0_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements and schedule based on our audits.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P1_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P1_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	Also, in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly in all material respects the information set forth therein.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Garmin Ltd. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, based on criteria established in the Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 23, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	Garmin Ltd. and subsidiaries (together, the Company ) manufacture, market, and distribute Global Positioning System-enabled products and other related products.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P5_S1	Garmin Corporation (GC), wholly-owned by Garmin Ltd., is primarily responsible for the manufacturing and distribution of the Company s products to Garmin International, Inc. (GII), a wholly-owned subsidiary of GC, and Garmin (Europe) Limited (GEL), a wholly-owned subsidiary of Garmin Ltd., and, to a lesser extent, new product development and sales and marketing of the Company s products in Asia and the Far East.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P5_S2	GII is primarily responsible for sales and marketing of the Company s products in many international markets and in the United States as well as research and new product development.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P5_S3	GII also manufactures certain products for the Company s aviation segment.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	GEL is responsible for sales and marketing of the Company s products, principally within the European market.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	The accompanying consolidated financial statements reflect the accounts of Garmin Ltd. and its wholly owned subsidiaries.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P7_S2	All significant inter-company balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	The Company has adopted a 52 53-week period ending on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P8_S1	Due to the fact that there are not exactly 52 weeks in a calendar year and there is slightly more than one additional day per year (not including the effects of leap year) in each calendar year as compared to a 52-week fiscal year, the Company will have a fiscal year comprising 53 weeks in certain fiscal years, as determined by when the last Saturday of the calendar year occurs.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	In those resulting fiscal years that have 53 weeks, the Company will record an extra week of sales, costs, and related financial activity.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P9_S1	Therefore, the financial results of those fiscal years, and the associated 14-week fourth quarter, will not be entirely comparable to the prior and subsequent 52-week fiscal years and the associated quarters having only 13 weeks.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P9_S2	Fiscal 2010, 2009, and 2008 included 52 weeks.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	Many Garmin Ltd. subsidiaries utilize currencies other than the United States Dollar (USD) as their functional currency.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P10_S1	As required by the Foreign Currency Matters topic of the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC), the financial statements of these subsidiaries for all periods presented have been translated into USD, the functional currency of Garmin Ltd., and the reporting currency herein, for purposes of consolidation at rates prevailing during the year for sales, costs, and expenses and at end-of-year rates for all assets and liabilities.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P10_S2	The effect of this translation is recorded in a separate component of stockholders equity.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P10_S3	Cumulative translation adjustments of $61,740 and $9,231 as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively, have been included in accumulated other comprehensive gain/(loss) in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	Transactions in foreign currencies are recorded at the approximate rate of exchange at the transaction date.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	Assets and liabilities resulting from these transactions are translated at the rate of exchange in effect at the balance sheet date.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S2	All differences are recorded in results of operations and amounted to exchange gains/(losses) of ($88,377), ($6,040), and ($35,286) for the years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009, and December 27, 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S3	The loss in fiscal 2010 was primarily the result of the strengthening of the USD against the Euro and the British Pound Sterling and the weakening of the USD against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S4	The loss in fiscal 2009 was primarily the result of the weakening of the USD against the Taiwan Dollar offset by the weakening of the USD against the Euro and the British Pound Sterling.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P11_S5	The loss in fiscal 2008 was the result of the strengthening of the USD offset by a gain associated with the sale and tender of our Tele Atlas N.V. shares.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	Basic earnings per share amounts are computed based on the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P12_S1	For purposes of diluted earnings per share, the number of shares that would be issued from the exercise of dilutive stock options has been reduced by the number of shares which could have been purchased from the proceeds of the exercise at the average market price of the Company s stock during the period the options were outstanding.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	For purposes of reporting cash flows, cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand, operating accounts, money market funds, and securities with maturities of three months or less when purchased.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P13_S1	The carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents approximates fair value, given the short maturity of those instruments.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	The Company sells its products to retailers, wholesalers, and other customers and extends credit based on its evaluation of the customer s financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S1	Potential losses on receivables are dependent on each individual customer s financial condition.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S2	The Company carries its trade accounts receivable at net realizable value.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S3	Typically, its accounts receivable are collected within 80 days and do not bear interest.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S4	The Company monitors its exposure to losses on receivables and maintains allowances for potential losses or adjustments.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S5	The Company determines these allowances by (1) evaluating the aging of its receivables and (2) reviewing its high-risk customers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P14_S6	Past due receivable balances are written off when its internal collection efforts have been unsuccessful in collecting the amount due.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	Cost is determined using the weighted-average method (which approximates the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method) by GC and the FIFO method by GII, GAT and GEL.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	Property and equipment are recorded at cost and depreciated using the straight-line method over the following estimated useful lives:
1121788_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	As required by the Property, Plant and Equipment topic of the FASB ASC, the Company reviews long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be fully recoverable.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	The carrying amount of a long-lived asset is not recoverable if it exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition of the asset.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P18_S2	That assessment is based on the carrying amount of the asset at the date it is tested for recoverability.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	An impairment loss is measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair value.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	The Intangibles Goodwill and Other topic of the FASB ASC requires that goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite useful lives should not be amortized but rather be tested for impairment at least annually or sooner whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that they may be impaired.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P20_S1	The Company did not recognize any goodwill or intangible asset impairment charges in 2010, 2009, or 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	The Company established reporting units based on its current reporting structure.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P21_S1	For purposes of testing goodwill for impairment, goodwill has been allocated to these reporting units to the extent it relates to each reporting unit.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	The accounting guidance also requires that intangible assets with definite lives be amortized over their estimated useful lives and reviewed for impairment.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company is currently amortizing its acquired intangible assets with definite lives over periods ranging from 3 to 10 years.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	On March 16, 2010 the Board of Directors declared a dividend of $1.50 per share to be paid on April 30, 2010 to shareholders of record on April 15, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P23_S1	The Company paid out a dividend in the amount of $298,853.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P23_S2	The dividend has been reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
