1121788_11_ITEM8_P24_S1	The Company paid out a dividend in the amount of $149,846.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P24_S2	The dividend has been reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	On June 6, 2008 the Board of Directors declared a dividend of $0.75 per share to be paid on December 15, 2008 to shareholders of record on December 1, 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	The Company paid out a dividend in the amount of $150,251.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P25_S2	The dividend has been reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	Approximately $213,486 and $199,549 of retained earnings are indefinitely restricted from distribution to stockholders pursuant to the laws of Taiwan at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, the Company had patents, license agreements, customer related intangibles and other identifiable finite-lived intangible assets recorded at a cost of $152,138 and $165,021, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P27_S1	The Company s excess purchase cost over fair value of net assets acquired (goodwill) was $136,548 at December 25, 2010 and $129,066 at December 26, 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	Identifiable, finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives on a straight-line basis over three to ten years.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P28_S1	Accumulated amortization was $103,534 and $80,428 at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P28_S2	Amortization expense was $36,675, $37,444, and $30,874, for the years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009, and December 27, 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P28_S3	In the next five years, the amortization expense is estimated to be $24,889, $10,584, $4,612, $2,482, and $2,317, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of marketable securities at the time of purchase and reevaluates such designation as of each balance sheet date.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	All of the Company s marketable securities are considered available-for-sale at December 25, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P30_S1	Available-for-sale securities are stated at fair value, with the unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive gain/(loss).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P30_S2	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, cumulative unrealized gains/(losses) of ($5,736) and ($22,613), respectively, were reported in accumulated other comprehensive gain/(loss), net of related taxes.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	The amortized cost of debt securities classified as available-for-sale is adjusted for amortization of premiums and accretion of discounts to maturity, or in the case of mortgage-backed securities, over the estimated life of the security.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	Such amortization is included in interest income from investments.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P31_S2	Realized gains and losses, and declines in value judged to be other-than-temporary are included in other income.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company accounts for income taxes using the liability method in accordance with the FASB ASC topic Income Taxes .
1121788_11_ITEM8_P33_S1	The liability method provides that deferred tax assets and liabilities are recorded based on the difference between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amount for financial reporting purposes as measured by the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	Income taxes of $233,028 and $171,097 at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively, have not been accrued by the Company for the unremitted earnings of several of its subsidiaries because such earnings are intended to be reinvested in the subsidiaries indefinitely.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	The Company adopted the applicable guidance included in the FASB ASC topic Income Taxes related to accounting for uncertainty in income taxes on December 31, 2006, the beginning of fiscal year 2007.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	The total amount of unrecognized tax benefits as of December 25, 2010 was $153,621 including interest of $9,580.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P35_S2	A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized tax benefits for years ending December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 is as follows:
1121788_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	The December 25, 2010 balance of $153,621 of unrecognized tax benefits, if recognized, would reduce the effective tax rate.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P36_S1	None of the unrecognized tax benefits are due to uncertainty in the timing of deductibility.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	Accounting guidance requires unrecognized tax benefits to be classified as non-current liabilities, except for the portion that is expected to be paid within one year of the balance sheet date.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P37_S1	The entire $153,621 and $255,748 are required to be classified as non-current at December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	Interest expense and penalties, if any, accrued on the unrecognized tax benefits are reflected in income tax expense.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P38_S1	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, the Company had accrued approximately $9,580 and $20,160 respectively for interest.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P38_S2	Interest expense included in income tax expense for the years ending December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 are ($10,580) and $9,000, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P38_S3	The Company had no amounts accrued for penalties as the nature of the unrecognized tax benefits, if recognized, would not warrant the imposition of penalties.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, and various state, local and foreign jurisdictions.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P39_S1	The Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state, or local tax examinations by tax authorities for years prior to 2007.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P39_S2	The Company is no longer subject to Taiwan income tax examinations by tax authorities for years prior to 2005.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P39_S3	The Company is no longer subject to United Kingdom tax examinations by tax authorities for years prior to 2008.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	The Company also considers 2007 and 2008 US federal returns to have been effectively settled due to completion of an audit examination by the Internal Revenue Service.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	A reduction of income tax expense of ($122,314) was recognized to reflect this settlement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P40_S2	In addition, the Company recognized a reduction of income tax expense of $24,066 and $19,771 in fiscal years ended December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, respectively, to reflect the expiration of statute of limitations in various jurisdictions.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Company believes that it is reasonably possible that approximately $14,069 million of its reserves for certain unrecognized tax benefits will decrease within the next 12 months as the result of the expiration of statute of limitations.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P41_S1	This potential decrease in unrecognized tax benefits would impact the Company s effective tax rate within the next 12 months.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company grants credit to certain customers who meet the Company s pre-established credit requirements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P43_S1	Generally, the Company does not require security when trade credit is granted to customers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P43_S2	Credit losses are provided for in the Company s consolidated financial statements and typically have been within management s expectations.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	Certain customers are allowed extended terms consistent with normal industry practice.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	Most of these extended terms can be classified as either relating to seasonal sales variations or to the timing of new product releases by the Company.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	Garmin recognizes revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales price is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	For the large majority of Garmin s sales, these criteria are met once product has shipped and title and risk of loss have transferred to the customer.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P45_S2	The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of hardware products and software bundled with hardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware in accordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P45_S3	The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific software accounting guidance for standalone sales of software products and sales of software bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality of the hardware.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P45_S4	The Company generally does not offer specified or unspecified upgrade rights to its customers in connection with software sales.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	Garmin introduced n Maps Lifetime in January 2009, which is a single fee program that, subject to the program s terms and conditions, enables customers to download the latest map and point of interest information every quarter for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	The revenue and associated cost of royalties for sales of n Maps Lifetime products are deferred at the time of sale and recognized ratably on a straight-line basis over the currently estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	For multiple element arrangements that include tangible products that contain software that is essential to the tangible product s functionality and undelivered software elements that relate to the tangible product s essential software, the Company allocates revenue to all deliverables based on their relative selling prices.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	In such circumstances, the new accounting principles establish a hierarchy to determine the selling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables as follows: (i) vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value ( VSOE ), (ii) third-party evidence of selling price ( TPE ), and (iii) best estimate of the selling price ( ESP ).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P47_S2	VSOE generally exists only when the Company sells the deliverable separately and is the price actually charged by the Company for that deliverable.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	In addition to the products listed below, the Company has offered certain other products that involve multiple-element arrangements that are immaterial.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	In 2010, Garmin began offering PNDs with lifetime map updates (LMU) bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P49_S1	Similar to n Maps Lifetime which was introduced in January 2009, this enables customers to download the latest map and point of interest information every quarter for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs including LMU.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P50_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the LMU.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P50_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined primarily using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P50_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P50_S4	The revenue and associated cost of royalties allocated to the LMU are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	In addition, Garmin offers PNDs with premium traffic bundled in the original purchase price in the European market.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs including premium traffic.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P52_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the premium traffic service.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P52_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P52_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P52_S4	The revenue and associated cost allocated to the premium traffic service are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated 36-month life of the products.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	service, which provides direct links to certain online information.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company has identified two deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of the n vi 1690 and 1695.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P54_S1	The first deliverable is the hardware and software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale, and the second deliverable is the n Link service.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P54_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these two deliverables using the relative selling price method determined using VSOE.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P54_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P54_S4	The revenue and associated cost allocated to the n Link services are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the 24-month life of the service.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	Garmin records estimated reductions to revenue for customer sales programs returns and incentive offerings including rebates, price protection (product discounts offered to retailers to assist in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases), promotions and other volume-based incentives.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P55_S1	The reductions to revenue are based on estimates and judgments using historical experience and expectation of future conditions.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P55_S2	Changes in these estimates could negatively affect Garmin s operating results.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P55_S3	These incentives are reviewed periodically and, with the exceptions of price protection and certain other promotions, are accrued for on a percentage of sales basis.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P55_S4	If market conditions were to decline, Garmin may take actions to increase customer incentive offerings possibly resulting in an incremental reduction of revenue at the time the incentive is offered.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	The Company records reductions to revenue for expected future product returns based on the Company s historical experience.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	At December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009, the Company had deferred revenues totaling $197,787 and $66,484, respectively, and related deferred costs totaling $44,738 and $13,310, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	The deferred revenues and costs are recognized over their estimated economic lives of two to three years on a straight-line basis.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P58_S1	In the next three years, the gross margin recognition of deferred revenue and cost for the currently deferred amounts is estimated to be $69,623, $56,617, and $26,809, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in cost of goods sold in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	The Company provides for estimated warranty costs at the time of sale.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	The warranty period is generally for one year from date of shipment with the exception of certain aviation products for which the warranty period is two years from the date of installation and certain marine products for which the warranty period is three years from the date of shipment .
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Company provides certain monthly and quarterly incentives for its dealers and distributors based on various factors including dealer purchasing volume and growth.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S1	Additionally, from time to time, the Company provides rebates to end users on certain products.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S2	Estimated rebates and incentives payable to dealers and distributors are regularly reviewed and recorded as accrued expenses on a monthly basis.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S3	In addition, the Company provides dealers and distributors with product discounts to assist these customers in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S4	Each discount is tied to a specific product and can be applied to all customers who have purchased the product or a special discount may be agreed to on an individual customer basis.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P61_S5	These rebates, incentives, and discounts are recorded as reductions to net sales in the accompanying consolidated statements of income in the period the Company has sold the product.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P62_S1	Advertising expense amounted to approximately $144,613, $155,521, and $208,177 for the years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009, and December 27, 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P63_S0	A majority of the Company s research and development is performed in the United States.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P63_S1	Research and development costs, which are expensed as incurred, amounted to approximately $277,261, $238,378, and $206,109 for the years ended December 25, 2010, December 26, 2009, and December 27, 2008, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P64_S0	Customer service and technical support costs are included as selling, general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P64_S1	Customer service and technical support costs include costs associated with performing order processing, answering customer inquiries by telephone and through Web sites, e-mail and other electronic means, and providing free technical support assistance to customers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P64_S2	The technical support is provided within one year after the associated revenue is recognized.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P64_S3	The related cost of providing this free support is not material.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P65_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Software requires companies to expense software development costs as they incur them until technological feasibility has been established, at which time those costs are capitalized until the product is available for general release to customers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P65_S1	Our capitalized software development costs are not significant as the time elapsed from working model to release is typically short.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P65_S2	As required by the Research and Development topic of the FASB ASC, costs we incur to enhance our existing products or after the general release of the service using the product are expensed in the period they are incurred and included in research and development costs in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P66_S0	The Company currently sponsors three stock based employee compensation plans.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P66_S1	The FASB ASC topic entitled Compensation Stock Compensation requires the measurement and recognition of compensation expenses for all share-based payment awards made to employees and directors including employee stock options and restricted stock based on estimated fair values.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P67_S0	Accounting guidance requires companies to estimate the fair value of share-based payment awards on the date of grant using an option-pricing model.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P67_S1	The value of the portion of the award that is ultimately expected to vest is recognized as stock-based compensation expenses over the requisite service period in the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P68_S0	As stock-based compensation expenses recognized in the accompanying consolidated statement of income are based on awards ultimately expected to vest, they have been reduced for estimated forfeitures.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P68_S1	Accounting guidance requires forfeitures to be estimated at the time of grant and revised, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P68_S2	Forfeitures were estimated based on historical experience and management s estimates.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P69_S0	In January 2010, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU) No. 2010-06, "Improving Disclosures about Fair Value Measurements" ("ASU 2010-06"), which is included in the ASC Topic 820 (Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P69_S1	ASU 2010-06 requires new disclosures on the amount and reason for transfers in and out of Level 1 and 2 fair value measurements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P69_S2	ASU 2010-06 also requires disclosure of activities, including purchases, sales, issuances, and settlements within the Level 3 fair value measurements and clarifies existing disclosure requirements on levels of disaggregation and disclosures about inputs and valuation techniques.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P69_S3	Except as otherwise provided, ASU 2010-06 is effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2009.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P70_S0	The adoption of this standard did not have a material effect on the Company s financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P71_S0	In February 2010, the FASB issued ASU No. 2010-09, "Amendments to Certain Recognition and Disclosure Requirements" ("ASU 2010-09"), which is included in ASC Topic 855 (Subsequent Events).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P71_S1	ASU 2010-09 clarifies that an SEC filer is required to evaluate subsequent events through the date that the financial statements are issued.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P71_S2	ASU 2010-09 was effective upon the issuance of the final update and did not have a significant impact on the Company's financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P72_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P73_S0	The accounting guidance classifies the inputs used to measure fair value into the following hierarchy:
1121788_11_ITEM8_P74_S0	The Company endeavors to utilize the best available information in measuring fair value.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P74_S1	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P75_S0	For fair value measurements using significant unobservable inputs, an independent third party provided the valuation.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P75_S1	The inputs used in the valuations used the following methodology.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P76_S0	The collateral composition was used to estimate Weighted Average Life based on historical and projected payment information.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P76_S1	Cash flows were projected for the issuing trusts, taking into account underlying loan principal, bonds outstanding, and payout formulas.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P76_S2	Taking this information into account, assumptions were made as to the yields likely to be required, based upon then current market conditions for comparable or similar term Asset Based Securities as well as other fixed income securities.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P78_S0	All Level 3 investments have been in a continuous unrealized loss position for 12 months or longer.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P78_S1	However, it is the Company s intent to hold these securities until they recover their value.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P79_S0	For assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis using significant unobservable inputs (Level 3) during the period, the accounting guidance requires a reconciliation of the beginning and ending balances, separately for each major category of assets.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P83_S0	The unrealized losses on the Company s investments in 2009 and 2010 were caused primarily by changes in interest rates, specifically, widening credit spreads.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P83_S1	The Company s investment policy requires investments to be rated A or better with the objective of minimizing the potential risk of principal loss.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P83_S2	The Company does not intend to sell the securities that have an unrealized loss shown in the table above and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the investment before recovery of their amortized costs bases, which may be maturity.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P83_S3	Therefore, the Company considers the declines to be temporary in nature.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P84_S0	Fair values were determined for each individual security in the investment portfolio.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P84_S1	When evaluating the investments for other-than-temporary impairment, the Company reviews factors such as the length of time and extent to which fair value has been below cost basis, the financial condition of the issuer, and the Company s ability and intent to hold the investment for a period of time, which may be sufficient for anticipated recovery in market value.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P84_S2	During 2009 and 2010, the Company did not record any material impairment charges on its outstanding securities.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P91_S1	It is not possible to predict with certainty whether or not the Company and its subsidiaries will ultimately be successful in any of these legal matters, or if not, what the impact might be.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P91_S2	However, the Company s management does not expect that the results in any of these legal proceedings will have a material adverse effect on the Company s results of operations, financial position or cash flows.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P102_S0	The Company operates within its targeted markets through four reportable segments, those being related to products sold into the marine, automotive/mobile, outdoor/fitness, and aviation markets.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P102_S1	For external reporting purposes, we aggregate operating segments which have similar economic characteristics, products, production processes, types or classes of customers and distribution methods into reportable segments.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P102_S2	All of the Company s reportable segments offer products through the Company s network of independent dealers and distributors as well as through OEM s.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P102_S3	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the four reportable segments vary significantly.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P103_S0	The Company s marine, automotive/mobile, and outdoor/fitness segments include portable global positioning system (GPS) receivers and accessories sold primarily to retail outlets.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P103_S1	These products are produced primarily by the Company s subsidiary in Taiwan.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P104_S0	The Company s aviation products are portable and panel mount avionics for Visual Flight Rules and Instrument Flight Rules navigation and are sold primarily to aviation dealers and certain aircraft manufacturers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P105_S0	The Company s Chief Executive Officer has been identified as the Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P105_S1	The CODM evaluates performance and allocates resources based on income before income taxes of each segment.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P106_S0	Income before income taxes represents net sales less operating expenses including certain allocated general and administrative costs, interest income and expense, foreign currency adjustments, and other non-operating corporate expenses.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P107_S0	The accounting policies of the reportable segments are the same as those described in the summary of significant accounting policies.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P107_S1	There are no inter-segment sales or transfers.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P108_S0	The identifiable assets associated with each reportable segment reviewed by the CODM include accounts receivable and inventories.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P108_S1	The Company does not report property and equipment, intangible assets, depreciation and amortization, or capital expenditures by segment to the CODM.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P119_S0	The fair value for these options was estimated at the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model with the following weighted-average assumptions for 2010, 2009, and 2008:
1121788_11_ITEM8_P120_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of traded options which have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P120_S1	In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected stock price volatility.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P120_S2	Because the Company s employee stock options have characteristics significantly different from those of traded options, and because changes in the subjective input assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate, in management s opinion, the existing models do not necessarily provide a reliable single measure of the fair value of its employee stock options.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P121_S0	The weighted-average fair value for all awards granted during 2010, 2009, and 2008 was $29.09, $29.20, and $37.96, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S0	The total fair value of awards vested during 2010, 2009, and 2008 was $41,249, $41,527, and $35,384, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S1	The aggregate intrinsic values of options and SARs outstanding and exercisable at December 25, 2010 were $21,723 and $21,563, respectively.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S2	The aggregate intrinsic value of options and SARs exercised during the year ended December 25, 2010 was $12,259.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S3	The aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs outstanding at December 25, 2010 was $45,645.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S4	The aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs released during the year ended December 25, 2010 was $8,828.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P122_S5	Aggregate intrinsic value represents the positive difference between the Company s closing stock price on the last trading day of the fiscal period, which was $30.36 on December 25, 2010, and the exercise price multiplied by the number of options exercised.

1121788_11_ITEM8_P131_S0	The redomestication effectively changed the place of incorporation of the ultimate parent holding company of Garmin from the Cayman Islands to Switzerland.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P132_S0	On February 9, 2010, Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) formed Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) as a direct subsidiary.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P133_S0	On April 6, 2010, Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) petitioned the Cayman Court to order, among other things, the calling of a meeting of Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) common shareholders to approve a scheme of arrangement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P133_S1	On April 7, 2010, the Cayman Court ordered us to seek shareholder approval of the scheme of arrangement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P133_S2	On May 20, 2010 we obtained the necessary shareholder approval.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P133_S3	On June 4, 2010, a hearing was held by the Cayman Court and at which hearing the Cayman Court was asked to and did approve the scheme of arrangement.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P133_S4	The scheme of arrangement became effective at 3:00 a.m., Cayman Islands time, on Sunday, June 27, 2010 (the Transaction Time ).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P134_S0	At and shortly following the Transaction Time, the following steps occurred:
1121788_11_ITEM8_P135_S0	all issued and outstanding Garmin Ltd.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P136_S0	in consideration, Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) (a) issued registered shares (on a one-for-one basis) to the holders of the Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) common shares that were transferred to Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland), and (b) increased the par value of the 10,000,000 shares of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) issued to Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) in connection with the formation of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) (the Formation Shares ) to the same par value as the shares of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) issued to the Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) shareholders.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P136_S1	The Formation Shares were subsequently transferred by Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) to its subsidiary, Garmin Luxembourg S. r.l. for future use to satisfy our obligations to deliver shares in connection with awards granted under our equity incentive plans for employees and other general corporate purposes.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P137_S0	As a result of the redomestication, the shareholders of Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) became shareholders of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland), and Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) became a subsidiary of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P137_S1	In addition, Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland) assumed, on a one-for-one basis, Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) s existing obligations in connection with awards granted under Garmin Ltd.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P137_S2	(Cayman) s equity incentive plans and other similar equity awards.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P138_S0	Any stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock units or performance shares issued by Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) that are convertible, exchangeable or exercisable into common shares of Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) became convertible, exchangeable or exercisable, as the case may be, into registered shares of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P139_S0	Subsequently on July 26, 2010, Garmin Ltd. (Cayman) relocated its registered office to Switzerland and changed its name to Garmin Switzerland GmbH.
1121788_11_ITEM8_P139_S1	The reported capitalization of the Company also changed to that of Garmin Ltd. (Switzerland).
1121788_11_ITEM8_P139_S2	CHF 10/ USD 9.0744) , and retained earnings was reduced by the same amount.

1121788_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, we have evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures pursuant to Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(b) as of the end of the period covered by this report.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on the evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting for the Company.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management s assessment of and conclusion on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting are included as Exhibits 31.1, 31.2, 32.1 and 32.2.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Management of the Company assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P4_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework .
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Based on such assessment and those criteria, management believes that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Ernst Young LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the Company s consolidated financial statements, issued an attestation report on management s effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P7_S0	We have audited Garmin Ltd. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (the COSO criteria).
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P7_S1	Garmin Ltd. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P8_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P11_S0	In our opinion, Garmin Ltd. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 25, 2010, based on the COSO criteria.
1121788_11_ITEM9A_P12_S0	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries as of December 25, 2010 and December 26, 2009 and the related consolidated statements of income, stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 25, 2010 of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries and our report dated February 23, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
