1121788_14_ITEM1_P58_S3	Additional advanced features and connectivity available include: Garmin s G Motion technology, which delivers ultra-smooth map panning and zooming, optional wireless remote and a wireless mouse and expanded plug-and-play access to onboard sensors, with NMEA 2000 and Garmin Marine Network connectivity (the Garmin Marine Network is a system that combines GPS, radar, XM WX Satellite Weather, sonar, and other data).
1121788_14_ITEM1_P59_S0	Garmin offers two series of fishfinders.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P59_S1	The echo series are standalone fishfinders ranging from grayscale displays to the highest-end echo 550C, which features a video-quality 640x480 pixel 5-inch VGA screen, a powerful 500-watt sonar transmitter, and offers fish arch display and bottom tracking as deep as 1,900 feet.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P59_S2	The echoMap series provides charplotter and fishfinder capabilities in a single device.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P60_S0	Garmin offers black-box sounders which interface with Garmin MFDs to enhance their utility by providing the depth sounder and fish finder functions in a remote mounted package.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P61_S0	Garmin offers full-featured marine autopilot systems designed for sailboats and powerboats.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P61_S1	The systems incorporate such features as: Garmin s patented Shadow Drive technology, which automatically disengages the autopilot if the helm is turned, remote steering and speed control, and integration with the Volvo Penta IPS steering and propulsion system.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P61_S2	Garmin has also introduced steer-by-wire autopilot capabilities for various steering systems.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P62_S0	Garmin offers both radomes and open array radar products with compatibility to any network-compatible Garmin chartplotter so that the chartplotter can double as the radar screen.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P62_S1	The Garmin radar solutions have a nautical mile range of 36-72 nm.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P63_S0	Garmin offers NMEA 2000 and NMEA 0183 compliant instrument displays that show data from multiple remote sensors on one screen.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P63_S1	Mariners can display instrument data such as depth, speed through the water, water temperature, fuel flow rate, engine data, fuel level, wind direction and more, depending upon what sensors are connected.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P64_S0	Garmin provides marine radios with differing feature sets for the radio needs of all types of mariners.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P64_S1	The entry-level radio is NMEA 0183 compatible, while the premium radio is designed for 35+ foot boats, is NMEA 2000 and NMEA 0183 compatible, offers multi-station support, and monitors all AIS channels at the same time.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P65_S0	Garmin offers a m arine-friendly GPS handheld featuring a 3-axis tilt-compensated electronic compass, wireless data transfer between compatible units and preloaded cartography for the coastal United States.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P65_S1	Also offered for mariners is the quatix , Garmin s first GPS watch designed for mariners, combining marine features and navigation and sailing capabilities while integrating Garmin s GPS technology and interface.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P66_S0	In September 2012, Garmin acquired Nexus Marine AB, a leading supplier of instrumentation for the sailing and yachting market.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P66_S1	Nexus designs and manufactures sailing instrumentation systems, and it also supplies binoculars, accessories and Silva branded marine compasses.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P67_S0	Garmin s aviation product line includes GPS-enabled navigation, VHF communications transmitters/receivers, multi-function displays, electronic flight instrumentation systems (EFIS), automatic flight control systems, traffic advisory systems and traffic collision avoidance systems, terrain awareness and warning systems, instrument landing system (ILS) receivers, surveillance products, audio panels, cockpit datalink systems and more.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P67_S1	The list below includes a sampling of some of the aviation capabilities currently offered by Garmin:
1121788_14_ITEM1_P68_S0	Garmin offers a range of integrated glass avionics from the G3X for the experimental and light-sport aircraft market to the G5000 for the business jet market.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P68_S1	Basic capabilities integrated include: navigation, communication, attitude, weather, terrain, traffic, surveillance and engine information on large high-resolution color displays.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P68_S2	More advanced features include: Garmin s 3-D synthetic vision technology (SVT ), weather, Garmin s electronic stability and protection system (ESP), electronic flight charts and touchscreen controls, which utilize patent pending, infrared touchscreen technology, audio and visual feedback, and animation to help pilots know exactly how the system is responding to their input.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P69_S0	Garmin offers similar integrated glass avionics for the helicopter market through the G500H, G1000H and G5000H .
1121788_14_ITEM1_P70_S0	Basic and advanced capabilities are similar to those offered to the aircraft market.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P70_S1	The helicopter offerings have been optimized for rotorcraft and offer features like helicopter synthetic vision technology (HSVT ), helicopter-specific databases with over 7,000 heliports and nearly 30,000 additional low-altitude obstacles, XM WX Satellite Weather with NEXRAD, and the ability to display video from a forward looking infrared (FLIR) camera or other video sources.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P71_S0	Garmin also offers all-glass integrated avionics to the retrofit market through the G500 and G600.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P71_S1	These solutions provide electronic flight displays that work with separate Garmin avionics to provide essential information such as attitude, air data, weather, terrain and traffic.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P71_S2	In addition, upgraded systems also allow for the display and control of such data as altitude preselects and vertical speed, DME distance, analog radar altitude, and analog navigation data.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P72_S0	Garmin provides certified GPS navigation receivers, traditional VHF navigation receivers, instrument landing systems receivers and VHF communication transmitters/receivers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P72_S1	Features available in different GNC, GTR, GNS and GTN series models include 4-color map graphics, GPS, communication and navigation capabilities, touchscreen operation, graphical flight planning with vector airways and high-altitude jet routes, remote transponder, remote audio control, SafeTaxi and electronic chart capabilities.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P72_S2	Helicopter Terrain Awareness and Warning System (HTAWS) is an option providing graphical and audible alerts of potential terrain and obstacle conflicts along the flight path.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P73_S0	Garmin offers traffic avoidance products combining active and passive surveillance data to pinpoint specific traffic threats.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P73_S1	These capabilities are part of our GTS series of systems.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P73_S2	The systems use Garmin s patent- pending CLEAR CAS technology and correlate automatic dependent surveillance broadcast (ADS-B) with radar targets.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P73_S3	The offerings include solutions for both the recreational and transport category of aircraft.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P74_S0	The GMA series are audio panels ranging from offerings with basic capabilities for the recreational pilot to advanced capabilities including voice recognition, 3D spatial audio processing, advanced auto squelch, ambient noise based volume adjustment and independent pilot/co-pilot communications capabilities.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P75_S0	Garmin provides a range of transponder solutions in the GTX series.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P75_S1	The FAA-certified transponders transmit altitude or flight identification to air traffic control radar systems or other aircraft s air traffic avoidance devices.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P75_S2	Newer transponders offer data link capability, including local air traffic information at FAA radar sites equipped with Traffic Information Service (TIS) and a pathway to ADS-B compliance for the Next Generation airspace system, via transmission of traffic surveillance data such as aircraft flight ID, position, altitude, velocity, climb/descent, and heading information.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P76_S0	Garmin offers solutions to both recreational and transport aircraft.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P77_S0	Garmin offers an FAA certified ADS-B product within the GDL series.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P77_S1	Capabilities include GPS satellite navigation with datalink communications to deliver interactive traffic and hazard surveillance.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P78_S0	Weather capabilities are delivered within our GDL, GSR and GWX series.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P78_S1	The solutions range from offering XM WX satellite real-time weather information to the aircraft via panel-mounted devices from Garmin to on-demand global weather information, text/voice communications and near real-time position tracking through the Iridium satellite network (subscription required).
1121788_14_ITEM1_P78_S2	Also available in the GWX series are all-in-one antenna/receiver/transmitters that bring real-time weather to Garmin s multi-function displays and Integrated Avionics Systems, as well as advanced Doppler-enabled features.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P79_S0	Garmin offers the aera series and GPSMAP 695/696 as portable avionics solutions.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P79_S1	The aera series combines an aviation portable with a full-featured automotive GPS.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P79_S2	These touchscreen products come with automotive maps, a terrain/obstacles aviation database, and a patented instrument display.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P79_S3	Advanced features include: a digital document viewer, a scratch pad, pre-loaded geo-referenced charts, and XM radio and weather.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P80_S0	The GPSMAP series offers detailed electronic charts, airways and IFR map mode.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P80_S1	Other features available include: XM radio and XM WX Satellite Weather.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P81_S0	Garmin announced D2 in October 2013, which is a premium watch designed specifically for aviators.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P82_S0	Garmin Pilot is a premium flight planning, flight plan filing, and pre-flight weather application for display on iOS and Android-based mobile devices.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P82_S1	It provides instant access to comprehensive U.S. and Canada weather data, winds and temperature aloft, and lightning data.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P83_S0	Garmin s non-aviation products are sold in approximately 100 countries through a worldwide network of approximately 4,000 independent dealers and distributors, who meet our sales and customer service qualifications.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P83_S1	No single customer s purchases represented 10% or more of Garmin s consolidated revenues in the fiscal year ended December 28, 2013.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P84_S0	Marketing support is provided geographically from Garmin s offices around the world.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P84_S1	Garmin s distribution strategy is intended to increase Garmin s global penetration and presence while maintaining high quality standards to ensure end-user satisfaction.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P85_S0	Garmin s U.S. consumer product sales are handled through its network of dealers and distributors who are serviced by a staff of regional sales managers and in-house sales associates.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P85_S1	Garmin s Europe, Middle East, Australia/New Zealand and Africa consumer product sales are handled through our in-country subsidiaries or local distributors who resell to dealers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P85_S2	Working closely with Garmin s in-house sales and marketing staff in the U.K. and U.S., these in-country subsidiaries or independent distributors are responsible for inventory levels and staff training requirements at each retail location.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P85_S3	Garmin s Taiwan-based marketing team handles the Company s Asia sales and marketing effort.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P86_S0	Some of Garmin s larger consumer products dealers and distributors include:
1121788_14_ITEM1_P87_S0	Wal-Mart the world s largest mass retailer.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P88_S0	Garmin s retrofit avionics and aviation portable products are sold through select aviation distributors around the world and, in the case of aviation portable products, also through catalogs and pilot shops.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P88_S1	Garmin s largest aviation distributors include Aircraft Spruce Specialty Co., Elliott Aviation, Gulf Coast Avionics Corp., Sarasota Avionics, and Sportsman s Market.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P88_S2	Avionics distributors have the training, equipment and certified staff required for at-airport installation of Garmin s avionics equipment.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P89_S0	In addition to the traditional distribution channels mentioned, Garmin has many relationships with original equipment manufacturers (OEMs).
1121788_14_ITEM1_P89_S1	In the automotive/mobile segment, Garmin s products are sold globally to automotive and motorcycle OEMs, either directly or through tier 2 sourcing.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P89_S2	Some of Garmin s larger OEM relationships include Chrysler, Suzuki, Volkswagen, Harley-Davidson, BMW Motorrad, Mercedes Benz, Bombardier, and Polaris.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P90_S0	In the marine segment, Garmin s products are standard equipment on various models of boats.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P90_S1	Some of the larger OEM relationships include Ranger Tugs, Cutwater Boats (a Division of Fluid Motion, LLC), Bayliner Boats (a division of Brunswick Corporation), Bavaria Yacht, Chaparral Boats, Inc., Andros Boats, Inc., Edgewater Boats, LLC, Bennington Marine, LLC, Cigarette Racing Team, LLC, Cobalt Boats, LLC, G3 Boats (a division of Yamaha Motor Corp.), Gulf Craft, Inc., Fairline Boats, Ltd., Inha Works Ltd. and Regal Marine Industries, Inc.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P91_S0	In the aviation market, Garmin s avionics are either standard equipment or options on various models of aircraft.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P91_S1	Some of the larger OEM relationships include AgustaWestland, Bombardier, Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc., Cessna Aircraft Company, Cirrus Aircraft, Embraer SA, Eurocopter, an EADS Company, Beechcraft Corporation, Pilatus Aircraft Ltd, Piper Aircraft, Inc., Quest Aircraft Company, and Robinson Helicopter Company.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P92_S0	In general, we operate in highly competitive markets though competitive conditions do vary among our diverse products and geographies.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P92_S1	Garmin believes the principal competitive factors impacting the market for its products are design, functionality, quality and reliability, customer service, brand, price, time-to-market and availability.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P92_S2	Garmin believes that it generally competes favorably in each of these areas and as such, is generally a significant competitor in each of our major markets.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S0	Garmin believes that its principal competitors for portable automotive products are TomTom N.V. and MiTAC Digital Corporation (MiTAC) (which distributes products under the brand names of Magellan, Mio, and Navman).
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S1	Garmin believes that its principal competitors for outdoor product lines are Bushnell, Delorme, Lowrance Electronics, Inc., a subsidiary of Navico ( Lowrance ) Magellan, a subsidiary of MiTAC, and Woodman Labs Inc. dba GoPro.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S2	For mobile products Garmin believes that its principal competitors are Google In., Apple Inc. and Telenav Inc.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S3	Garmin believes that its principal competitors for fitness products are Bryton Corp., Fitbit Inc., Nike, Inc., Polar Electro Oy, Sigma Sports, Suunto Oy and Timex Corp.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S4	For marine products, Garmin believes that its principal competitors are Furuno Electronic Company, the Humminbird division of Johnson Outdoors, Inc., Navico and Raymarine Inc.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P93_S5	For Garmin s aviation product lines, Garmin considers its principal competitors to be Aspen Avionics, Avidyne Corporation, Chelton Flight Systems, CMC Electronics, Free Flight Systems, Honeywell, Inc., L-3 Avionics Systems, Rockwell Collins, Inc., Sagem Avionics, Inc. and Universal Avionics Systems Corporation.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S0	Garmin s product innovations are driven by its strong emphasis on research and development and the close partnership between Garmin s engineering and manufacturing teams.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S1	Garmin s products are created by its engineering and development staff, which numbered 3,168 people worldwide as of December 28, 2013.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S2	Garmin s manufacturing staff includes manufacturing process engineers who work closely with Garmin s design engineers to ensure manufacturability and manufacturing cost control for its products.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S3	Garmin s development staff includes industrial designers, as well as software engineers, electrical engineers, mechanical engineers and cartographic engineers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S4	Garmin believes the industrial design of its products has played an important role in Garmin s success.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P94_S5	Once a development project is initiated and approved, a multi-disciplinary team is created to design the product and transition it into manufacturing.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P95_S0	Below is a table of Garmin s expenditures on research and development over the last three fiscal years.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P96_S0	Garmin believes that one of its core competencies and strengths is its manufacturing capability at its Sijhih, Jhongli and LinKou, Taiwan facilities, its Olathe, Kansas facility, and its Salem, Oregon facility.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P96_S1	Garmin believes that its vertically integrated approach has provided it the following benefits with respect to all products other than a few select marine products (VHF radios and AIS receivers) and our accessory products, which are manufactured by one or more third parties.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P97_S0	Utilizing concurrent engineering techniques, Garmin s products are introduced to production at an early development stage and the feedback provided by manufacturing is incorporated into the design before mass production begins.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P97_S1	In this manner, Garmin attempts to reduce the time required to move a product from its design phase to mass production deliveries.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P98_S0	Garmin uses its manufacturing resources to rapidly prototype design concepts, products and processes in order to achieve higher efficiency, improved quality and yields, lower cost and better value for customers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P98_S1	Garmin s ability to fully explore product design and manufacturing process concepts has enabled it to optimize its designs to minimize size and weight in GPS devices that are functional, waterproof, and rugged.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P99_S0	Operating our own manufacturing and distribution facilities helps Garmin minimize problems, such as component shortages and long component lead times which are common in the electronics industry.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P99_S1	Many products can be re-engineered to bypass component shortages or reduce cost and the new designs can be delivered to market quickly.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P100_S0	Garmin reacts rapidly to changes in market demand by striving to maintain a safety stock of long-lead components and by rescheduling components from one product line to another.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P100_S1	Operating our own manufacturing facilities also allows Garmin to quickly adjust the mix of product production, helping to foster faster delivery response to the customer.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P101_S0	Garmin s design, manufacturing, distribution, and servicing processes in our US, Taiwan, and UK facilities are certified to ISO 9001, an international quality standard developed by the International Organization for Standardization.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P101_S1	Garmin s automotive operations in Taiwan and Olathe have also achieved TS 16949 certification, a quality standard for automotive suppliers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P101_S2	In addition, Garmin s aviation operations have achieved certification to AS9100, the quality standard for the aviation industry.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P102_S0	Garmin International, Inc., Garmin (Europe) Ltd and Garmin Corporation have also achieved certification of their environmental management systems to the ISO14001 standard.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P102_S1	This certification recognizes that Garmin s subsidiaries have systems and processes in place to minimize or prevent harmful effects on the environment and to strive continually to improve its environmental performance.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P103_S0	Although most components essential to Garmin s business are generally available from multiple sources, certain key components, including, but not limited to, microprocessors, certain liquid crystal displays (LCDs), and certain application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs) are currently obtained by the Company from single or limited sources, which subjects Garmin to supply and pricing risks.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P103_S1	Many of these and other key components that are available from multiple sources, including, but not limited to, NAND flash memory, dynamic random access memory (DRAM), GPS chipsets and certain LCDs, are subject at times to industry-wide shortages and commodity pricing fluctuations.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P104_S0	Garmin and other participants in the personal computer, tablet, mobile communication, aviation electronics and consumer electronics industries also compete for various components with other industries that have experienced increased demand for their products.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P104_S1	In addition, Garmin uses some custom components that are not common to the rest of the personal computer, tablet, mobile communication and consumer electronics industries, and new products introduced by the Company often utilize custom components available from only one source until Garmin has evaluated whether there is a need for, and subsequently qualifies, additional suppliers.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P105_S0	When a component or product uses new technologies, initial capacity constraints may exist until the suppliers yields have matured or manufacturing capacity has increased.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P105_S1	Garmin makes efforts to manage risks in these areas through the use of supply agreements for strategically important components.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P105_S2	Nevertheless, if Garmin s supply of a key single-sourced component for a new or existing product was delayed or constrained, if such components were available only at significantly higher prices, or if a key manufacturing vendor delayed shipments of completed products to Garmin, Garmin s financial condition and operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P105_S3	Garmin s business and financial performance could also be adversely affected depending on the time required to obtain sufficient quantities from the original source, or to identify and obtain sufficient quantities from an alternative source.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P105_S4	Continued availability of these components at acceptable prices, or at all, may be affected if those suppliers decided to concentrate on the production of common components instead of components customized to meet Garmin s requirements.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P106_S0	Our sales are subject to seasonal fluctuation.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P106_S1	Sales of our consumer products are generally higher in the fourth quarter, due to increased demand during the holiday buying season, and, to a lesser extent, the second quarter, due to increased demand during the spring and summer season and the Father s Day/graduation buying season.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P107_S0	Sales of consumer products are also influenced by the timing of the release of new products.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P107_S1	Our aviation products do not experience much seasonal variation, but are more influenced by the timing of the release of new products when the initial demand is typically the strongest.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P108_S0	Our sales are generally of a consumer nature and there is a relatively short cycle between order and shipment.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P108_S1	Therefore, we believe that backlog information is not material to the understanding of our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P108_S2	We typically ship most orders within 72 hours of receipt.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P109_S0	Our success and ability to compete is dependent in part on our proprietary technology.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P109_S1	We rely on a combination of patent, copyright, trademark and trade secret laws, as well as confidentiality agreements, to establish and protect our proprietary rights.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P109_S2	In addition, Garmin often relies on licenses of intellectual property for use in its business.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P109_S3	For example, Garmin obtains licenses for digital cartography technology for use in our products from various sources.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P110_S0	As of February 1, 2014, Garmin s worldwide IP portfolio includes over 820 patent and 470 trademark registrations issued worldwide.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P110_S1	For the past seven years Garmin has been selected as a constituent of the Ocean Tomo 300 Patent Index which recognizes companies with high intellectual property value.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P110_S2	We believe that our continued success depends on the intellectual skills of our employees and their ability to continue to innovate.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P110_S3	Garmin will continue to file and prosecute patent applications when appropriate to attempt to protect Garmin s rights in its proprietary technologies.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P111_S0	There is no assurance that our current patents, or patents which we may later acquire, may successfully withstand any challenge, in whole or in part.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P111_S1	It is also possible that any patent issued to us may not provide us with any competitive advantages, or that the patents of others will preclude us from manufacturing and marketing certain products.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P112_S0	Despite our efforts to protect our proprietary rights, unauthorized parties may attempt to copy aspects of our products or to obtain and use information that we regard as proprietary.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P112_S1	Litigation may be necessary in the future to enforce our intellectual property rights, to protect our trade secrets, to determine the validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others or to defend against claims of infringement or invalidity.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P113_S0	The telecommunications industry is highly regulated, and the regulatory environment in which Garmin operates is subject to change.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P113_S1	In accordance with the United States Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rules and regulations, wireless transceiver products are required to be certified by the FCC and comparable authorities in foreign countries where they are sold.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P113_S2	Garmin s products sold in Europe are required to comply with relevant directives of the European Commission.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P113_S3	A delay in receiving required certifications for new products, or enhancements to Garmin s products, or losing certification for Garmin s existing products could adversely affect our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P113_S4	In addition, aviation products that are intended for installation in type certificated aircraft are required to be certified by the FAA, its European counterpart, the European Aviation Safety Agency, and other comparable organizations before they can be used in an aircraft.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P114_S0	Because Garmin Corporation, one of the Company s principal subsidiaries, is located in Taiwan, foreign exchange control laws and regulations of Taiwan with respect to remittances into and out of Taiwan may have an impact on Garmin s operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P114_S1	The Taiwan Foreign Exchange Control Statute, and regulations thereunder, provides that all foreign exchange transactions must be executed by banks designated to handle such business by the Ministry of Finance of Taiwan and by the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan), also referred to as the CBC.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P114_S2	Current regulations favor trade-related foreign exchange transactions.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P114_S3	Consequently, foreign currency earned from exports of merchandise and services may now be retained and used freely by exporters, while all foreign currency needed for the import of merchandise and services may be purchased freely from the designated foreign exchange banks.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P115_S0	Aside from trade-related foreign exchange transactions, Taiwan companies and residents may, without foreign exchange approval, remit outside and into Taiwan foreign currencies of up to $50 million and $5 million respectively, or their equivalent, each calendar year.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P115_S1	Currency conversions within the limits are processed by the designated banks and do not have to be reviewed and approved by the CBC.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P116_S0	The above limits apply to remittances involving a conversion between New Taiwan Dollars and U.S. Dollars or other foreign currencies.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P116_S1	The CBC typically approves foreign exchange in excess of the limits if a party applies with the CBC for review and presents legitimate business reasons justifying the currency conversion.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P116_S2	A requirement is also imposed on all enterprises to register all medium and long-term foreign debt with the CBC.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P117_S0	Garmin s operations are subject to various environmental laws, including laws addressing air and water pollution and management of hazardous substances and wastes.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P117_S1	Substantial noncompliance with applicable environmental laws could have a material adverse effect on our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P117_S2	Currently, we do not anticipate material capital expenditures for environmental control facilities.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P118_S0	Environmental regulation of Garmin s products is increasing.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P119_S0	Many of Garmin's products are subject to laws relating to the chemical and material composition of our products and their energy efficiency.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P119_S1	Garmin is also subject to laws requiring manufacturers to be financially responsible for collection, recovery and recycling of wastes from certain electronic products.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P119_S2	Compliance with current environmental laws does not have a material impact on our business, but the impact of future enactment of environmental laws cannot yet be fully determined and could be substantial.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P120_S0	Garmin has implemented multiple Environmental Management System (EMS) policies in accordance with the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 14001 standard for Environmental Health and Safety Management.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P120_S1	Garmin s EMS policies set forth practices, standards, and procedures to ensure compliance with applicable environmental laws and regulations at Garmin s Kansas headquarters facility, Garmin s European headquarters facility, and Garmin s Taiwan manufacturing facility.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P121_S0	Regulatory and Green Procurement demands from our customers are also increasing; particularly in the areas of restricted substance use and environmentally-friendly design and manufacture initiatives.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P121_S1	The overall impacts of these customer requirements cannot yet be established.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P122_S0	Garmin is committed to improving our products and processes to meet our customer needs.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P123_S0	As of December 28, 2013, Garmin had 10,086 full and part-time employees worldwide, of whom 3,804 were in the United States, 75 were in Canada, 4,687 were in Taiwan, 1,117 were in Europe, and 403 were in other global locations.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P123_S1	Except for some of Garmin s employees in Brazil and Sweden, none of Garmin s employees are represented by a labor union and none of Garmin's North American or Taiwan employees are covered by a collective bargaining agreement.
1121788_14_ITEM1_P124_S0	Garmin considers its employee relations to be good.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The risks described below are not the only ones facing our company.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently believe to be immaterial may also impair our business operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P0_S2	If any of the following risks occur, our business, financial condition or operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The demand for personal navigation devices (PNDs) has been and continues to be reduced by replacement technologies becoming available on mobile devices and factory-installed systems in new autos.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P2_S0	From 2005 to 2008, we experienced substantial growth in the automotive/mobile segment.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P2_S1	This has resulted in GPS/navigation technologies being incorporated into competing devices such as mobile handsets, tablets, and new automobiles through factory-installed systems.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Mobile handsets and tablets are frequently GPS-enabled and many companies are now offering navigation software for these mobile devices.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P2_S3	The acceptance of this technology by consumers has halted our growth in this segment and reduced margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Navigation systems are also becoming more prevalent as optional equipment on new automobiles.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Increased navigation penetration on mobile handsets and in new automobiles is expected to cause further declines in sales of our portable navigation devices and could further reduced margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Our financial results are dependent on the automotive/mobile segment, which represents approximately 50% of our revenues, is maturing and expected to further decline in 2014.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We experienced substantial growth through 2008 in the automotive/mobile segment of our business as the products became mass-market consumer electronics in both Europe and North America.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P5_S1	This market has peaked as penetration rates increased and competing technologies emerged.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P5_S2	This has resulted in, and could continue to result in, lower revenues for this segment and lower earnings per share.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Economic conditions and uncertainty could adversely affect our revenue and margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Our revenue and margins depend significantly on general economic conditions and the demand for products in the markets in which we compete.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Economic weakness or constrained consumer and business spending has resulted in decreased revenue and in the future, could result in decreased revenue and problems with our ability to manage inventory levels and collect customer receivables.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P7_S2	In addition, financial difficulties experienced by our retailer and OEM customers have resulted, and could result in the future, in significant bad debt write-offs and additions to reserves in our receivables and could have an adverse affect on our results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Gross margins for our products may fluctuate or erode.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Gross margins in some of our segments have declined in recent years and could further decline in the future due to competitive price reductions that are not fully offset by material cost reductions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S1	In addition, our overall gross margin may fluctuate from period to period due to a number of factors, including product mix, competition and unit volumes.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S2	In particular, the average selling prices of a specific product tend to decrease over that product s life.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S3	To offset such decreases, we intend to rely primarily on component cost reduction, obtaining yield improvements and corresponding cost reductions in the manufacturing of existing products and on introducing new products that incorporate advanced features and therefore can be sold at higher average selling prices.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S4	However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain any such yield improvements or cost reductions or introduce any such new products in the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P9_S5	To the extent that such cost reductions and new product introductions do not occur in a timely manner or our products do not achieve market acceptance, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Changes in our United States federal income tax classification or in applicable tax laws could result in adverse tax consequences to our shareholders.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We do not believe that we, or any of our United States or non-United States subsidiaries, are currently a passive foreign investment company for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P11_S1	We do not expect to become a passive foreign investment company.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P11_S2	However, because the passive foreign investment company determination is made annually based on whether the company s income or assets meet certain thresholds as determined under United States federal tax principles which are based on facts and circumstances that may be beyond our control, we cannot assure that we will not become a passive foreign investment company in the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P11_S3	If we are a passive foreign investment company in any year, then any of our shareholders that is a United States person could be liable to pay tax on their pro rata share of our income plus an interest charge upon some distributions by us or when that shareholder sells our common shares at a gain.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Further, if we are classified as a passive foreign investment company in any year in which a United States person is a shareholder, we generally will continue to be treated as a passive foreign investment company with respect to such shareholder in all succeeding years, regardless of whether we continue to satisfy the income or asset tests mentioned above.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P12_S0	We do not believe that we, or any of our United States or non-United States subsidiaries, are currently a Controlled Foreign Corporation (CFC) for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We do not expect to become a CFC.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P13_S0	The CFC determination is made daily based on whether the United States shareholders own more than fifty percent of the voting power or value of the Company.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P13_S1	Only United States persons that own ten percent or more of the voting power of the Company s shares qualify as United States shareholders.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P13_S2	If the Company were to be classified as a CFC for an uninterrupted thirty day period in any year, the Company s shareholders that qualify as United States shareholders could be liable to pay US income tax at ordinary income tax rates on their pro-rata share of certain categories of the Company s income for the period in which the Company is classified as a CFC.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P13_S3	As the Company cannot control the ownership of the Company s stock nor can the Company control which shareholders participate in the Company s stock buyback program, ownership changes could result that create United States shareholders which increase the risk of Garmin being treated as a CFC.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Legislative proposals have been considered in the United States within the past few years that could increase the United States tax burden of corporations with international operations and could broaden the circumstances under which foreign corporations could be considered resident in the United States.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Legislative proposals are being considered in Switzerland that could make significant changes in the corporate tax regime and increase the taxes applicable to us in Switzerland.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Our tax position could be adversely impacted by changes in Swiss, United States or foreign tax laws, tax treaties or tax regulations or the interpretation or enforcement thereof by any tax authority.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P15_S1	We cannot predict the outcome of any specific legislative proposals.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P16_S0	If we are not successful in the continued development, introduction or timely manufacture of new products, demand for our products could decrease.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We expect that a significant portion of our future revenue will continue to be derived from sales of newly introduced products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P17_S1	The market for our products is characterized by rapidly changing technology, evolving industry standards and changes in customer needs.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P17_S2	If we fail to introduce new products, or to modify or improve our existing products, in response to changes in technology, industry standards or customer needs, our products could rapidly become less competitive or obsolete.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P17_S3	We must continue to make significant investments in research and development in order to continue to develop new products, enhance existing products and achieve market acceptance for such products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P17_S4	However, there can be no assurance that development stage products will be successfully completed or, if developed, will achieve significant customer acceptance.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S0	If we are unable to successfully develop and introduce competitive new products, and enhance our existing products, our future results of operations would be adversely affected.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S1	Our pursuit of necessary technology may require substantial time and expense.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S2	We may need to license new technologies to respond to technological change.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S3	These licenses may not be available to us on terms that we can accept or may materially change the gross profits that we are able to obtain on our products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S4	We may not succeed in adapting our products to new technologies as they emerge.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Development and manufacturing schedules for technology products are difficult to predict, and there can be no assurance that we will achieve timely initial customer shipments of new products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S6	The timely availability of these products in volume and their acceptance by customers are important to our future success.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P18_S7	From time to time we have experienced delays in shipping certain of our new products and any future delays, whether due to product development delays, manufacturing delays, lack of market acceptance, delays in regulatory approval, or otherwise, could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P19_S0	If we are unable to compete effectively with existing or new competitors, our resulting loss of competitive position could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S0	The markets for many of our products are highly competitive, and we expect competition to increase in the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Some of our competitors have significantly greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S2	These competitors may be able to respond more rapidly to new or emerging technologies or changes in customer requirements.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S3	They may also be able to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S4	Increased competition could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P20_S5	Our failure to compete successfully against current or future competitors could seriously harm our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We rely on independent dealers and distributors to sell our products, and disruption to these channels would harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Because we sell a majority of our products to independent dealers and distributors, we are subject to many risks, including risks related to their inventory levels and support for our products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P22_S1	In particular, our dealers and distributors maintain significant levels of our products in their inventories.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P22_S2	If dealers and distributors attempt to reduce their levels of inventory or if they do not maintain sufficient levels to meet customer demand, our sales could be negatively impacted.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Many of our dealers and distributors also sell products offered by our competitors.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P23_S1	If our competitors offer our dealers and distributors more favorable terms, those dealers and distributors may de-emphasize or decline to carry our products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P23_S2	In the future, we may not be able to retain or attract a sufficient number of qualified dealers and distributors.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P23_S3	If we are unable to maintain successful relationships with dealers and distributors or to expand our distribution channels, our business will suffer.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Our quarterly operating results are subject to fluctuations and seasonality.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Our operating results are difficult to predict.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Our future quarterly operating results may fluctuate significantly.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P25_S2	If such operating results decline, the price of our stock would likely decline.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P25_S3	As we have expanded our operations, our operating expenses, particularly our research and development costs, have increased as a percentage of our sales.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P25_S4	If revenues decrease and we continue to increase research and development costs, our operating results would be negatively affected.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Historically, our revenues have been weaker in the first quarter of each fiscal year as our devices are highly consumer-oriented, and consumer buying is traditionally lower in this quarter.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P26_S1	Sales of certain of our marine and automotive products tend to be higher in our second fiscal quarter due to increased consumer spending for such products during the recreational marine, fishing, and travel season.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Sales of many of our consumer products also have been higher in our fourth fiscal quarter due to increased consumer spending patterns on electronic devices during the holiday season.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P26_S3	In addition, we attempt to time our new product releases to coincide with relatively higher consumer spending in the second and fourth fiscal quarters, which contributes to these seasonal variations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our quarterly financial statements will reflect fluctuations in foreign currency translation.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The operation of Garmin s subsidiaries in international markets results in exposure to movements in currency exchange rates.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P29_S0	We have experienced significant foreign currency gains and losses due to the strengthening and weakening of the U.S. dollar.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P29_S1	The potential of volatile foreign exchange rate fluctuations in the future could have a significant effect on our results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P30_S0	The currencies that create a majority of the Company s exchange rate exposure are the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Garmin Corporation, headquartered in Sijhih, Taiwan, uses the local currency as the functional currency.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P31_S1	The Company translates all assets and liabilities at year-end exchange rates and income and expense accounts at average rates during the year.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P32_S0	In order to minimize the effect of the currency exchange fluctuations on our net assets, we have elected to retain most of our Taiwan subsidiary s cash and investments in marketable securities denominated in U.S. dollars.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Nonetheless, U.S. GAAP requires the Company at the end of each accounting period to translate into Taiwan Dollars all such U.S. Dollar denominated assets held by our Taiwan subsidiary.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P33_S1	This translation is required because the Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of the subsidiary.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P33_S2	This U.S. GAAP-mandated translation will cause us to recognize gain or loss on our financial statements as the Taiwan Dollar/U.S. Dollar exchange rate varies.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P33_S3	Such gain or loss will create variations in our earnings per share.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P33_S4	Because there is minimal cash impact caused by such exchange rate variations, management will continue to focus on the Company s operating performance before the impact of the foreign currency translation.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P34_S0	If we do not correctly anticipate demand for our products, we may not be able to secure sufficient quantities or cost-effective production of our products or we could have costly excess production or inventories.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We have generally been able to increase production to meet this increasing demand.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P35_S1	However, the demand for our products depends on many factors and will be difficult to forecast.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P35_S2	We expect that it will become more difficult to forecast demand as we introduce and support multiple products, as competition in the market for our products intensifies and as the markets for some of our products mature to the mass market category.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P35_S3	Significant unanticipated fluctuations in demand could cause the following problems in our operations:
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P36_S0	If demand increases beyond what we forecast, we would have to rapidly increase production.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P36_S1	We would depend on suppliers to provide additional volumes of components and those suppliers might not be able to increase production rapidly enough to meet unexpected demand.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P37_S0	Rapid increases in production levels to meet unanticipated demand could result in higher costs for manufacturing and supply of components and other expenses.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P37_S1	These higher costs could lower our profit margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P37_S2	Further, if production is increased rapidly, manufacturing quality could decline, which may also lower our margins and reduce customer satisfaction.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P38_S0	If forecasted demand does not develop, we could have excess production resulting in higher inventories of finished products and components, which would use cash and could lead to write-offs of some or all of the excess inventories.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P38_S1	Lower than forecasted demand could also result in excess manufacturing capacity or reduced manufacturing efficiencies at our facilities, which could result in lower margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P39_S0	We have benefited in the past from Taiwan government tax incentives offered on certain high technology capital investments that may not always be available.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Our effective tax rate is lower than the U.S. federal statutory rate, in part because we have benefited from incentives offered in Taiwan related to our high technology investments in Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P40_S1	The loss of these tax benefits has begun to have a negative impact on our effective tax rate and reduced benefits will continue into the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We may experience unique economic and political risks associated with companies that operate in Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Relations between Taiwan and the People s Republic of China, also referred to as the PRC, and other factors affecting the political or economic conditions of Taiwan in the future could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations and the market price and the liquidity of our shares.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P42_S1	Our principal manufacturing facilities where we manufacture all of our products, except our panel-mounted aviation products, are located in Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P43_S0	Taiwan has a unique international political status.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P43_S1	The PRC asserts sovereignty over all of China, including Taiwan, certain other islands and all of mainland China.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P43_S2	The PRC government does not recognize the legitimacy of the Taiwan government.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P43_S3	Although significant economic and cultural relations have been established during recent years between Taiwan and the PRC, the PRC government has indicated that it may use military force to gain control over Taiwan in certain circumstances, such as the declaration of independence by Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P43_S4	Relations between Taiwan and the PRC have on occasion adversely affected the market value of Taiwanese companies and could negatively affect our operations in Taiwan in the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P44_S0	Our intellectual property rights are important to our operations, and we could suffer loss if they infringe upon other s rights or are infringed upon by others.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We rely on a combination of patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets, confidentiality provisions and licensing arrangements to establish and protect our proprietary rights.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P45_S1	To this end, we hold rights to a number of patents and registered trademarks and regularly file applications to attempt to protect our rights in new technology and trademarks.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P45_S2	However, there is no guarantee that our patent applications will become issued patents, or that our trademark applications will become registered trademarks.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P45_S3	Moreover, even if approved, our patents or trademarks may thereafter be successfully challenged by others or otherwise become invalidated for a variety of reasons.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P45_S4	Thus, any patents or trademarks we currently have or may later acquire may not provide us a significant competitive advantage.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P46_S0	Third parties may claim that we are infringing their intellectual property rights.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Such claims could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P47_S0	From time to time we receive letters alleging infringement of patents, trademarks or other intellectual property rights.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P47_S1	Litigation concerning patents or other intellectual property is costly and time consuming.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P47_S2	We may seek licenses from such parties, but they could refuse to grant us a license or demand commercially unreasonable terms.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P47_S3	We might not have sufficient resources to pay for the licenses.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P47_S4	Such infringement claims could also cause us to incur substantial liabilities and to suspend or permanently cease the use of critical technologies or processes or the production or sale of major products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P48_S0	We may become subject to significant product liability costs.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P49_S0	If our aviation products malfunction or contain errors or defects, airplane collisions or crashes could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P49_S1	Malfunctions or errors or defects in our marine navigational products could cause boats to run aground or cause other wreckage, personal injury or death.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P49_S2	If our automotive or marine products contain defects or errors in the mapping supplied by third-party map providers or if our users do not heed our warnings about the proper use of these products, collisions or accidents could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P49_S3	If any of these events occurs, we could be subject to significant liability for personal injury and property damage and, under certain circumstances, could be subject to a judgment for punitive damages.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We maintain insurance against accident-related risks involving our products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P50_S1	However, there can be no assurance that such insurance would be sufficient to cover the cost of damages to others or that such insurance will continue to be available at commercially reasonable rates.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P50_S2	In addition, insurance coverage generally will not cover awards of punitive damages and may not cover the cost of associated legal fees and defense costs, which could result in lower margins.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P50_S3	If we are unable to maintain sufficient insurance to cover product liability costs or if our insurance coverage does not cover the award, this could have a materially adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P51_S0	We depend on our suppliers, some of which are the sole source for specific components, and our production would be seriously harmed if these suppliers are not able to meet our demand and alternative sources are not available, or if the costs of components rise.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S0	We are dependent on third party suppliers for various components used in our current products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Some of the components that we procure from third party suppliers include semiconductors and electroluminescent panels, liquid crystal displays, memory chips, batteries and microprocessors.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S2	The cost, quality and availability of components are essential to the successful production and sale of our products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S3	Some components we use are from sole source suppliers.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S4	Certain application-specific integrated circuits incorporating our proprietary designs are manufactured for us by sole source suppliers.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P52_S5	Alternative sources may not be currently available for these sole source components.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P53_S0	In the past we have experienced shortages of liquid crystal displays and other components.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P53_S1	In addition, if there are shortages in supply of components, the costs of such components may rise.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P53_S2	If suppliers are unable to meet our demand for components on a timely basis and if we are unable to obtain an alternative source or if the price of the alternative source is prohibitive, or if the costs of components rise, our ability to maintain timely and cost-effective production of our products would be seriously harmed.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P54_S0	We depend on third party licensors for the digital map data contained in our automotive/mobile products, and our business and/or gross margins could be harmed if we become unable to continue licensing such mapping data or if the royalty costs for such data rise.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P55_S0	We license digital mapping data for use in our products from various sources.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P55_S1	There are only a limited number of suppliers of mapping data for each geographical region.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P55_S2	and Tele Atlas N.V. HERE is owned by Nokia Oyj and Tele Atlas N.V. is owned by TomTom N.V. Nokia and TomTom are both competitors of Garmin.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P56_S0	Although we do not foresee difficulty in continuing to license data at favorable pricing due to the long term license extension signed between Garmin and HERE in June 2010 (extending our HERE license agreement through 2017 with an option to extend through 2021), if we are unable to continue licensing such mapping data and are unable to obtain an alternative source, or if the nature of our relationships with HERE changes detrimentally, our ability to supply mapping data for use in our products would be seriously harmed.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P57_S0	We may pursue strategic acquisitions, investments, strategic partnerships or other ventures, and our business could be materially harmed if we fail to successfully identify, complete and integrate such transactions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P58_S0	We intend to evaluate acquisition opportunities and opportunities to make investments in complementary businesses, technologies, services or products, or to enter into strategic partnerships with parties who can provide access to those assets, additional product or services offerings, additional distribution or marketing synergies or additional industry expertise.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P58_S1	We may not be able to identify suitable acquisition, investment or strategic partnership candidates, or if we do identify suitable candidates in the future, we may not be able to complete those transactions on commercially favorable terms, or at all.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P59_S0	Any past or future acquisitions could also result in difficulties assimilating acquired employees (including cultural differences with foreign acquisitions), operations, and products and diversion of capital and management s attention away from other business issues and opportunities.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P59_S1	Integration of acquired companies may result in problems related to integration of technology and inexperienced management teams.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P59_S2	In addition, the key personnel of the acquired company may decide not to work for us.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P59_S3	We may not successfully integrate internal controls, compliance under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other corporate governance matters, operations, personnel or products related to acquisitions we have made in previous years or may make in the future.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P59_S4	If we fail to successfully integrate such transactions, our business could be materially harmed.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P60_S0	We may have additional tax liabilities.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S0	We are subject to income taxes in Switzerland, the United States and numerous foreign jurisdictions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S1	Significant judgment is required in determining our worldwide provision for income taxes.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S2	In the ordinary course of our business, there are many transactions and calculations where the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S3	We are regularly under audit by tax authorities.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S4	Although we believe our tax estimates are reasonable, the final determination of tax audits and any related litigation could be materially different from our historical income tax provisions and accruals.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P61_S5	The results of an audit or litigation could have a material effect on our income tax provision, net income or cash flows in the period or periods for which that determination is made.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P62_S0	Failure to obtain required certifications of our products on a timely basis could harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S0	We have certain products, especially in our aviation segment, that are subject to governmental and similar certifications before they can be sold.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S1	For example, FAA certification is required for all of our aviation products that are intended for installation in type certificated aircraft.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S2	To the extent required, certification is an expensive and time-consuming process that requires significant focus and resources.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S3	An inability to obtain, or excessive delay in obtaining, such certifications could have an adverse effect on our ability to introduce new products and, for certain aviation OEM products, our customers ability to sell airplanes.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S4	Delays in our obtaining certification for our aviation products have resulted, and may in the future result, in our being required to pay compensation to our customers.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S5	Therefore, such inabilities or delays could adversely affect our operating results.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S6	In addition, we cannot assure you that our certified products will not be decertified.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P63_S7	Any such decertification could have an adverse effect on our operating results.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P64_S0	Our business may suffer if we are not able to hire and retain sufficient qualified personnel or if we lose our key personnel.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S0	Our future success depends partly on the continued contribution of our key executive, engineering, sales, marketing, manufacturing and administrative personnel.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S1	We currently do not have employment agreements with any of our key executive officers.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S2	Swiss law prohibits us from paying severance payments to our senior executive officers, which may impair our ability to recruit for these positions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S3	We do not have key man life insurance on any of our key executive officers and do not currently intend to obtain such insurance.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S4	The loss of the services of any of our senior level management, or other key employees, could harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S5	Recruiting and retaining the skilled personnel we require to maintain and grow our market position may be difficult.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S6	For example, in some recent years there has been a nationwide shortage of qualified electrical engineers and software engineers who are necessary for us to design and develop new products, and therefore, it has sometimes been challenging to recruit such personnel.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P65_S7	If we fail to hire and retain qualified employees, we may not be able to maintain and expand our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P66_S0	There is uncertainty as to our shareholders ability to enforce certain foreign civil liabilities in Switzerland and Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P67_S0	We are a Swiss company and a substantial portion of our assets are located outside the United States, particularly in Taiwan.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P67_S1	As a result, it may be difficult to effect service of process within the United States upon us.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P67_S2	In addition, there is uncertainty as to whether the courts of Switzerland or Taiwan would recognize or enforce judgments of United States courts obtained against us predicated upon the civil liability provisions of the securities laws of the United States or any state thereof, or be competent to hear original actions brought in Switzerland or Taiwan against us predicated upon the securities laws of the United States or any state thereof.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P68_S0	A shut down of U.S. airspace or imposition of restrictions on general aviation would harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P69_S0	Following the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, the FAA ordered all aircraft operating in the U.S. to be grounded for several days.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P69_S1	In addition to this shut down of U.S. airspace, the general aviation industry was further impacted by the additional restrictions implemented by the FAA on those flights that fly utilizing Visual Flight Rules (VFR).
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P69_S2	The FAA restricted VFR flight inside 30 enhanced Class B (a 20-25 mile radius around the 30 largest metropolitan areas in the USA) airspace areas.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P69_S3	The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association (AOPA) estimated that these restrictions affected approximately 41,800 general aviation aircraft based at 282 airports inside the 30 enhanced Class B airspace areas.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P69_S4	The AOPA estimates that approximately 90% of all general aviation flights are conducted VFR, and that only 15% of general aviation pilots are current to fly utilizing Instrument Flight Rules (IFR).
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P70_S0	The shutdown of U.S. airspace following September 11, 2001 caused reduced sales of our general aviation products and delays in the shipment of our products manufactured in our Taiwan manufacturing facility to our distribution facility in Olathe, Kansas, thereby adversely affecting our ability to supply new and existing products to our dealers and distributors.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P71_S0	Any future shut down of U.S. airspace or imposition of restrictions on general aviation could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial results.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P72_S0	A shut down of Federal Aviation Administration operations would harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P73_S0	Any failure of Congress to appropriate funds for FAA operations that results in any shut down of FAA operations or furloughing of FAA employees could result in delays in the required FAA certification of our avionics products and in the production, sale and registration of aircraft that use our avionics products.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P73_S1	Such delays could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial results.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P74_S0	Many of our products rely on the Global Positioning System.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P75_S0	The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a satellite-based navigation and positioning system consisting of a constellation of orbiting satellites.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P75_S1	The satellites and their ground control and monitoring stations are maintained and operated by the United States Department of Defense.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P75_S2	The Department of Defense does not currently charge users for access to the satellite signals.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P76_S0	These satellites and their ground support systems are complex electronic systems subject to electronic and mechanical failures and possible sabotage.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P76_S1	The satellites were originally designed to have lives of 7.5 years and are subject to damage by the hostile space environment in which they operate.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P76_S2	However, of the current deployment of satellites in place, some have been operating for more than 12 years.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P77_S0	To repair damaged or malfunctioning satellites is currently not economically feasible.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P77_S1	If a significant number of satellites were to become inoperable, there could be a substantial delay before they are replaced with new satellites.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P77_S2	A reduction in the number of operating satellites may impair the current utility of the GPS system and the growth of current and additional market opportunities.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P78_S0	GPS satellites and ground control segments are being modernized.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P78_S1	GPS modernization software updates can cause problems.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P78_S2	We depend on public access to open technical specifications in advance of GPS updates.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P79_S0	GPS is operated by the U. S. Government, which is committed to maintenance and improvement of GPS; however if the policy were to change, and GPS were no longer supported by the U. S. Government, or if user fees were imposed, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, and financial condition.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P80_S0	Some of our products also use signals from Satellite Based Augmentation Systems (SBAS) that augment GPS, such as the U.S. Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS), Japanese MTSAT-based Satellite Augmentation System (MSAS), and European Geostationary Navigation Overlay Service (EGNOS).
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P80_S1	Any curtailment of SBAS operating capability could result in decreased user capability for many of our aviation products, thereby impacting our markets.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P81_S0	Any of the foregoing factors could affect the willingness of buyers of our products to select Global Positioning System-based products instead of products based on competing technologies.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P82_S0	Any reallocation or repurposing of radio frequency spectrum could cause harmful interference with the reception of Global Positioning System signals.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P82_S1	This interference could harm our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P83_S0	Our Global Positioning System technology is dependent on the use of the Standard Positioning Service (SPS) provided by the U.S. Government s Global Positioning System satellites.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P83_S1	The Global Positioning System operates in radio frequency bands that are globally allocated for radio navigation satellite services.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P84_S0	International allocations of radio frequency are made by the International Telecommunications Union (ITU), a specialized technical agency of the United Nations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P84_S1	These allocations are further governed by radio regulations that have treaty status and which may be subject to modification every two to three years by the World Radio Communication Conference.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P84_S2	Each country also has regulatory authority on how each band is used.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P85_S0	In the United States, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) share responsibility for radio frequency allocations and spectrum usage regulations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P86_S0	Any ITU or national reallocation of radio frequency spectrum, including frequency band segmentation or sharing of spectrum, or other modifications of the permitted uses of relevant frequency bands, may materially and adversely affect the utility and reliability of our products and have significant negative impacts on our business and our customers.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P86_S1	For example, the FCC has been considering a proposal by a private party, LightSquared, to repurpose spectrum adjacent to the GPS bands for terrestrial broadband wireless operations in metropolitan areas throughout the United States.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P86_S2	If the FCC were to permit implementation of LightSquared s proposal, terrestrial broadband wireless operations could create harmful interference to GPS receivers within range of such operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P87_S0	Our business is subject to disruptions and uncertainties caused by war or terrorism.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P88_S0	Acts of war or acts of terrorism, especially any directed at the GPS signals, could have a material adverse impact on our business, operating results, and financial condition.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P88_S1	The threat of terrorism and war and heightened security and military response to this threat, or any future acts of terrorism, may cause a redeployment of the satellites used in GPS or interruptions of the system.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P88_S2	To the extent that such interruptions have an effect on sales of our products, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, and financial condition.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P89_S0	Privacy concerns relating to our technology could damage our reputation and deter current and potential users from using our products and applications.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P90_S0	Concerns about our practices with regard to the collection, use, disclosure, or security of personal information, user location information or other privacy related matters, even if unfounded, could damage our reputation and operating results.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P90_S1	While we strive to comply with all applicable data protection laws and regulations, as well as our own posted privacy policies, any failure or perceived failure to comply may result in proceedings or actions against us by government entities or others, or could cause us to lose users and customers, which could potentially have an adverse effect on our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P91_S0	Regulatory authorities around the world are considering a number of legislative and regulatory proposals concerning data protection.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P91_S1	In addition, the interpretation and application of consumer and data protection laws in the U.S., Europe and elsewhere are often uncertain and in flux.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P91_S2	It is possible that these laws may be interpreted and applied in a manner that is inconsistent with our data practices.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P91_S3	If so, in addition to the possibility of fines, this could result in an order requiring that we change our data practices, which could have an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P91_S4	Complying with these various laws could cause us to incur substantial costs or require us to change our business practices in a manner adverse to our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P92_S0	Security breaches and other disruptions, including as a result of cyber attacks, could compromise our information and expose us to liability, which would cause our business and reputation to suffer.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P93_S0	In the ordinary course of our business, we collect and store sensitive data, including intellectual property, our proprietary business information and that of our customers and suppliers, and some personally identifiable information of our customers and employees, in our facilities and on our networks.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P93_S1	The secure processing, maintenance and transmission of this information is important to our operations.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P93_S2	Despite our security measures, our information technology and infrastructure may be vulnerable to attacks by hackers or breached due to employee error or other disruptions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P93_S3	Any such breach could compromise our networks and the information stored there could be accessed, publicly disclosed, lost or stolen.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P93_S4	Any such access, disclosure or other loss of information could result in legal claims or proceedings, disrupt our operations, damage our reputation, and cause a loss of confidence, which could adversely affect our business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P94_S0	We may be exposed to certain regulatory and financial risks related to climate change.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P95_S0	Climate change is receiving increasing attention worldwide.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P95_S1	Some scientists, legislators and others attribute global warming to increased levels of greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, which has led to significant legislative and regulatory efforts to limit greenhouse gas emissions.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P96_S0	Various regulatory and legislative measures to address greenhouse gas emissions are in different phases of implementation or discussion.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P97_S0	In the aftermath of its 2009 endangerment finding that greenhouse gas emissions pose a threat to human health and welfare, the Environmental Protection Agency has begun to regulate greenhouse gas emissions under the authority granted to it under the Clean Air Act.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P97_S1	At the federal legislative level, Congressional passage of legislation adopting some form of federal mandatory greenhouse gas emission reduction, such as a nationwide cap-and-trade program, does not appear likely at this time, although it could be adopted at a future date.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P97_S2	It is also possible that Congress may pass alternative climate change bills that do not mandate a nationwide cap-and-trade program and instead focus on promoting renewable energy and energy efficiency, which could increase the cost of doing business.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P98_S0	Because it is uncertain what laws and regulations will be enacted, we cannot predict the potential impact of such laws and regulations on our future consolidated financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P99_S0	The volatility of our stock price could adversely affect investment in our common shares.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P100_S0	The market price of our common shares has been, and may continue to be, highly volatile.
1121788_14_ITEM1A_P100_S1	During 2013, the closing price of our common shares ranged from a low of $32.60 to a high of $49.33.
