1121788_15_ITEM3_P17_S0	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that each asserted claim of the 952 patent, the 825 patent, and the 974 patent is invalid and/or not infringed and, in addition, that the 952, 825, and 974 patents are unenforceable under the doctrine of inequitable conduct and that Johnson Outdoors claims are barred in whole or in part by the doctrines of prosecution history estoppel and/or prosecution disclaimer.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P17_S1	The ITC Administrative Law Judge has scheduled a trial hearing commencing on April 3, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P17_S2	Garmin intends to vigorously defend the complaint.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P18_S0	On June 9, 2014 Navico Inc. and Navico Holding AS filed a complaint with the United States International Trade Commission ( ITC ) against Garmin International, Inc., Garmin North America, Inc., Garmin USA, Inc. and Garmin (Asia) Corporation (collectively Garmin ) alleging a violation of Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930, as amended, through alleged infringement by Garmin of U.S. Patents 8,300,499 ( the 499 patent ); 8,305,840 ( the 840 patent ); and 8,605,550 ( the 550 patent ).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P18_S1	On July 9, 2014 the ITC instituted an investigation pursuant to the complaint.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P19_S0	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that each asserted claim of the 499 patent, the 840 patent, and the 550 patent is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P19_S1	The ITC Administrative Law Judge has scheduled a trial hearing commencing on March 18, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P19_S2	Garmin intends to vigorously defend the complaint .
1121788_15_ITEM3_P20_S0	Johnson Outdoors Inc. and Johnson Outdoors Marine Electronics, Inc. v. Garmin International, Inc., Garmin North America, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S0	On July 17, 2014, Johnson Outdoors Inc and Johnson Outdoors Marine Electronics Inc. filed suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama, Northern Division, against Garmin International, Inc., Garmin North America, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc. (collectively, Garmin ) alleging infringement of U.S. Patents 7,652,952 ( the 952 patent ); 7,710,825 ( the 825 patent ); and 7,755,974 ( the 974 patent ).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S1	On August 15, 2014, Garmin filed an answer.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S2	On October 17, 2014, Garmin filed an amended answer.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S3	In its amended answer Garmin asserts that each asserted claim of the 952 patent, the 825 patent and the 974 patent is invalid and/or not infringed and, in addition, that the 952, 825, and 974 patents are unenforceable under the doctrine of inequitable conduct, and that Johnson Outdoors claims are barred in whole or in part by the doctrines of prosecution history estoppel and/or prosecution disclaimer and Garmin seeks treble damages against Johnson Outdoors for antitrust violations under Section 2 of the Sherman Act, 15 U.S.C. 2.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S4	Garmin intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P21_S5	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P22_S0	Andrea Katz, on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated, v. Garmin Ltd. and Garmin International, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S0	On December 18, 2013, a purported class action lawsuit was filed against Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin Ltd. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S1	The lead plaintiff was Andrea Katz, on behalf of herself and all others similarly situated.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S2	The class of plaintiffs that Andrea Katz purported to represent includes all individuals who purchased any model of Forerunner watch in the State of Illinois and the United States.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S3	Plaintiff asserted claims for breach of contract, breach of express warranty, breach of implied warranties, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Illinois statutory law.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S4	Plaintiff alleged that Forerunner watch bands have an unacceptable rate of failure in that they detach from the watch.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S5	Plaintiff sought compensatory and punitive damages, prejudgment interest, costs, and attorneys fees, and injunctive relief.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S6	On January 29, 2014 the court dismissed the lawsuit without prejudice.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S7	On January 30, 2014, the plaintiff re-filed the lawsuit with the same claims for relief as the earlier action and adding an additional claim for unjust enrichment.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S8	On February 4, 2014, the court ordered the case to be transferred to the United States District Court for the District of Utah.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S9	The plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case filed in Illinois and, on March 6, 2014, she refiled the lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Utah with the same claims, but with additional claims for violations of the Utah Consumers Sales Practice Act, Lanham Act, and Utah Truth in Advertising Act.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P23_S10	The relief she requested is the same.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S0	On March 31, 2014, Garmin filed a motion to transfer the venue of the Utah action back to the Northern District of Illinois.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S1	On October 21, 2014, the United States District Court for the District of Utah denied Garmin s motion to transfer venue.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S2	On December 26, 2014, Garmin filed a motion to dismiss certain counts of the complaint.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S3	The court has scheduled a hearing on this motion on April 16, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S4	No class has been certified at this time.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P24_S5	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P25_S0	Brian Meyers, on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated, v. Garmin International, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P25_S1	Garmin USA, Inc. and Garmin Ltd.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S0	On August 13, 2013, Brian Meyers filed a putative class action complaint against Garmin International, Inc., Garmin USA, Inc. and Garmin Ltd. in the United States District Court for the District of Kansas.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S1	Meyers alleges that lithium-ion batteries in certain Garmin products are defective and alleges violations of the Kansas Consumer Protection Act, breach of an implied warranty of merchantability, breach of contract, unjust enrichment, breach of express warranty and also requests declaratory relief that the batteries are defective and must be covered by Garmin s warranties.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S2	The complaint seeks an order for class certification, a declaration that the batteries are defective, an order of injunctive relief, payment of damages in an unspecified amount on behalf of a putative class of all purchasers of certain Garmin products, and an award of attorneys fees.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S3	On September 18, 2013 the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed Garmin Ltd. as a defendant without prejudice.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S4	On October 18, 2013 the plaintiff filed an amended class action complaint.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S5	On November 1, 2013 the remaining Garmin defendants filed a motion to dismiss all counts of the complaint for failure to state a claim on which relief can be granted.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S6	On January 24, 2014, the Court granted the motion to dismiss in part and denied it in part, dismissing the count for declaratory relief and the prayer for a declaration that the batteries are defective, but allowing the case to proceed on other substantive counts.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S7	No class has been certified at this time.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P26_S8	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P27_S0	MSPBO, LLC v. Garmin International, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P28_S0	On December 16, 2013, MSPBO, LLC filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado against Garmin International, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P28_S1	No. 6,744,375 ( the 375 patent ).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P28_S2	On January 9, 2014, Garmin filed a motion to dismiss the complaint alleging that the claims are subject to arbitration pending in Kansas and alternatively asked the Colorado federal court to stay the suit until the arbitration in Kansas is resolved.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P28_S3	On September 11, 2014, the Colorado federal court denied the motion to dismiss or stay the suit.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P29_S0	On September 25, 2014, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each asserted claim of the 375 patent is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S0	Garmin filed a petition on January 8, 2014 with the District Court of Johnson County, Kansas to compel arbitration with Phatrat Technology, Inc. and Phatrat Technology, LLC, alleging Garmin s prior license agreement with Phatrat (the Phatrat License Agreement ) covers MSPBO s current claims as MSPBO is an affiliate of Phatrat under the license agreement with Garmin.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S1	On April 28, 2014, the District Court of Johnson County, Kansas granted Garmin s motion to compel arbitration.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S2	Phatrat filed a counterclaim for damages in this arbitration claiming that Garmin breached the Phatrat License Agreement by selling certain products that were excluded from the definition of licensed products in the Phatrat License Agreement.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S3	A hearing in this arbitration was held on December 14 to December 17, 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S4	Post-hearing briefs in the arbitration were filed on January 28, 2015, and the arbitrator has scheduled oral argument on the post-hearing briefs on February 18, 2015 .
1121788_15_ITEM3_P30_S5	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in the MSPBO lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend these actions.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P31_S0	On June 4, 2014 Navico Inc. and Navico Holding AS filed suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma against Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc. alleging infringement of U.S. Patents 8,300,499 ( the 499 patent ); 8,305,840 ( the 840 patent ); and 8,605,550 ( the 550 patent ).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P31_S1	On October 21, 2014, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each asserted claim of the 499, 840, and 550 patents is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P31_S2	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this lawsuit.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P32_S0	Pacing Technologies, LLC v. Garmin International, Inc., Garmin USA, Inc. and Garmin Ltd.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P33_S0	On May 1, 2012, Pacing Technologies, LLC ( Pacing Technologies ) filed suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California against Garmin International, Inc., Garmin USA, Inc. and Garmin Ltd alleging infringement of U.S. Patent No. 8,101,843.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P33_S1	On July 6, 2012, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each asserted claim of the patent-in-suit is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P33_S2	On March 11, 2014, the court granted Garmin s motion for summary judgment of non-infringement and found that Garmin s products could not infringe Pacing Technologies patent as a matter of law.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P33_S3	Pacing Technologies has appealed the court s summary judgment order to the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit which heard oral argument on the appeal December 3, 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P33_S4	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P34_S0	On October 2, 2014, Pioneer Corporation filed suit in the Tokyo District Court in Japan against Iiyonet Inc. alleging certain Garmin consumer products infringe Japanese Patent No. 3,442,138 (the 138 patent).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P34_S1	Iiyonet Inc. is the distributor in Japan for Garmin s consumer products.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P34_S2	Garmin intervened in this action on December 19, 2014, and has filed an answer asserting that the asserted claim of the 138 patent is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P34_S3	The Tokyo court has scheduled preparatory oral arguments on March 9, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P34_S4	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P35_S0	Silver State Intellectual Technologies, Inc. v. Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P36_S0	On September 29, 2011, Silver State Intellectual Technologies, Inc. filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Nevada against Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc. (collectively Garmin ), alleging infringement of U.S. Patent Nos. 6,525,768; 6,529,824; 6,542,812; 7,343,165; 7,522,992; 7,593,812; 7,650,234; 7,702,455 and 7,739,039.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P36_S1	On December 8, 2011, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each asserted claim of the patents-in-suit is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P36_S2	On April 5, 2013, the Court held a claim construction hearing and on August 15, 2013 the Court issued an order construing the clams of the patents in suit.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P37_S0	On March 21, 2014, Garmin filed a motion for partial summary judgment.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P37_S1	On July 24, 2014, the court denied the motion for partial summary judgment.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S0	On March 6, 2014, Garmin filed a request for ex parte reexamination of certain claims of the 992 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S1	On May 5, 2014, Garmin filed a request for ex parte reexamination of certain claims of the 812 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S2	On October 24, 2014, the U.S. Patent Office issued a non-final rejection of the identified claims of the 992 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S3	On September 24, 2014, the U.S. Patent Office issued a non-final rejection of the identified claims of the 812 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S4	The court has scheduled a trial commencing on May 11, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P38_S5	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P39_S0	Technology Properties Limited, LLC et al v. Garmin Ltd., Garmin International, Inc. and Garmin USA, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P40_S0	On July 24, 2012 Technology Properties Limited LLC, Phoenix Digital Solutions LLC, and Patriot Scientific Corporation filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Garmin Ltd., Garmin International, Inc., and Garmin USA, Inc. (collectively Garmin ) alleging infringement by Garmin of one or more of the following patents: U.S. Patent No. 5,809,336, U.S. Patent 5,440,749 and U.S. Patent No. 5,530,890.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P40_S1	By agreement of the parties, on October 29, 2012 this lawsuit was stayed pending the resolution of the investigation by the International Trade Commission in In the Matter of Certain Wireless Consumer Electronics Devices and Components Thereof.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P40_S2	Such Investigation was terminated with a finding of no violation by Garmin.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P41_S0	On March 21, 2012, Technology Properties Limited LLC filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P41_S1	On September 24, 2014, the court related the Garmin case with other cases brought by TPL, effectively lifting the stay.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P42_S0	On December 18, 2014, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each asserted claim of the 336, 749, and 890 patents is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P42_S1	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity, or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this action are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P43_S0	Visteon Global Technologies, Inc. and Visteon Technologies LLC v. Garmin International, Inc.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P44_S0	No 6,097,316 ( the 316 patent ).
1121788_15_ITEM3_P45_S0	On May 17, 2010, Garmin filed its answer asserting that each claim of the 060 patent, the 892 patent, the 408 patent and the 375 patent is invalid and/or not infringed.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P46_S0	On April 12, 2011, the special master appointed by the court held a claim construction hearing.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P46_S1	On December 12, 2011, the court issued an order adopting the special master s report construing the claims of the patents-in-suit.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P47_S0	On September 14, 2012, Garmin filed with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office petitions for ex parte reexamination of the 408 patent and the 060 patent as being anticipated and obvious in view of the prior art.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P47_S1	The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office subsequently granted Garmin s requests for ex parte reexaminations and initially rejected all identified claims.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P47_S2	On April 15, 2013, the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office issued a reexamination certificate confirming the patentability of the challenged claims of the 060 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S0	On November 30, 2012, Garmin filed motions for summary judgment of non-infringement and/or invalidity for the 892, 316, and 375 patents.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S1	Visteon filed its own motions for summary judgment of infringement of the 408 patent and validity, under section 112, of the 375 and 060 patents.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S2	On February 4, 2013, the summary judgment motions were referred to the special master for consideration.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S3	On May 23, 2014 the special master held a hearing on the summary judgment motions.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S4	Prior to the hearing Visteon dropped its claim that Garmin infringes the 316 patent.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S5	On September 17, 2014, the special master issued a report recommending that Garmin s motion for summary judgment of non-infringement of the 375 patent be granted, Visteon s motion for summary judgment of validity under section 112 of the 375 and 060 patents be granted, and that all other motions for summary judgment be denied.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S6	On October 16, 2014, Garmin filed objections to the special master s report and the parties await an order from the court.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P48_S7	Although there can be no assurance that an unfavorable outcome of this litigation would not have a material adverse effect on our operating results, liquidity or financial position, Garmin believes that the claims in this lawsuit are without merit and intends to vigorously defend this action.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P49_S0	In the normal course of business, the Company and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal claims, actions, and complaints, including matters involving patent infringement, other intellectual property, product liability, customer claims and various other risks.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P49_S1	It is not possible to predict with certainty whether or not the Company and its subsidiaries will ultimately be successful in any of these legal matters, or if not, what the impact might be.
1121788_15_ITEM3_P49_S2	However, the Company s management does not expect that the results in any of these legal proceedings will have a material adverse effect on the Company s results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P0_S0	Pursuant to General Instruction G(3) of Form 10-K and instruction 3 to paragraph (b) of Item 401 of Regulation S-K, the following list is included as an unnumbered Item in Part I of this Annual Report on Form 10-K in lieu of being included in the Company s Definitive Proxy Statement in connection with its annual meeting of shareholders scheduled for June 5, 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P1_S0	Dr. Min H. Kao , age 66, has served as Executive Chairman of Garmin Ltd. since January 2013 and was previously Chairman of Garmin Ltd. from August 2004 to December 2012 and Co-Chairman of Garmin Ltd. from August 2000 to August 2004.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P1_S1	He served as Chief Executive Officer of Garmin Ltd. from August 2002 to December 2012 and previously served as Co-Chief Executive Officer from August 2000 to August 2002.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P1_S2	Dr. Kao served as a director and officer of various subsidiaries of the Company from August 1990 until January 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P1_S3	Dr. Kao holds Ph.D. and MS degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Tennessee and a BS degree in Electrical Engineering from National Taiwan University.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S0	Clifton A. Pemble , age 49, has served as a director of Garmin Ltd. since August 2004.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S1	He has served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Garmin Ltd. since January 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S2	Previously, he served as President and Chief Operating Officer of Garmin Ltd. from October 2007 to December 2012.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S3	Previously, he was Vice President, Engineering of Garmin International, Inc. from 2005 to October 2007, Director of Engineering of Garmin International, Inc. from 2003 to 2005, and Software Engineering Manager of Garmin International, Inc. from 1995 to 2002 and a Software Engineer with Garmin International, Inc. from 1989 to 1995.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S4	Mr. Pemble has served as a director and officer of various Garmin subsidiaries since August 2003.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P2_S5	Mr. Pemble holds BA degrees in Mathematics and Computer Science from MidAmerica Nazarene University.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P3_S0	Douglas G. Boessen , age 52, has served as Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer of Garmin Ltd. since July 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P3_S1	Global, LLC from September 2013 to May 2014, as well as Collective Brands, Inc. from November 1997 to November 2012.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P3_S2	Mr. Boessen has served as a director and officer of various Garmin subsidiaries since July 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P3_S3	Mr. Boessen is a certified public accountant and holds a BS degree in Business from the University of Central Missouri and is a graduate of the executive development program at Northwestern University s Kellogg Graduate School of Management.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P4_S0	Andrew R. Etkind , age 59, has served as Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Garmin Ltd. since June 2009.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P4_S1	He was previously General Counsel and Secretary of Garmin Ltd. from August 2000 to June 2009.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P4_S2	He has been Vice President and General Counsel of Garmin International, Inc. since July 2007, General Counsel since February 1998, and Secretary since October 1998.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P4_S3	Mr. Etkind has served as a director and officer of various Garmin subsidiaries since December 2001.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P4_S4	Mr. Etkind holds BA, MA and LLM degrees from Cambridge University, England and a JD degree from the University of Michigan Law School.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P5_S0	All executive officers are elected by and serve at the discretion of the Company s Board of Directors.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P5_S1	None of the executive officers have an employment agreement with the Company.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P5_S2	There are no arrangements or understandings between the executive officers and any other person pursuant to which he or she was or is to be selected as an officer.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P5_S3	There is no family relationship among any of the executive officers.
1121788_15_ITEM4_P5_S4	Dr. Min H. Kao is the brother of Ruey-Jeng Kao, who is a supervisor of Garmin Corporation, Garmin s Taiwan subsidiary, who serves as an ex-officio member of Garmin Corporation s Board of Directors.

1121788_15_ITEM5_P0_S1	As of January 25, 2015, there were 196 shareholders of record.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P1_S1	Readers can identify these forward-looking statements by their use of such verbs as expects, anticipates, believes or similar verbs or conjugations of such verbs.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P1_S2	If any of our assumptions on which the statements are based prove incorrect or should unanticipated circumstances arise, our actual results could materially differ from those anticipated by such forward-looking statements.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P1_S3	The differences could be caused by a number of factors or combination of factors including, but not limited to, those discussed above in Item 1A. Readers are strongly encouraged to consider those factors when evaluating any such forward-looking statement.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P1_S4	We do not undertake to update any forward-looking statements in this Form 10-K.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	Garmin s fiscal year is a 52-53 week period ending on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	Fiscal years 2014, 2013 and 2012 contained 52 weeks.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P2_S2	Unless otherwise stated, all years and dates refer to the Company s fiscal year and fiscal periods.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P2_S3	Unless the context otherwise requires, references in this document to we, us, our and similar terms refer to Garmin Ltd. and its subsidiaries.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	Unless otherwise indicated, dollar amounts set forth in the tables are in thousands, except per share data.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	We are a leading worldwide provider of navigation, communications and information devices, most of which are enabled by Global Positioning System, or GPS, technology.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	We operate in five business segments, which serve the marine, outdoor, fitness, automotive/mobile, and aviation markets.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	Our segments offer products through our network of subsidiary distributors and independent dealers and distributors.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P4_S3	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the five segments can vary significantly.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P4_S4	As such, the segments are managed separately.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	Since our first products were delivered in 1991, we have generated positive income from operations each year and have funded our growth from these profits.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	Garmin s discussion and analysis of its financial condition and results of operations are based upon Garmin s consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P6_S1	The presentation of these financial statements requires Garmin to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P6_S2	On an on-going basis, Garmin evaluates its estimates, including those related to customer sales programs and incentives, product returns, bad debts, inventories, investments, intangible assets, income taxes, warranty obligations, and contingencies and litigation.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P6_S3	Garmin bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P6_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	For information on each of the following critical accounting policies and/or estimates, refer to the discussion in the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements as indicated in the table below:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	Our net sales are primarily generated through sales to our retail partners, dealer and distributor network and to original equipment manufacturers.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P8_S1	Refer to the Revenue Recognition discussion in Note 2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	Our sales are largely of a consumer nature; therefore, backlog levels are not necessarily indicative of our future sales results.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P9_S1	We aim to achieve a quick turnaround on orders we receive, and we typically ship most orders within 72 hours.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	Net sales are subject to seasonal fluctuation.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P10_S1	Typically, sales of our consumer products are highest in the second quarter, due to increased demand during the spring and summer season, and in the fourth quarter, due to increased demand during the holiday buying season.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P10_S2	Our aviation products do not experience much seasonal variation, but are more influenced by the timing of aircraft certifications and the release of new products when the initial demand is typically the strongest.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	Raw material costs are our most significant component of cost of goods sold.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	Our existing practice of performing the design and manufacture of our products in-house has enabled us to source components from different suppliers and, where possible, to redesign our products to leverage lower cost components.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P11_S2	We believe that our flexible production model allows our Xizhi, Jhongli, and LinKou manufacturing plants in Taiwan, our Olathe, Kansas, and Salem, Oregon manufacturing plants to experience relatively low costs of manufacturing.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P11_S3	In general, products manufactured in Taiwan have been our highest volume products.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P11_S4	Our manufacturing labor costs historically have been lower in Taiwan than in Olathe and Salem.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P12_S0	Sales price variability has had and can be expected to have an effect on our gross profit.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P12_S1	In the past, prices of our devices sold into the automotive/mobile market have declined due to market pressures and introduction of new products sold at lower price points.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P12_S2	In recent years, pricing has stabilized in automotive/mobile allowing for stable to improving gross margins.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P12_S3	The average selling prices of our aviation, outdoor, fitness, and marine products have historically been stable due to product mix and the introduction of more advanced products sold at higher prices.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P12_S4	In 2014, fitness pricing declined due to high volumes of lower-priced activity trackers.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	The effect of the sales price differences inherent within the mix of products sold could have a significant impact on our gross profit.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our advertising expenses consist of costs for media advertising, cooperative advertising with our retail partners, point of sale displays, and sponsorships.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	Our selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	The majority of our research and development costs represent salaries for our engineers, costs for high technology components and costs of test equipment used in product and prototype development.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P16_S1	Approximately 82% of the research and development of our products is performed in North America.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P17_S0	We are committed to increasing the level of innovative design and development of new products as we strive for expanded ability to serve our existing consumer and aviation markets as well as new markets for active lifestyle products.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P18_S0	We have experienced a relatively low effective corporate tax rate due to the proportion of our revenue generated by entities in tax jurisdictions with low statutory rates.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P18_S1	In particular, the profit entitlement afforded our Swiss-based companies based on their intellectual property rights ownership of our consumer products along with tax incentives offered by the Taiwanese government on certain high-technology capital investments have continued to reduce our tax rate.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P18_S2	We have taken advantage of the tax benefit in Taiwan since our inception and we expect to continue to benefit from lower effective tax rates at least through 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P19_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations as a percentage of net sales during the periods shown (the table may not foot due to rounding):
1121788_15_ITEM7_P20_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations through income before income taxes for each of our five segments during the period shown.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P20_S1	For each line item in the table the total of the segments amounts equals the amount in the consolidated statements of income data included in Item 6.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P21_S0	Net sales increased 9% in 2014 when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P21_S1	All segments, excluding automotive/mobile, grew in the fiscal year 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P21_S2	Automotive/mobile revenue remains the largest portion of our revenue mix at 43% in the fiscal year 2014 compared to 49% in the fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P22_S0	Total unit sales increased 9% to 15.1 million units in 2014 from 13.9 million units in 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P22_S1	The increase in unit sales volume was attributable to growth in all segments except automotive/mobile which had volume decline due to penetration rates and competing technologies.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S0	Automotive/mobile segment revenue decreased 5% from fiscal year 2013, as a 10% volume decline and slight average selling price (ASP) decline, were partially offset by amortization of previously deferred revenue exceeding current period revenue deferrals and increased auto OEM contributions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S1	Revenues in our fitness segment increased 60% from fiscal year 2013 on the strength of wellness products first introduced in 2014, and recent biking and running product introductions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S2	Aviation revenues increased 14% from fiscal year 2013 as both OEM market share gains and aftermarket strength contributed to growth.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S3	Outdoor revenues increased 4% from fiscal year 2013 primarily due to strong sales of f nix 2 and our lineup of dog tracking and training products, offset by declining sales of our handheld products which serve a mature industry.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S4	Revenues in our marine segment increased 11% due to both the recent acquisition of Fusion Electronics as well as new product introductions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P23_S5	This growth was partially offset by a competitive pricing environment in the global marine electronics industry.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P24_S0	The Company anticipates revenue of $2.9 billion in 2015 driven by growth in the fitness, aviation and marine segments offset by ongoing declines in the automotive/mobile segment.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P24_S1	In general, management believes that continuous innovation and the introduction of new products are essential for future revenue growth.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P25_S0	Cost of goods sold increased 3% in absolute dollars for fiscal year 2014 when compared to fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P25_S1	The increase was driven by growth in all segments excluding automotive/mobile.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P25_S2	Fitness and marine cost of goods increased in-line with sales growth as described above with gross margins stable year-over-year.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P25_S3	Outdoor cost of goods increased due to sales growth with gross margin contraction driven by product mix.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P26_S0	As a percentage of revenue, cost of goods sold decreased 240 basis points from fiscal year 2013 with improvement or stability in each segment, excluding outdoor as mentioned above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P26_S1	The automotive/mobile cost of goods improvement as a percent of revenues was primarily due to benefit from the amortization of previously deferred revenue and costs exceeding new deferrals on current period sales in 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P26_S2	Aviation margin improvement was primarily due to increased contribution of software sales which carry a higher margin.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P27_S0	Management believes that cost of goods sold as a percentage of sales will be relatively stable in 2015 given the growth in segments with higher margin profiles than corporate average, product mix within those segments and current component pricing.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P28_S0	Gross profit dollars in fiscal year 2014 increased 14% while gross profit margin increased 240 basis points compared to fiscal year 2013 with all segments stable or improving, excluding outdoor.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P28_S1	The automotive/mobile, fitness, marine and aviation segments recorded improved gross margins, as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P29_S0	Outdoor gross profit margins declined, as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P30_S0	Management believes that total company gross margins will be relatively stable in 2015 as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	Advertising expense increased 30% in absolute dollars while increasing 80 basis points as a percent of revenues.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	The increase in absolute dollars occurred primarily in outdoor and fitness to support new product introductions and was partially offset by decreased spending in automotive/mobile due to reduced cooperative advertising associated with lower volumes.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	Aviation advertising increased materially due to increased cooperative advertising efforts with our dealers.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	Management expects to decrease advertising as a percentage of sales in 2015 due to continued benefit from the 2014 advertising increase.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense increased 5% in absolute dollars and declined 50 basis points as a percent of revenues compared to fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	The absolute dollar increase is primarily related to product support, information technology costs and legal costs specific to marine litigation.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	The aviation increase was primarily driven by product support costs.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	Other variances by segment, excluding aviation, are primarily due to the allocation of certain selling, general and administrative expenses based on percentage of total revenues.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	Management expects selling, general and administrative expenses to increase slightly as a percentage of sales in 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	Research and development expense increased 8% due to ongoing development activities for new products and the addition of over 200 new engineering personnel to our staff since the fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	In absolute dollars, research and development costs increased $30.2 million when compared with fiscal year 2013 and decreased 10 basis points as a percent of revenue.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	Fitness, outdoor and aviation increased to support new product initiatives.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P38_S3	Automotive/mobile investment declined due to efforts to allocate research and development spending to areas with the highest growth potential.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	Management believes that one of the key strategic initiatives for future growth and success of Garmin is continuous innovation, development, and introduction of new products.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	Management expects that its research and development expenses will increase during fiscal 2015 on an absolute dollar basis and as a percent of revenue in order to deliver innovative new products and technologies.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	As a result of the above, operating income increased 20% in absolute dollars and 220 basis points as a percent of revenue when compared to the fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	Revenue growth and an improving gross margin percentage, as discussed above, contributed to the growth.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P41_S0	By segment results are discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	The average return on cash and investments during the fiscal years of 2014 and 2013 were 1.3% and 1.4%, respectively.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P42_S1	The slight increase in interest income was offset by fewer capital gains on investments in 2014, which is recorded as Other income.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	Foreign currency gains and losses for the Company are primarily tied to movements by the Taiwan Dollar, the Euro, and the British Pound Sterling in relation to the U.S. Dollar.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S0	The Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin Corporation.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S1	The U.S. Dollar remains the functional currency of Garmin (Europe) Ltd.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S2	The Euro is the functional currency of most European subsidiaries.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S3	As these entities have grown, currency fluctuations can generate material gains and losses.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S4	Additionally, Euro-based inter-company transactions can also generate currency gains and losses.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P44_S5	Due to the relative size of the entities using a functional currency other than the Taiwan Dollar, the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, currency fluctuations related to these entities are not expected to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P45_S0	The majority of the $4.3 million currency loss in the fiscal year 2014 was due to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P45_S1	The strengthening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Taiwan Dollar contributed an offsetting gain.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P45_S2	The movements of the Taiwan Dollar and Euro/British Pound Sterling have offsetting impacts when the currencies move congruently against the U.S. Dollar due to the use of the Taiwan Dollar for manufacturing costs and cash held in non-functional currency while the Euro and British Pound Sterling transactions relate primarily to revenue.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P46_S0	During fiscal year 2014, the U.S. Dollar strengthened 11.4% compared to the Euro and 5.5% compared to the British Pound Sterling resulting in a net loss of $43.7 million.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	This was more than offset as the U.S. Dollar strengthened 5.5% compared to the Taiwan Dollar resulting in a gain of $44.8 million.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	The remaining net currency loss of $5.4 million is related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P47_S0	The majority of the $35.5 million currency gain in 2013 was due to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P47_S1	The weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro and British Pound Sterling contributed additional gains.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P47_S2	During 2013, the U.S. Dollar weakened 4.1% and 2.2%, respectively, relative to the Euro and British Pound Sterling resulting in a foreign currency gain of $7.5 million in Garmin Ltd. and our European subsidiaries.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P47_S3	The U.S. Dollar strengthened 3.3% against the Taiwan Dollar resulting in a $30.2 million foreign currency gain due to the fluctuation of asset balances throughout the year.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P47_S4	The net result of these currency moves combined with other losses of $2.1 million, and the timing of transactions during the year was a net gain of $35.5 million for the Company.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	Our income tax expense increased by $318.4 million, to $359.5 million for the fiscal year 2014, from $41.1 million for the fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P48_S1	Contributing to the significant increase were:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P49_S0	research and development tax credits of $6.3 million related to 2012 which were recognized when the related legislation was enacted in January 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P50_S0	Partially offset by favorable impacts including:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P51_S0	release of uncertain tax position reserves due to expiration of certain statutes of limitations or completion of tax audits of $83.9 million in fiscal year 2014 compared to releases of $79.9 million in fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S0	In the third quarter of 2014, the Company initiated an inter-company restructuring that realigned our corporate entity structure.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S1	This change in corporate structure provides access to historical earnings that were previously permanently reinvested and allows us to efficiently repatriate future earnings.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S2	As a result of the change in corporate structure, Garmin recorded tax expense of $307,635.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S3	The first cash tax payment of $78,137 associated with the restructuring was made in the third quarter of 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S4	We anticipate paying approximately $185,000 in the second quarter of 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P52_S5	The remainder of the accrued tax will be paid incrementally as the cash is repatriated.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P53_S0	The Company expects the effective income tax rate to be between 16-17% in 2015.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income decreased 41% to $364.2 million for the fiscal year 2014 compared to $612.4 million for fiscal year 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	Net sales decreased 3% in 2013 when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P55_S1	The decrease was driven by the automotive/mobile segment which posted a 13% decline with offsetting growth in outdoor, fitness, marine and aviation.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P55_S2	Automotive/mobile revenue remains the largest portion of our revenue mix at 49% in 2013, compared to 55% in 2012.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	Total unit sales decreased 10% to 13.9 million units in 2013 from 15.4 million units in 2012.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P56_S1	The decrease in unit sales volume was attributable to reduced automotive/mobile volumes due to penetration rates and competing technologies.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P56_S2	This decline was partially offset by growth in each of the other segments.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P57_S0	Automotive/mobile segment revenue decreased 13% from the year-ago period, as volumes decreased 17% partially offset by average selling price (ASP) improvement due to the amortization of previously deferred revenue exceeding current year revenue deferrals in 2013 and increased auto OEM contribution with a higher ASP.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	Aviation revenues increased 16% from the year-ago period as the OEM market improved in some aircraft categories, as well as contribution from recent share gains and aftermarket products.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	Fitness revenues increased 11% on the strength of our cycling products, power meter, and the Forerunner 10 with strong volume growth partially offset by reduced ASPs associated with the Forerunner 10.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P58_S2	Revenues in our marine segment increased 7% as new product introductions were partially offset by a weak first quarter when we discounted many products in advance of new products and a global marine electronics industry that continues to be weak due to macroeconomic instability.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	Cost of goods sold decreased 4% when compared to the year ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	As a percentage of revenue, cost of goods sold decreased 50 basis points from the year ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S2	Cost of goods as a percentage of revenue for outdoor and fitness were negatively impacted by product mix and slight ASP declines.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S3	Cost of goods as a percentage of revenues increased by 850 basis points in marine due to significant pricing discounts on legacy inventory in the first half of 2013, competitive pricing dynamics on new products and rising component costs.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S4	The automotive/mobile segment recorded a 13% decline in cost of goods in absolute dollars as revenues declined 13%.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S5	Cost of goods as a percentage of revenues for the automotive/mobile segment decreased by 30 basis points as the effect of a $21 million one-time royalty fee benefit related to license fee overpayments recorded in the second quarter of 2012 was offset by the benefit from the amortization of previously deferred high margin revenue and the associated costs exceeding new deferrals on current period sales in 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P59_S6	The aviation segment experienced an absolute dollar cost of goods sold increase generally commensurate with the sales increase discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	Gross profit dollars in 2013 decreased 2% while gross profit margin increased 50 basis points compared to 2012 driven primarily by the automotive/mobile and aviation segments.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P60_S1	The automotive/mobile gross margin was stable at 43% as the royalty benefit recorded in the second quarter of 2012 was offset by increased amortization of previously deferred high margin revenues in 2013, as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	The gross profit margin percentage for the marine segment declined by 850 basis points as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	Advertising expense decreased 19% in absolute dollars and 80 basis points as a percent of revenue compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P62_S1	The decrease occurred primarily in the automotive/mobile and marine segments due to reduced cooperative advertising associated with lower volumes in automotive/mobile and a newer product line in marine requiring less promotional activity.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense decreased 4% in absolute dollars and 10 basis points as a percent of revenues compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	The absolute dollar decrease is primarily related to reduced legal settlements and legal fees in the automotive/mobile segment.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P63_S2	The increase in aviation is partially related to an increase in bad debt expense.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	Variances by segment are primarily due to the allocation of certain selling, general and administrative expenses based on percentage of total revenues.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	Research and development expense increased 12% due to ongoing development activities for new products and the addition of over 200 new engineering personnel to our staff since 2012.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	In absolute dollars, research and development costs increased $39.2 million when compared with 2012 representing a 190 basis point increase as a percent of revenue.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	Aviation had the largest increase in absolute dollars as we are investing heavily in OEM opportunities.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P65_S3	Marine and automotive/mobile investment is focused on marine product enhancements and automotive OEM opportunities, respectively.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	Within outdoor and fitness, we launched a number of new product categories in 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	We are also exploring new categories within these segments.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P67_S0	Operating income decreased 5% in absolute dollars and 40 basis points as a percent of revenue when compared to 2012 due to declining revenues and increased research and development expense offset by a slight improvement in gross margins and cost reductions in advertising and selling, general and administrative expenses, as discussed above.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P68_S0	Other income (expense) principally consists of interest income and foreign currency exchange gains and losses.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P68_S1	Interest income for fiscal 2013 increased slightly due to increasing cash and marketable securities balances during the year.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S0	The majority of the $35.5 million currency gain in 2013 was due to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S1	The weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Euro and British Pound Sterling contributed additional gains.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S2	The movements of the Taiwan Dollar and Euro/British Pound Sterling have offsetting impacts due to the use of the Taiwan Dollar for manufacturing costs and cash held in non-functional currency while the Euro and British Pound Sterling transactions relate to revenue.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S3	During 2013, the U.S. Dollar weakened 4.1% and 2.2%, respectively, relative to the Euro and British Pound Sterling resulting in a foreign currency gain of $7.5 million in Garmin Ltd. and our European subsidiaries.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S4	The U.S. Dollar strengthened 3.3% against the Taiwan Dollar resulting in a $30.2 million foreign currency gain due to the fluctuation of asset balances throughout the year.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P69_S5	The net result of these currency moves combined with other losses of $2.1 million, and the timing of transactions during the year was a net gain of $35.5 million for the Company.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P70_S0	The $20.0 million currency loss in 2012 was due primarily to weakening of the U.S. Dollar compared to the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P70_S1	During 2012, the U.S. Dollar weakened 3.8% compared to the Taiwan Dollar resulting in a loss of $31.3 million.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P70_S2	This was partially offset by the U.S. Dollar weakening 2.1% and 4.3%, respectively, compared to the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, resulting in a $10.4 million gain.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P70_S3	The remaining net currency gain of $0.8 million is related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P71_S0	Our income tax expense decreased by $41.0 million, to $41.1 million for the fiscal year 2013, from $82.1 million for the fiscal year 2012.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P74_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income increased 13% to $612.4 million for fiscal year 2013 compared to $542.4 million for fiscal year 2012.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P80_S0	The $221.8 million decrease in cash used in investing activities in fiscal year 2013 compared to fiscal year 2012 was primarily due to the following:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P81_S0	We have budgeted approximately $85 million of capital expenditures during fiscal 2015 to include some facility expansion, along with normal ongoing capital expenditures and maintenance activities.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P81_S1	It is management s goal to invest the on-hand cash consistent with Garmin s investment policy, which has been approved by the Board of Directors.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P81_S2	The investment policy s primary purpose is to preserve capital, maintain an acceptable degree of liquidity, and maximize yield within the constraint of low credit risk.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P81_S3	Garmin s average return on cash and investments during fiscal 2014, 2013, and 2012 were approximately 1.3%, 1.4% and 1.4%, respectively.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P82_S0	The fair value of our securities varies from period to period due to changes in interest rates, in the performance of the underlying collateral and in the credit performance of the underlying issuer, among other factors.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P83_S0	In 2013, Garmin experienced unrealized, non-cash losses on its investment portfolio resulting in a balance of $57,356 and $4,377 of gross other-than-temporary impairment and other unrealized losses on marketable securities at December 28, 2013.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P83_S1	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of the securities at an unrealized loss position at December 28, 2013 were $1,215,498 and $1,153,765, respectively.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P83_S2	This decrease in estimated fair value was primarily due to market valuations on mortgage-backed securities and obligations of states and political subdivisions declining.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P83_S3	The decline was due to increases in the 10 Year Treasury Bond Yield during 2013, which caused market valuations of securities in our investment portfolios to decline.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S0	The 10 Year Treasury Bond Yield decreased in 2014, resulting in a balance of $13,031 and $8,420 of gross other-than-temporary impairment and other unrealized losses on marketable securities at December 27, 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S1	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of the securities at an unrealized loss position at December 27, 2014 were $1,276,404 and $1,254,953, respectively.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S2	Approximately 59% of securities in our portfolio were at an unrealized loss position at December 27, 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S3	We have the ability to hold these securities until maturity or their value is recovered.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S4	We do not consider these unrealized losses to be other than temporary credit losses because there has been no deterioration in credit quality and no change in the cash flows of the underlying securities.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P84_S5	We do not intend to sell the securities and it is not more likely than not that we will be required to sell the securities; therefore, no impairment has been recorded in the accompanying condensed consolidated statement of income.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P86_S0	The $157.0 million increase in cash used in financing activities in fiscal year 2013 compared to fiscal year 2012 was primarily due to the following:
1121788_15_ITEM7_P87_S0	Our dividend has progressively increased from $0.40 per share for the four calendar quarters beginning in June 2011 to $0.45 per share for the eight calendar quarters beginning in June 2012 to $0.48 per share for the four calendar quarters beginning in June 2014.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P88_S0	We currently use cash flow from operations to fund our capital expenditures, to support our working capital requirements, and to pay dividends.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P88_S1	We expect that future cash requirements will principally be for capital expenditures, working capital, payment of dividends declared, share repurchases and the funding of strategic acquisitions.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P88_S2	We believe that our existing cash balances and cash flow from operations will be sufficient to meet our long-term projected capital expenditures, working capital and other cash requirements.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P90_S1	Pursuant to these agreements, the Company is contractually committed to make purchases of approximately $268.1 million over the next five years.

1121788_15_ITEM7_P91_S1	However, due to the uncertainty of the timing of future cash flows associated with our unrecognized tax benefits, we are unable to make reasonably reliable estimates of the period of cash settlement, if any, with the respective taxing authorities.
1121788_15_ITEM7_P91_S2	Accordingly, unrecognized tax benefits of $77.5 million as of December 27, 2014, have been excluded from the contractual obligations table above.
