1121788_16_ITEM8_P35_S1	Both the dividend paid and the remaining dividend payable were reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	Approximately $304,674 and $290,955 of retained earnings are indefinitely restricted from distribution to stockholders pursuant to the laws of Taiwan at December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	At December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, the Company had patents, customer related intangibles and other identifiable finite-lived intangible assets recorded at a cost of $216,465 and $191,034, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	Identifiable, finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives on a straight-line basis over three to ten years, which represents the expected pattern and duration of use of and benefit received from the respective assets.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P37_S2	Accumulated amortization was $158,704 and $151,589 at December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P37_S3	Amortization expense on these intangible assets was $7,115, $8,362 and $17,847, for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014, and December 28, 2013, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P37_S4	In the next five years, the amortization expense is estimated to be $19,780, $7,506, $6,734, $4,787 and $3,610, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company s excess purchase cost over fair value of net assets acquired (goodwill) was $187,791 at December 26, 2015 and $178,638 at December 27, 2014.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of marketable securities at the time of purchase and reevaluates such designation as of each balance sheet date.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	All of the Company s marketable securities were considered available-for-sale at December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	Available-for-sale securities are stated at fair value, with the unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive gain (loss).
1121788_16_ITEM8_P40_S2	At December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, cumulative unrealized gains and losses, net of tax of ($16,321) and ($18,303), respectively, were reported in accumulated other comprehensive income, net of related taxes.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	Investments are reviewed periodically to determine if they have suffered an impairment of value that is considered other than temporary.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	If investments are determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized at the date of determination.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	Testing for impairment of investments requires significant management judgment.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P42_S1	The identification of potentially impaired investments, the determination of their fair value and the assessment of whether any decline in value is other than temporary are the key judgment elements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P42_S2	The discovery of new information and the passage of time can significantly change these judgments.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P42_S3	Revisions of impairment judgments are made when new information becomes known, and any resulting impairment adjustments are made at that time.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	The economic environment and volatility of securities markets increase the difficulty of determining fair value and assessing investment impairment.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	The amortized cost of debt securities classified as available-for-sale is adjusted for amortization of premiums and accretion of discounts to maturity, or in the case of mortgage-backed securities, over the estimated life of the security.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	Such amortization is included in interest income from investments.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P44_S2	Realized gains and losses, and credit declines in value judged to be other-than-temporary are included in other income.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	Investments are discussed in detail in Note 3 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company accounts for income taxes using the liability method in accordance with the FASB ASC 740 topic Income Taxes .
1121788_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	The liability method provides that deferred tax assets and liabilities are recorded based on the difference between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amount for financial reporting purposes as measured based on the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P47_S2	The Company records a valuation allowance to reduce deferred tax assets to the amount that is believed more likely than not to be realized.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Company adopted the applicable guidance included in the FASB ASC 740 topic Income Taxes related to accounting for uncertainty in income taxes on December 31, 2006, the beginning of fiscal year 2007.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	We recognize liabilities for tax audit issues in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on our estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P49_S1	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves not to be required, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when we determine the liabilities are no longer necessary.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P49_S2	If our estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate assessment, a further charge to expense would result.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	Income taxes are discussed in detail in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	Garmin recognizes revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales price is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P51_S1	For the large majority of Garmin s sales, these criteria are met once product has shipped and title and risk of loss have transferred to the customer.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P51_S2	The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of hardware products and software bundled with hardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware in accordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P51_S3	The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific software accounting guidance for standalone sales of software products and sales of software bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality of the hardware.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P51_S4	The Company generally does not offer specified or unspecified upgrade rights to its customers in connection with software sales.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	For multiple-element arrangements that include tangible products that contain software essential to the tangible product s functionality and undelivered software elements that relate to the tangible product s essential software, the Company allocates revenue to all deliverables based on their relative selling prices.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P52_S1	In such circumstances, the accounting principles establish a hierarchy to determine the selling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables as follows: (i) vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value (VSOE), (ii) third-party evidence of selling price (TPE), and (iii) best estimate of the selling price (ESP).
1121788_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	VSOE generally exists only when the Company sells the deliverable separately, on more than a limited basis, at prices within a relatively narrow range.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P53_S1	In addition to the products listed below, the Company has offered certain other products including mobile applications, in-dash navigation solutions, aviation subscriptions and extended warranties that involve multiple-element arrangements that are immaterial.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	Garmin offers PNDs with lifetime map updates (LMUs) bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P54_S1	LMUs enable customers to download the latest map and point of interest information for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P54_S2	In addition, Garmin offers PNDs with traffic service bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P54_S3	The Company has identified multiple deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs which include the LMU and/or traffic service.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	The first deliverable is the hardware along with the software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	The remaining deliverables are the LMU and/or traffic service.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these deliverables using the relative selling price method.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P55_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P55_S4	The revenue and associated cost of royalties allocated to the LMU and/or the traffic service are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated life of the products.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P56_S0	The Company has determined sufficient VSOE does not exist for LMU or traffic, and that third party evidence of selling price is not available.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P56_S1	During 2013, the Company estimated selling price of the undelivered element based on the relative selling price method using a weighted average of the stand-alone sales price, the price differential between bundled and unbundled PND units, and the royalty or subscription cost plus a normal margin.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P56_S2	These estimates were reflective of how the Company established product pricing based in part on customer perception of value of the added LMU or traffic service capability to the PND.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P56_S3	In 2014, the Company determined that stand-alone and unbundled unit sales no longer occurred on more than a limited basis, and therefore began using the royalty cost plus a normal margin as the primary indicator to calculate relative selling prices of the undelivered elements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	Garmin records estimated reductions to revenue for customer sales programs, returns and incentive offerings including rebates, price protection (product discounts offered to retailers to assist in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases), promotions and other volume-based incentives.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P57_S1	The reductions to revenue are based on estimates and judgments using historical experience and expectation of future conditions.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P57_S2	Changes in these estimates could negatively affect Garmin s operating results.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P57_S3	These incentives are reviewed periodically and, with the exceptions of price protection and certain other promotions, accrued for on a percentage of sales basis.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P57_S4	If market conditions were to decline, Garmin may take actions to increase customer incentive offerings, possibly resulting in an incremental reduction of revenue at the time the incentive is offered.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P58_S0	The Company records revenue net of sales tax, trade discounts and customer returns.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P58_S1	The reductions to revenue for expected future product returns are based on Garmin s historical experience.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	At December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, the Company had deferred revenues totaling $293,713 and $338,728 , respectively, and related deferred costs totaling $87,945 and $87,476, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P60_S0	The deferred revenues and costs are recognized over their estimated economic lives of two to five years on a straight-line basis.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	In the next five years, the gross margin recognition of deferred revenue and cost for the currently deferred amounts is estimated to be $115,806, $60,971, $21,467, $5,356 and $2,168, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in cost of goods sold in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Company provides for estimated warranty costs at the time of sale.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S1	The Company s standard warranty obligation to retail partners generally provides for a right of return of any product for a full refund in the event that such product is not merchantable, is damaged or defective.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S2	The Company s historical experience is that these types of warranty obligations are generally fulfilled within 5 months from time of sale.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S3	The Company s standard warranty obligation to its end-users provides for a period of one to two years from date of shipment while certain aviation products have a warranty period of two years from the date of installation .
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S4	The Company s estimate of costs to service its warranty obligations are based on historical experience and expectations of future conditions and are recorded as a liability on the balance sheet.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S5	To the extent Garmin experiences increased warranty claim activity or increased costs associated with servicing those claims, its warranty accrual will increase, resulting in decreased gross profit.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P62_S6	The following reconciliation provides an illustration of changes in the aggregate warranty reserve:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	(1) Our expected future cost is estimated based upon historical trends in the volume of product returns and the related warranty costs incurred.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P63_S1	In 2013 we updated these assumptions and shortened the estimated time horizon in which we settle claims with our retail partners.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	(2) Minor changes in cost estimates related to pre-existing warranties are aggregated with accruals for new warranty contracts in the accrual for products sold line .
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S0	The Company provides certain monthly and quarterly incentives for its dealers and distributors based on various factors including dealer purchasing volume and growth.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	Additionally, from time to time, the Company provides rebates to end users on certain products.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S2	Estimated rebates and incentives payable to dealers and distributors are regularly reviewed and recorded as accrued expenses on a monthly basis.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S3	In addition, the Company provides dealers and distributors with product discounts to assist these customers in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S4	Each discount is tied to a specific product and can be applied to all customers who have purchased the product or a special discount may be agreed to on an individual customer basis.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P65_S5	These rebates, incentives, and discounts are recorded as reductions to net sales in the accompanying consolidated statements of income in the period the Company has sold the product.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P66_S0	The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P66_S1	Advertising expense amounted to approximately $167,166, $146,633, and $112,905, for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	A majority of the Company s research and development is performed in the United States.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	Research and development costs, which are expensed as incurred, amounted to approximately $427,043, $395,121, and $364,923, for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P68_S0	Customer service and technical support costs are included as selling, general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of income.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P68_S1	Customer service and technical support costs include costs associated with performing order processing, answering customer inquiries by telephone and through Web sites, e-mail and other electronic means, and providing free technical support assistance to customers.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P68_S2	The technical support is provided within one year after the associated revenue is recognized.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P68_S3	The related cost of providing this free support is not material.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Software requires companies to expense software development costs as they incur them until technological feasibility has been established, at which time those costs are capitalized until the product is available for general release to customers.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P69_S1	Capitalized software development costs are not significant as the time elapsed from working model to release is typically short.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P69_S2	As required by the Research and Development topic of the FASB ASC, costs incurred to enhance our existing products or after the general release of the service using the product are expensed in the period they are incurred and included in research and development costs in the accompanying consolidated statements of income.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	The Company currently sponsors four stock based employee compensation plans.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	The FASB ASC topic entitled Compensation Stock Compensation requires the measurement and recognition of compensation expenses for all share-based payment awards made to employees and directors including employee stock options and restricted stock based on estimated fair values.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	Accounting guidance requires companies to estimate the fair value of share-based payment awards on the date of grant using an option-pricing model.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P71_S1	The value of the portion of the award that is ultimately expected to vest is recognized as stock-based compensation expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite service period in the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	As stock-based compensation expenses recognized in the accompanying consolidated statements of income are based on awards ultimately expected to vest, they have been reduced for estimated forfeitures.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P72_S1	Accounting guidance requires forfeitures to be estimated at the time of grant and revised, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P72_S2	Forfeitures were estimated based on historical experience and management s estimates.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	Stock compensation plans are discussed in detail in Note 9 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) ( ASU 2014-09 ), which supersedes previous revenue recognition guidance.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P74_S1	ASU 2014-09 requires that a company will recognize revenue at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring goods or services to a customer.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P74_S2	In applying the new guidance, a company will (1) identify the contract(s) with a customer; (2) identify the performance obligations in the contract; (3) determine the transaction price; (4) allocate the transaction price to the contract s performance obligations; and (5) recognize revenue when (or as) the entity satisfies a performance obligation.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P74_S3	The new standard may be applied retrospectively to each prior period presented or in a modified retrospective approach in which the cumulative effect will be recognized as of the date of adoption.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P75_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-14, which defers the effective date of the new guidance by one year such that the new provisions will now be required for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P75_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting the new revenue standard on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P76_S0	In January 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-01, Financial Instruments Overall (Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities ( ASU 2016-01 ).
1121788_16_ITEM8_P76_S1	The standard addresses certain aspects of recognition, measurement, presentation, and disclosure of financial instruments.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P76_S2	ASU 2016-01 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P76_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting the new standard on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
1121788_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	The accounting guidance classifies the inputs used to measure fair value into the following hierarchy:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	The Company endeavors to utilize the best available information in measuring fair value.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P79_S1	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P79_S2	The valuation methods used by the Company for each significant class of investments are summarized below.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P80_S0	Mortgage-backed securities, corporate bonds and obligations of states and political subdivisions Valued based on prices obtained from an independent pricing vendor using both market and income approaches.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P81_S0	The primary inputs to the valuation include quoted prices for similar assets in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets in markets that are not active, contractual cash flows, benchmark yields, and credit spreads.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P82_S0	Common stocks Valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the individual securities are traded.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P83_S0	The methods described above may produce a fair value calculation that may not be indicative of net realizable value or reflective of future fair values.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P83_S1	Furthermore, while the Company believes its valuation methods are appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of different methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value of certain financial instruments could result in a different fair value measurement at the reporting date.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P90_S0	The Company s investment policy requires investments to be rated A or better with the objective of minimizing the potential risk of principal loss.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P90_S1	The fair value of our securities varies from period to period due to changes in interest rates, in the performance of the underlying collateral and in the credit performance of the underlying issuer, among other factors.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P90_S2	The Company does not intend to sell the securities that have an unrealized loss shown in the table above and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the investment before recovery of their amortized costs bases, which may be maturity.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P91_S0	The Company recognizes the credit component of other-than-temporary impairments of debt securities in Other Income and the noncredit component in Other comprehensive income (loss) for those securities that we do not intend to sell and for which it is not more likely than not that we will be required to sell before recovery.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P91_S1	In 2013, the Company experienced unrealized, noncredit losses on its investment portfolio resulting in gross other-than-temporary impairment and other unrealized losses on marketable securities.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P91_S2	During 2014 and 2015, the Company did not record any material impairment changes on its outstanding securities.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P92_S0	The amortized cost and estimated fair value of the securities at an unrealized loss position at December 26, 2015 were $1,299,856 and $1,281,150, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P92_S1	Approximately 63.6% of securities in the Company s portfolio were at an unrealized loss position at December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P92_S2	We have the ability to hold these securities until maturity or their value is recovered.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P92_S3	We do not consider these unrealized losses to be other than temporary credit losses because there has been no deterioration in credit quality and no change in the cash flows of the underlying securities.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P92_S4	The Company does not intend to sell the securities and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell the securities; therefore, no impairment has been recorded in the accompanying condensed consolidated statement of income.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P93_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P103_S0	In the normal course of business, the Company and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal claims, investigations, and complaints, including matters involving patent infringement and other intellectual property claims.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P103_S1	The Company evaluates, on a quarterly basis, developments in legal proceedings, investigations or claims that could affect the amount of any accrual or disclosure.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P103_S2	The assessment regarding whether a loss is probable or a reasonable possibility, and whether the loss or a range of loss is estimable, often involves a series of complex judgments about future events.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P104_S0	Management of the Company currently does not believe there is at least a reasonable possibility the Company may have incurred a material loss, or a material loss in excess of recorded accruals, with respect to loss contingencies individually and in the aggregate, for the fiscal year ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P104_S1	The results of legal proceeding, investigations and claims, however, cannot be predicted with certainty.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P104_S2	Although management considers the likelihood to be remote, an adverse resolution of one of more of such matters in excess of management s expectations could have a material adverse effect on the Company s results of operations in a particular quarter or fiscal year.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P105_S0	The Company settled or resolved certain matters during the fiscal year ended December 26, 2015 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material impact on the Company s financial condition or results of operations.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P106_S0	GII and the Company s other U.S.-based subsidiaries sponsor a defined contribution employee retirement plan under which their employees may contribute up to 50% of their annual compensation subject to Internal Revenue Code maximum limitations and to which the subsidiaries contribute a specified percentage of each participant s annual compensation up to certain limits as defined in the retirement plan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P106_S1	Additionally, GEL has a defined contribution plan under which its employees may contribute up to 7.5% of their annual compensation.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P106_S2	In both the plans described above, the subsidiaries contribute an amount determined annually at the discretion of the Board of Directors.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P106_S3	During the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013, expense related to these and other defined contribution plans of $37,489, $29,267 and $26,839, respectively, was charged to operations.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P107_S0	Certain of the Company s foreign subsidiaries participate in local defined benefit pension plans.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P107_S1	Contributions are calculated by formulas that consider final pensionable salaries.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P107_S2	Neither obligations nor contributions for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013, were significant.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P108_S0	The Company s income tax provision (benefit) consists of the following:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P109_S0	The income tax provision differs from the amount computed by applying the U.S. statutory federal income tax rate to income before taxes.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P109_S1	The sources and tax effects of the differences, including the impact of establishing tax contingency accruals, are as follows:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P110_S0	In the third quarter of 2014, the Company initiated an inter-company restructuring that realigned our corporate entity structure.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P110_S1	This change in corporate structure provides access to historical earnings that were previously permanently reinvested and allows us to efficiently repatriate future earnings.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P110_S2	As a result of the change in corporate structure, Garmin recorded tax expense of $307,635.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P110_S3	Approximately $263,000 of this amount has been paid.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P110_S4	The remainder of the accrued tax is expected to be paid incrementally as the cash is repatriated.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P111_S0	The holding company statutory federal income tax rate in Switzerland, the Company's place of incorporation since the Redomestication effective June 27, 2010, is 7.83%.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P111_S1	If the Company reconciled taxes at the Swiss holding company federal statutory tax rate to the reported income tax for 2015 as presented above, the amounts related to tax at the statutory rate would be $154,000 lower, or $44,000, and the foreign tax rate differential would be adjusted by a similar amount to $52,000.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P111_S2	For 2014, the amounts related to tax at the statutory rate would be approximately $197,000 lower, or $57,000, and the foreign tax rate differential would be adjusted by a similar amount to approximately $44,000.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P111_S3	For 2013, the amount related to tax at the statutory rate would be approximately $178,000 lower, or $51,000, and the foreign tax differential would be reduced by a similar amount to approximately $64,000.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P111_S4	All other amounts would remain substantially unchanged.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P112_S0	The Company s income before income taxes attributable to non-U.S. operations was $403,242, $546,790, and $502,423, for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014, and December 28, 2013, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P112_S1	The Taiwan tax holiday benefits included in the table above reflect $0.02, $0.02, and $0.03 per weighted-average common share outstanding for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014, and December 28, 2013, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P112_S2	The Company currently expects to benefit from these Taiwan tax holidays through 2017, at which time these tax benefits will likely expire.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P113_S0	Income taxes of $21,085, $20,606, and $307,990 at December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014, and December 28, 2013, respectively, have not been accrued by the Company for the unremitted earnings of several of its foreign subsidiaries because such earnings are intended to be reinvested in the subsidiaries indefinitely.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P113_S1	These balances decreased in 2014 as a result of the inter-company restructuring which reduced the amount of earnings reinvested in the subsidiaries indefinitely.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P114_S0	Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P114_S1	Significant components of the Company s deferred tax assets and liabilities are as follows:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P115_S0	The stock options outstanding related to the deferred tax asset of $35,360 will begin to expire over the next several years.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P115_S1	Given the exercise price of the options expiring over the next 12 months compared to the current market price it is possible that these options will expire unexercised, resulting in a potential write-off of $6,000 that would reduce the deferred tax asset and reduce equity.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P116_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015-17, Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes ( ASU 2015-17 ), requiring all deferred tax assets and liabilities, and any related valuation allowance, to be classified as non-current on the balance sheet, which simplifies the presentation of deferred income taxes.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P117_S0	The standard is effective for financial statements issued for annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016, and interim periods within those annual periods.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P117_S1	Early adoption is permitted, and the Company elected to prospectively adopt the accounting standard as of December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P118_S0	Prior periods in our Consolidated Financial Statements were not retrospectively adjusted.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P119_S0	At December 26, 2015, the Company had $3,906 of tax credit carryover compared to $2,726 at December 27, 2014.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P119_S1	The surtax credit carryover from 2013 of $52,618 was adjusted and subsequently fully utilized in 2014 upon the execution of the inter-company restructuring.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P119_S2	In turn, the entire valuation allowance regarding the surtax credit was released.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P120_S0	At December 26, 2015, the Company had a deferred tax asset of $5,228 related to the future tax benefit on net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards of $19,580.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P120_S1	Included in the NOL carryforwards is $7,092 that relates to Spain and expires in varying amounts between 2022 and 2027, $338 that relates to Switzerland and expires in 2022, $4,238 related to the Netherlands and expires in varying amounts between 2017 and 2022, $1,317 that relates to Finland and expires in 2025, $1,300 that relates to the United States and expires in 2035, and $5,295 that relates to various other jurisdictions and has no expiration date.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P121_S0	The Company has recorded a valuation allowance for a portion of its deferred tax asset relating to various tax attributes that it does not believe are more likely than not to be realized.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P121_S1	In the future, if the Company determines, based on existence of sufficient evidence, that it should realize more or less of its deferred tax assets, an adjustment to the valuation allowance will be made in the period such a determination is made.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P123_S3	None of the unrecognized tax benefits are due to uncertainty in the timing of deductibility.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P130_S0	The Company has identified five reportable segments for external reporting purposes auto, aviation, marine, outdoor and fitness.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P130_S1	There are two operating segments (auto PND and auto OEM) that are not reported separately but aggregated within the auto reportable segment.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P130_S2	Each operating segment is individually reviewed and evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM), who allocates resources and assesses performance of each segment individually.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P131_S0	All of the Company s reportable segments offer products through the Company s network of independent dealers and distributors as well as through OEMs.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P131_S1	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the five reportable segments vary.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P132_S0	The Company s marine, auto, outdoor, and fitness segments include portable global positioning system (GPS) receivers and accessories sold primarily to retail outlets.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P132_S1	These products are produced primarily by the Company s subsidiary in Taiwan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P133_S0	The Company s aviation products are portable and panel mount avionics for Visual Flight Rules and Instrument Flight Rules navigation and are sold primarily to aviation dealers and certain aircraft manufacturers.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P134_S0	The Company s Chief Executive Officer has been identified as the CODM.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P134_S1	In 2015, the measure of segment profit or loss used by the CODM to assess segment performance and allocate resources changed from income before income taxes to operating income.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P134_S2	This change did not impact the measurement methods used to determine reported segment profit or loss in the years ended December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P135_S0	Operating income represents net sales less costs of goods sold and operating expenses, including certain allocated general and administrative costs.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P135_S1	The accounting policies of the reportable segments are the same as those described in the summary of significant accounting policies.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P135_S2	There are no inter-segment sales or transfers.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P136_S0	The Company s reportable segments share many common resources, infrastructures and assets in the normal course of business.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P136_S1	Thus, the Company does not report accounts receivable, inventories, property and equipment, intangible assets, or capital expenditures by segment to the CODM.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P141_S0	The various Company stock compensation plans are summarized below.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P142_S0	For all stock compensation plans, the company s policy is to issue treasury shares for option/stock appreciation right (SAR) exercises, restricted stock unit (RSU) releases and employee stock purchase plan (ESPP) purchases.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P143_S0	In June 2011, the stockholders adopted an equity incentive plan for non-employee directors (the 2011 Directors Plan ) providing for grants of stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares, pursuant to which up to 122,592 shares were available for issuance.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P143_S1	The term of each award cannot exceed ten years.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P143_S2	Awards may vest over a minimum two-year period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P143_S3	In 2015, 2014, and 2013, 12,008, 7,120, and 11,484, restricted stock units were granted under this plan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P144_S0	In June 2005, the shareholders adopted an equity incentive plan (the 2005 Plan ) providing for grants of incentive and nonqualified stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares to employees of the Company and its subsidiaries, pursuant to which up to 10,000,000 common shares were available for issuance.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P144_S1	In 2013, the shareholders approved an additional 3,000,000 shares to the plan, making the total shares authorized under the plan 13,000,000.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S0	Option and SAR grants vest evenly over a period of five years or as otherwise determined by the Board of Directors or the Compensation Committee and generally expire ten years from the date of grant, if not exercised.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S1	RSUs granted prior to December 10, 2012 vested or are vesting evenly over a period of five years, while RSUs granted on and after that date vest evenly over a period of three years.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S2	In addition to time-based vesting requirements, the vesting of certain RSU grants is also contingent upon the achievement of certain revenue and profitability goals.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S3	During 2015, 2014, and 2013, 1,171,905, 425,347, and 413,978 RSUs were granted under the 2005 Plan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S4	No SARs were granted under the 2005 Plan in 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P145_S5	During 2014 and 2013, 47,095 and 52,673 SARs were granted under the 2005 plan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P146_S0	In October 2000, the shareholders adopted an equity incentive plan (the 2000 Plan ) providing for grants of incentive and nonqualified stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares to employees of the Company and its subsidiaries, pursuant to which up to 7,000,000 common shares were available for issuance.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P146_S1	The stock options and SARs vest evenly over a period of five years or as otherwise determined by the Board of Directors or the Compensation Committee and generally expire ten years from the date of grant, if not exercised.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P146_S2	The Company did not grant any stock awards from the 2000 Plan in 2015, 2014, or 2013.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P147_S0	Also in October 2000, the stockholders adopted a stock option plan for non-employee directors (the 2000 Directors Plan ) providing for grants of options for up to 100,000 common shares.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P147_S1	In 2009, the stockholders approved an additional 150,000 shares to the plan, making the total shares authorized under the plan 250,000.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P147_S2	The term of each award is ten years.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P147_S3	All awards vest evenly over a three-year period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P147_S4	Following the June 2011 approval of the 2011 Directors Plan, the Company will no longer issue options to purchase shares under this plan.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P148_S0	A summary of the Company s stock-based compensation activity and related information under the 2011 Directors Plan, the 2005 Plan, the 2000 Plan and the 2000 Directors Plan for the years ended December 26, 2015, December 27, 2014 and December 28, 2013 is provided below:
1121788_16_ITEM8_P149_S0	The weighted-average remaining contract life for stock options and SARs outstanding and exercisable at December 26, 2015 is 1.81 and 1.67 years, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P149_S1	The weighted-average remaining contract life of restricted stock units at December 26, 2015 was 1.54 years.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P150_S0	The fair value of awards is determined at the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P150_S1	The fair value of RSUs is calculated using the closing price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant, reduced by the present value of estimated dividends over the vesting period, which are not accrued.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P150_S2	The fair value of stock options and SARs was calculated with the following weighted-average assumptions for 2014 and 2013.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P150_S3	No options or SARs were granted in 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P151_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of traded options and SARs which have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P151_S1	In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected stock price volatility.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P152_S0	The total fair value of awards vested during 2015, 2014, and 2013 was $23,351, $19,127, and $20,956, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P152_S1	The aggregate intrinsic values of options and SARs outstanding and exercisable at December 26, 2015 were $207 and $207, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P152_S2	The aggregate intrinsic values of options and SARs exercised during 2015, 2014, and 2013 were $3,714, $18,885, and $13,114 respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P152_S3	The aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs outstanding at December 26, 2015 was $61,259.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P152_S4	The aggregate intrinsic values of RSUs released during 2015, 2014, and 2013, were $20,787, $28,119, and $27,007 respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P153_S0	Aggregate intrinsic value of options and SARs represents the applicable number of awards multiplied by the positive difference between the exercise price and the Company s closing stock price on the last trading day of the relevant fiscal period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P153_S1	Aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs represents the applicable number of awards multiplied by the Company s closing stock price on the last trading day of the relevant fiscal period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P153_S2	The Company s closing stock price was $36.98 on December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P153_S3	As of December 26, 2015, there was $52,590 of total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested share-based compensation awards granted to employees under the stock compensation plans.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P153_S4	That cost is expected to be recognized over the weighted average remaining vesting period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S0	The shareholders also adopted an ESPP.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S1	Up to 6,000,000 shares of common stock have been reserved for the ESPP with shareholders approving an additional 2,000,000 shares in June 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S2	Shares will be offered to employees at a price equal to the lesser of 85% of the fair market value of the stock on the date of purchase or 85% of the fair market value on the first day of the ESPP period.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S3	The ESPP is intended to qualify as an employee stock purchase plan under Section 423 of the Internal Revenue Code.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S4	During 2015, 2014, and 2013, 488,753, 349,982, and 395,220, shares, respectively were purchased under the plan for a total purchase price of $16,789, $14,634, and $12,181, respectively.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S5	During 2015, 2014, and 2013, the purchases were issued from treasury shares.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P154_S6	At December 26, 2015, approximately 2,000,628 shares were available for future issuance.

1121788_16_ITEM8_P165_S0	On February 11, 2016, Garmin Ltd. announced the signing of a purchase agreement to acquire DeLorme, a privately-held company that designs and markets consumer based satellite tracking devices with two-way communication and navigational capabilities based in Yarmouth, Maine.
1121788_16_ITEM8_P165_S1	This acquisition is not expected to be material.

1121788_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, we have evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures pursuant to Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(b) as of the end of the period covered by this report.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based on the evaluation, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that these disclosure controls and procedures are effective.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting for the Company.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management s assessment of and conclusion on the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting are included as Exhibits 31.1, 31.2, 32.1 and 32.2.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P4_S0	Management of the Company assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P4_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013 framework).
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P5_S0	Based on such assessment and those criteria, management believes that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 26, 2015.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P6_S0	Ernst Young LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the Company s consolidated financial statements, issued an attestation report on management s effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 26, 2015, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P7_S0	We have audited Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries internal control over financial reporting as of December 26, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) (the COSO criteria).
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P7_S1	Garmin Ltd. s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P7_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P8_S0	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P8_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P8_S2	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P8_S3	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P9_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P9_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P10_S0	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P10_S1	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P11_S0	In our opinion, Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 26, 2015, based on the COSO criteria.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P12_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated balance sheets of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries as of December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, shareholders equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 26, 2015 of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries and our report dated February 17, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
1121788_16_ITEM9A_P13_S0	There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 26, 2015 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.

1121788_17_ITEM1A_P0_S0	The risks described below are not the only ones facing our company.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to us or that we currently believe to be immaterial may also impair our business operations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P0_S2	If any of the following risks occur, our business, financial condition or operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P1_S0	If we are not successful in the continued development, timely manufacture, and introduction of new products or product categories, demand for our products could decrease to the extent that lost sales and profits from declining segments or product categories are not entirely offset.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We expect that a significant portion of our future revenue will continue to be derived from sales of newly introduced products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P2_S1	This is particularly important to replace sales and profits lost in declining segments or product categories.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P3_S0	The market for our products is characterized by rapidly changing technology, evolving industry standards and changes in customer needs.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P3_S1	If we fail to introduce new products, or to modify or improve our existing products, in response to changes in technology, industry standards or customer needs, our products could rapidly become less competitive or obsolete.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P3_S2	We must continue to make significant investments in research and development in order to continue to develop new products, enhance existing products and achieve market acceptance for such products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P3_S3	However, there can be no assurance that development stage products will be successfully completed or, if developed, will achieve significant customer acceptance.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S0	If we are unable to successfully develop and introduce competitive new products, and enhance our existing products, our future results of operations would be adversely affected.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S1	Our pursuit of necessary technology may require substantial time and expense.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S2	We may need to license new technologies to respond to technological change.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S3	These licenses may not be available to us on terms that we can accept or may materially change the gross profits that we are able to obtain on our products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S4	We may not succeed in adapting our products to new technologies as they emerge.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Development and manufacturing schedules for technology products are difficult to predict, and there can be no assurance that we will achieve timely initial customer shipments of new products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S6	The timely availability of these products in volume and their acceptance by customers are important to our future success.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P4_S7	Any future challenges related to new products, whether due to product development delays, manufacturing delays, lack of market acceptance, delays in regulatory approval, or otherwise, could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P5_S0	If we are unable to compete effectively with existing or new competitors, our resulting loss of competitive position could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The markets for many of our products are highly competitive, and we expect competition to increase in the future.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Some of our competitors have significantly greater financial, technical and marketing resources than we do.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P6_S2	These competitors may be able to respond more rapidly to new or emerging technologies or changes in customer requirements.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P6_S3	They may also be able to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products or secure better product positioning with retailers.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Increased competition could result in price reductions, fewer customer orders, reduced margins and loss of market share.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Our failure to compete successfully against current or future competitors could seriously harm our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P8_S0	Maturation or contraction of the market for wearable devices could adversely affect our revenue and profits.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We have experienced growth in sales and profits in our outdoor and fitness segments, which in recent years have benefited from increased sales of wearable devices.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P9_S1	If the wearable device market declines, or categories of devices within the wearable device market decline, such as fitness trackers or smartwatches, our business, financial condition or operating results could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The demand for personal navigation devices (PNDs) has been and continues to be reduced by replacement technologies becoming available on mobile devices and factory-installed systems in new autos, as well as by market saturation.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P11_S0	GPS/navigation technologies have been incorporated into competing devices such as mobile handsets, tablets, and new automobiles through factory-installed systems.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Many companies are now offering navigation software for these mobile devices.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P11_S2	The acceptance of this technology by consumers has reduced sales in this segment and has reduced profits in some periods.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Navigation systems are also becoming more prevalent as standard and/or optional equipment on new automobiles.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Increased navigation penetration on mobile handsets and in new automobiles is expected to cause further declines in sales of our portable navigation devices and could further reduce profits.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The auto segment, which represents approximately 29% of our revenues, is expected to continue to decline in 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We experienced substantial growth through 2008 in the auto segment of our business as PNDs became mass-market consumer electronics in both Europe and North America.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P13_S1	This market is declining as competing technologies emerged and market saturation occurred.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P13_S2	This has resulted in, and is expected to continue to result in, periods of lower revenues and profits for this segment.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P14_S0	Our annual and quarterly financial statements will reflect fluctuations in foreign currency translation.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P15_S0	The operation of our subsidiaries in international markets results in exposure to movements in currency exchange rates.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We have experienced significant foreign currency gains and losses due to the strengthening and weakening of the U.S. Dollar relative to certain other currencies.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The potential of volatile foreign exchange rate fluctuations in the future could have a significant effect on our results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We have not historically hedged our foreign currency exchange rate risks.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The currencies that typically create a majority of our exchange rate exposure are the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin Corporation, the U.S. Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin (Europe) Ltd., and the Euro is the functional currency of most of our other European subsidiaries, although some transactions and balances are denominated in British Pounds.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Other legal entities primarily use the local currency as the functional currency.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P18_S3	Due to the relative size of entities using a functional currency other than the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling, fluctuations of other currencies are not expected to have a material impact on our financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We translate income and expense activity at the approximate rate of exchange at the transaction date, and all assets and liabilities at the rate of exchange in effect at the balance sheet date.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Income and expense activity in a currency other than the U.S. Dollar can be impacted by exchange rate variations over time.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P20_S1	The majority of our consolidated foreign currency gain or loss is typically driven by exchange rate impacts on the significant cash, receivables, and payables held in a currency other than the functional currency at a given legal entity.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Such gain or loss will create variations in our earnings per share.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P20_S3	However, because there is minimal cash impact caused by such exchange rate variations, management will continue to focus on our operating performance before the impact of foreign currency gains and losses.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Changes in applicable tax laws or resolutions of tax disputes could result in adverse tax consequences to the Company.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Our tax position could be adversely impacted by changes in Swiss, United States or foreign tax laws, tax treaties, or tax regulations or the interpretation or enforcement thereof by any tax authority.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P22_S1	We cannot predict the outcome of any specific legislative proposals.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P23_S0	Legislative proposals are being considered in Switzerland that could make significant changes in the corporate tax regime and increase the taxes applicable to us in Switzerland.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Corporate reform being considered in the United States could significantly change our tax liability such as proposals to remove certain domestic deductions, implement border adjustments, and/or broaden the circumstances under which foreign corporations could be considered resident in the United States.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P23_S2	Moreover, international taxing standards continue to evolve as a result of the Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD) recommendations aimed at preventing perceived base erosion and profit shifting by multinational corporations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P23_S3	While these recommendations are not changes to tax law, the countries where we operate may implement legislation or take unilateral actions which may result in adverse effects to our income tax provision and financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Significant judgment is required in determining our worldwide provision for income taxes.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P24_S1	In the ordinary course of our business, there are many transactions and calculations where the ultimate tax determination is uncertain.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P24_S2	We are regularly under audit by tax authorities.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Although we believe our tax estimates are reasonable, the final determination of tax audits and any related litigation could be materially different from our historical income tax provisions and accruals.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P24_S4	The results of an audit or litigation could have a material effect on our income tax provision, net income or cash flows in the period or periods for which that determination is made.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P25_S0	A significant portion of our global and U.S. sales are comprised of goods assembled and manufactured in our facilities in Taiwan and the PRC.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P25_S1	The imposition of additional U.S. or foreign governmental controls, regulations that create new or enhanced restrictions on free trade with the U.S., or increases in tariffs on goods imported into the U.S., including goods imported from China and Taiwan, could have substantial adverse effects on our business operations, results of operations, and financial condition.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Economic, regulatory and political conditions and uncertainty could adversely affect our revenue and profits.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Our revenue and profits depend significantly on general economic conditions and the demand for products in the markets in which we compete.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P27_S1	Economic weakness or constrained consumer and business spending has resulted in periods of decreased revenue and in the future, could result in decreased revenue and problems with our ability to manage inventory levels and collect customer receivables.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P27_S2	In addition, financial difficulties experienced by our retailers and OEM customers have resulted, and could result in the future, in significant bad debt write-offs and additions to reserves in our receivables and could have an adverse effect on our results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P28_S0	The United Kingdom (UK) held a referendum on June 23, 2016 in which a majority of voters voted to exit the European Union (EU).
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P29_S0	Due to the unprecedented nature of the expected withdrawal, significant uncertainty exists surrounding the timing and terms of the expected exit.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P29_S1	We have operations in the UK and several EU member states whose currencies, namely British Pound Sterling (GBP) and Euro, economies, taxation, and trade regulation, among other factors, could be adversely impacted by the negotiations and outcomes of the UK s leaving the EU, which is likely to be a lengthy and complicated process.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P29_S2	These events could have a material adverse effect on our business operations, results of operations and financial condition.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P30_S0	If we do not correctly anticipate demand for our products, we may not be able to secure sufficient quantities or cost-effective production of our products or we could have costly excess production or inventories.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P31_S0	We have generally been able to increase or decrease production to meet fluctuations in demand.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P31_S1	However, the demand for our products depends on many factors and may be difficult to forecast.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P31_S2	We expect that it will become more difficult to forecast demand as we introduce and support a diverse product portfolio, as competition in the market for our products intensifies and as the markets for some of our products mature.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Significant unanticipated fluctuations in demand could cause the following problems in our operations:
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P32_S0	If demand increases beyond what we forecast, we would have to rapidly increase production.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P32_S1	We would depend on suppliers to provide additional volumes of components and those suppliers might not be able to increase production rapidly enough to meet unexpected demand.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P33_S0	Rapid increases in production levels to meet unanticipated demand could result in higher costs for manufacturing and supply of components and other expenses.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P33_S1	These higher costs could lower our profit margins.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P33_S2	Further, if production is increased rapidly, manufacturing quality could decline, which may also lower our margins and reduce customer satisfaction.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P34_S0	If forecasted demand does not develop, we could have excess inventories of finished products and components, which would use cash and could lead to write-offs of some or all of the excess inventories.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P34_S1	Lower than forecasted demand could also result in excess manufacturing capacity or reduced manufacturing efficiencies at our facilities, which could result in lower margins.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We depend on our suppliers, some of which are the sole source for specific components, and our production would be seriously harmed if these suppliers are not able to meet our demand and alternative sources are not available, or if the costs of components rise.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We are dependent on third party suppliers for various components used in our current products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S1	Some of the components that we procure from third party suppliers include semiconductors and electroluminescent panels, liquid crystal displays, memory chips, batteries and microprocessors.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S2	The cost, quality and availability of components are essential to the successful production and sale of our products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S3	Some components we use are from sole source suppliers.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S4	Certain application-specific integrated circuits incorporating our proprietary designs are manufactured for us by sole source suppliers.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P36_S5	Alternative sources may not be currently available for these sole source components.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P37_S0	In the past we have experienced shortages of certain components.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P37_S1	In addition, if there are shortages in supply of components, the costs of such components may rise.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P37_S2	If suppliers are unable to meet our demand for components on a timely basis and if we are unable to obtain an alternative source or if the price of the alternative source is prohibitive, or if the costs of components rise, our ability to maintain timely and cost-effective production of our products would be seriously harmed.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Gross margins for our products may fluctuate or erode.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S0	Gross margins in some of our segments have declined in recent years and could further decline in the future due to competitive price reductions that are not fully offset by material cost reductions.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S1	In addition, our overall gross margin may fluctuate from period to period due to a number of factors, including product mix, competition and unit volumes.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S2	In particular, the average selling prices of a specific product tend to decrease over that product s life.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S3	To offset such decreases, we intend to rely primarily on component cost reduction, obtaining yield improvements and corresponding cost reductions in the manufacturing of existing products and on introducing new products that incorporate advanced features and therefore can be sold at higher average selling prices.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S4	However, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain any such yield improvements or cost reductions or introduce any such new products in the future.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P39_S5	To the extent that such cost reductions and new product introductions do not occur in a timely manner or our products do not achieve market acceptance, our business, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Changes in our United States federal income tax classification could result in adverse tax consequences to our shareholders.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P41_S0	We do not believe that we, or any of our United States or non-United States subsidiaries, are currently a passive foreign investment company for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P41_S1	We do not expect to become a passive foreign investment company.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P41_S2	However, because the passive foreign investment company determination is made annually based on whether the company s income or assets meet certain thresholds as determined under United States federal tax principles which are based on facts and circumstances that may be beyond our control, we cannot assure that we will not become a passive foreign investment company in the future.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P41_S3	If we are a passive foreign investment company in any year, then any of our shareholders that is a United States person could be liable to pay tax on their pro rata share of our income plus an interest charge upon some distributions by us or when that shareholder sells our common shares at a gain.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P41_S4	Further, if we are classified as a passive foreign investment company in any year in which a United States person is a shareholder, we generally will continue to be treated as a passive foreign investment company with respect to such shareholder in all succeeding years, regardless of whether we continue to satisfy the income or asset tests mentioned above.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P42_S0	We do not believe that we, or any of our United States or non-United States subsidiaries, are currently a Controlled Foreign Corporation (CFC) for United States federal income tax purposes.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P42_S1	We do not expect to become a CFC.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P43_S0	The CFC determination is made daily based on whether the United States shareholders own more than fifty percent of the voting power or value of the Company.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P43_S1	Only United States persons that own ten percent or more of the voting power of the Company s shares qualify as United States shareholders.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P43_S2	Currently the Company has two shareholders that qualify as United States shareholders owning greater than ten percent of the voting power, totaling 36% of the outstanding shares.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P43_S3	Thus, the addition of even one additional ten percent or greater United States shareholder could result in classification as a CFC and subject all such holders to significant tax consequences.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P44_S0	If the Company were to be classified as a CFC for an uninterrupted thirty-day period in any year, the Company s shareholders that qualify as United States shareholders could be liable to pay US income tax at ordinary income tax rates on their pro-rata share of certain categories of the Company s income for the period in which the Company is classified as a CFC.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P44_S1	As the Company cannot control the ownership of the Company s stock nor can the Company control which shareholders participate in the Company s stock buyback program, ownership changes could result that create United States shareholders which increase the risk of Garmin being treated as a CFC.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We may experience unique economic and political risks associated with companies that operate in Taiwan.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P46_S0	Our principal manufacturing facilities, where we manufacture most of our consumer products, are located in Taiwan.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P46_S1	Relations between Taiwan and the People s Republic of China, also referred to as the PRC, and other factors affecting the political or economic conditions of Taiwan in the future could materially affect our business, financial condition and results of operations and the market price and the liquidity of our shares.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P47_S0	The PRC asserts sovereignty over all of China, including Taiwan, certain other islands and all of mainland China.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P47_S1	The PRC government does not recognize the legitimacy of the Taiwan government.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Although significant economic and cultural relations have been established during recent years between Taiwan and the PRC, the PRC government has indicated that it may use military force to gain control over Taiwan in certain circumstances, such as the declaration of independence by Taiwan.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P48_S0	The United States' relations with Taiwan are governed by the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, which signifies when the U.S. switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to the PRC, referred to as the one-China policy.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P48_S1	Deviations from the one-China policy could lead to adverse changes in China-U.S. and China-Taiwan relations and could adversely affect our operations in Taiwan in the future.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our intellectual property rights are important to our operations, and we could suffer loss if they infringe upon other s rights or are infringed upon by others.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P50_S0	We rely on a combination of patents, copyrights, trademarks and trade secrets, confidentiality provisions and licensing arrangements to establish and protect our proprietary rights.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P50_S1	To this end, we hold rights to a number of patents and registered trademarks and regularly file applications to attempt to protect our rights in new technology and trademarks.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P50_S2	However, there is no guarantee that our patent applications will become issued patents, or that our trademark applications will become registered trademarks.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P50_S3	Moreover, even if approved, our patents or trademarks may thereafter be successfully challenged by others or otherwise become invalidated for a variety of reasons.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P50_S4	Thus, any patents or trademarks we currently have or may later acquire may not provide us a significant competitive advantage.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P51_S0	Third parties may claim that we are infringing their intellectual property rights.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P51_S1	Such claims could have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P52_S0	From time to time we receive letters alleging infringement of patents, trademarks or other intellectual property rights and we have been, and currently are, a defendant in lawsuits alleging patent infringement.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P52_S1	Litigation concerning patents or other intellectual property is costly and time consuming.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P52_S2	We may seek licenses from such parties, but they could refuse to grant us a license or demand commercially unreasonable terms.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P52_S3	Such infringement claims could also cause us to incur substantial liabilities and to suspend or permanently cease the use of critical technologies or processes or the production or sale of major products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P53_S0	We may become subject to significant product liability costs.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P54_S0	If our aviation products malfunction or contain errors or defects, airplane collisions or crashes could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P54_S1	Malfunctions or errors or defects in our marine navigational products could cause boats to run aground or cause other wreckage, personal injury or death.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P54_S2	If our automotive or marine products contain defects or errors in the mapping supplied by third-party map providers or if our users do not heed our warnings about the proper use of these products, collisions or accidents could occur resulting in property damage, personal injury or death.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P54_S3	If any of these events occurs, we could be subject to significant liability for personal injury and property damage and, under certain circumstances, could be subject to a judgment for punitive damages.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P55_S0	We maintain insurance against accident-related risks involving our products.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P55_S1	However, there can be no assurance that such insurance would be sufficient to cover the cost of damages to others or that such insurance will continue to be available at commercially reasonable rates.
1121788_17_ITEM1A_P55_S2	In addition, insurance coverage may not cover awards of punitive damages and may not cover the cost of associated legal fees and defense costs, which could result in lower margins.
