1121788_17_ITEM7_P72_S0	We have budgeted approximately $130 million to $140 million of capital expenditures during fiscal 2017 to include some facility expansion, along with normal ongoing capital expenditures and maintenance activities.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P0_S0	We have market risk primarily in connection with the pricing of our products and services and the purchase of raw materials.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Product pricing and raw materials costs are both significantly influenced by semiconductor market conditions.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Historically, during cyclical industry downturns, we have been able to offset pricing declines for our products through a combination of improved product mix and success in obtaining price reductions in raw materials costs.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P1_S0	We do not believe that inflation has had a material effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P1_S1	If our costs were to become subject to significant inflationary pressures, we may not be able to fully offset such higher costs through price increases.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P1_S2	Our inability or failure to do so could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The operation of Garmin s subsidiaries in international markets results in exposure to movements in currency exchange rates.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P3_S0	We have experienced significant foreign currency gains and losses due to the strengthening and weakening of the U.S. dollar.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P3_S1	The potential of volatile foreign exchange rate fluctuations in the future could have a significant effect on our results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company has not historically hedged its foreign currency exchange rate risks.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P5_S0	The currencies that create a majority of the Company s exchange rate exposure are the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Garmin Corporation, headquartered in Xizhi, Taiwan, uses the local currency as the functional currency.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P6_S1	The Company translates all assets and liabilities at year-end exchange rates and income and expense accounts at average rates during the year.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P7_S0	In order to minimize the effect of the currency exchange fluctuations on our net assets, we have elected to retain most of our Taiwan subsidiary s cash and investments in marketable securities denominated in U.S. dollars.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Most European subsidiaries use the Euro as the functional currency.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The functional currency of our largest European subsidiary, Garmin (Europe) Ltd. remains the U.S. Dollar, and as some transactions occurred in British Pounds Sterling or Euros, foreign currency gains or losses have been realized historically related to the movements of those currencies relative to the U.S. Dollar.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P8_S2	The Company believes that gains and losses will become more material in the future as our European presence grows.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P9_S0	During fiscal year 2016, the U.S. Dollar weakened 1.7% against the Taiwan Dollar resulting in a $9.2 million foreign currency loss.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P9_S1	The U.S. Dollar strengthened 4.2% against the Euro resulting in a foreign currency loss of $13.0 million.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P9_S2	The U.S. Dollar strengthened 16.8% against the British Pound Sterling resulting in a loss of $5.1 million.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P9_S3	The net result of these currency moves combined with other net losses of $4.4 million, and the timing of transactions during the year was a net loss of $31.7 million for the Company and a currency translation adjustment of $4.7 million during the fiscal year 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P10_S0	We assessed the Company s exposure to movements in currency exchange rates by performing a sensitivity analysis of adverse changes in exchange rates and the corresponding impact to our results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Based on monetary assets and liabilities denominated in currencies other than respective functional currencies as of December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, hypothetical and reasonably possible adverse changes of 10% for the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling would have resulted in an adverse impact on income before income taxes of approximately $92 million and $95 million at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P11_S0	We have no outstanding long-term debt as of December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P11_S1	We, therefore, have no meaningful debt-related interest rate risk.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P12_S0	We are exposed to interest rate risk in connection with our investments in marketable securities.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P12_S1	As interest rates change, the unrealized gains and losses associated with those securities will fluctuate accordingly.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P13_S0	The Company s investment policy targets low risk investments with the objective of minimizing the potential risk of principal loss.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P13_S1	The Company does not intend to sell securities in an unrealized loss position and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell such investments before recovery of their amortized costs bases, which may be maturity.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P13_S2	During 2016 and 2015, the Company did not record any material impairment charges on its outstanding securities.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P14_S0	We assessed the Company s exposure to interest rate risk by performing a sensitivity analysis of a parallel shift in the yield curve and the corresponding impact to the Company s portfolio of marketable securities.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P14_S1	Based on balance sheet positions as of December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, the hypothetical and reasonably possible 100 basis point increases in interest rates across all securities would have resulted in declines in portfolio fair market value of approximately $45 million and $43 million at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM7A_P14_S2	Such losses would only be realized if the Company sold the investments prior to maturity.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P0_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries as of December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, stockholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P0_S1	These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P0_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P1_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P1_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P2_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P2_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P2_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P3_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2016, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P4_S0	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Garmin Ltd. and Subsidiaries' internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) and our report dated February 22, 2017 expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P5_S0	Garmin Ltd. and subsidiaries (together, the Company ) design, develop, manufacture, market, and distribute a diverse family of hand-held, wrist-based, portable and fixed-mount Global Positioning System (GPS)-enabled products and other navigation, communications, information and sensor-based products.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P5_S1	Garmin Corporation (GC) is primarily responsible for the manufacturing and distribution of the Company s products to the Company s subsidiaries and, to a lesser extent, new product development and sales and marketing of the Company s products in Asia and the Far East.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P5_S2	Garmin International, Inc. (GII) is primarily responsible for sales and marketing of the Company s products in the Americas region and for most of the Company s research and new product development.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P5_S3	GII also manufactures most of the Company s products in the aviation segment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P6_S0	Garmin (Europe) Ltd. (GEL) is responsible for sales and marketing of the Company s products in Europe, the Middle East and Africa (EMEA).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P6_S1	Many of GEL s sales are to other Company-owned distributors in the EMEA region.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P7_S1	The accompanying consolidated financial statements reflect the accounts of Garmin Ltd. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P7_S2	All significant inter-company balances and transactions have been eliminated.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P8_S0	At the Company s Annual General Meeting on June 10, 2016, the Company s shareholders approved the cancellation of 10,000,000 registered shares of the Company held by the Company (the Formation Shares ) and the reduction in par value of each share of the Company from CHF 10 to CHF 0.10 and the amendment of the Company s Articles of Association to effect a corresponding share capital reduction.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P9_S0	The Company s fiscal year is based on a 52-53-week period ending on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P9_S1	Due to the fact that there are not exactly 52 weeks in a calendar year, and there is slightly more than one additional day per year (not including the effects of leap year) in each calendar year as compared to a 52-week fiscal year, the Company will have a fiscal year comprising 53 weeks in certain fiscal years, as determined by when the last Saturday of the calendar year occurs.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P10_S0	In those resulting fiscal years that have 53 weeks, the Company will record an extra week of sales, costs, and related financial activity.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P10_S1	Therefore, the financial results of those 53-week fiscal years, and the associated 14-week fourth quarters, will not be entirely comparable to the prior and subsequent 52-week fiscal years and the associated 13-week quarters.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P10_S2	Fiscal years 2015 and 2014 included 52 weeks while fiscal 2016 included 53 weeks.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P11_S0	The preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P11_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P12_S0	Many Garmin Ltd. subsidiaries utilize currencies other than the United States Dollar (USD) as their functional currency.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P12_S1	As required by the Foreign Currency Matters topic of the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC), the financial statements of these subsidiaries for all periods presented have been translated into USD, the functional currency of Garmin Ltd., and the reporting currency herein, for purposes of consolidation at rates prevailing during the year for sales, costs, and expenses and at end-of-year rates for all assets and liabilities.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P12_S2	The effect of this translation is recorded in a separate component of stockholders equity.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P12_S3	Cumulative currency translation adjustments of ($9,411) and ($14,107) as of December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, respectively, have been included in accumulated other comprehensive income in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P13_S0	Transactions in foreign currencies are recorded at the approximate rate of exchange at the transaction date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P13_S1	Assets and liabilities resulting from these transactions are translated at the rate of exchange in effect at the balance sheet date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P14_S0	The movements of the Taiwan Dollar and Euro/British Pound Sterling have offsetting impacts on operating income when the currencies move congruently against the U.S. Dollar due to the use of the Taiwan Dollar for manufacturing costs while the Euro and British Pound Sterling transactions relate primarily to revenue.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P14_S1	Foreign currency losses recorded in results of operations were $31,651, $23,465, and $4,299, for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P14_S2	The loss in fiscal 2016 was due primarily to the USD weakening against the Taiwan Dollar and the USD strengthening against the Euro and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P14_S3	The loss in fiscal 2015 was due primarily to the USD strengthening against the Euro and British Pound Sterling, partially offset by the USD strengthening against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P14_S4	The loss in fiscal 2014 was due primarily to the USD strengthening against the Euro and the British Pound Sterling, which was largely offset by the USD strengthening against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P15_S0	Basic earnings per share amounts are computed based on the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P15_S1	For purposes of diluted earnings per share, the number of shares that would be issued from the exercise of dilutive stock options has been reduced by the number of shares which could have been purchased from the proceeds of the exercise at the average market price of the Company s stock during the period the options were outstanding.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P16_S0	For purposes of reporting cash flows, cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand, operating accounts, money market funds, and securities with maturities of three months or less when purchased.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P16_S1	The carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents approximates fair value, given the short maturity of those instruments.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S0	The Company sells its products to retailers, wholesalers, and other customers and extends credit based on its evaluation of the customer s financial condition.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S1	Potential losses on receivables are dependent on each individual customer s financial condition.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S2	The Company carries its trade accounts receivable at net realizable value.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S3	Typically, its accounts receivable are collected within 80 days and do not bear interest.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S4	The Company monitors its exposure to losses on receivables and maintains allowances for potential losses or adjustments.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S5	The Company determines these allowances by (1) evaluating the aging of its receivables and (2) reviewing its high-risk customers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P17_S6	Past due receivable balances are written off when internal collection efforts have been unsuccessful in collecting the amount due.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P18_S0	The Company maintains trade credit insurance to provide security against large losses.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P19_S0	The Company grants credit to certain customers who meet the Company s pre-established credit requirements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P19_S1	Generally, the Company does not require security when trade credit is granted to customers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P19_S2	Credit losses are provided for in the Company s consolidated financial statements and typically have been within management s expectations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P20_S0	Certain customers are allowed extended terms consistent with normal industry practice.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P20_S1	Most of these extended terms can be classified as either relating to seasonal sales variations or to the timing of new product releases by the Company.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P21_S0	The Company s top ten customers have contributed between 22% and 24% of net sales since 2014.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P21_S1	None of the Company s customers accounted for more than or equal to 10% of consolidated net sales in the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P22_S0	On March 14, 2013, the Company entered into a Memorandum of Agreement (the Agreement ) with Bombardier, Inc. ( Bombardier ).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P23_S0	The Company is the supplier of the avionics system for the Lear 70 and Lear 75 aircraft for Learjet, Inc., which is a subsidiary of Bombardier (the Program ).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P23_S1	In order to assist Bombardier in connection with delayed cash flows from the Program partially related to the certification of avionics for the Program exceeding the planned delivery date, the Company agreed to provide Bombardier a short term, interest free, loan of $173,708 in cash in seven installments beginning on March 22, 2013 and ending on September 20, 2013 pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Agreement.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P23_S2	Bombardier repaid the loan in five installments beginning in November 2013 and ending in April 2014 pursuant to the terms and conditions of the Agreement and subsequent amendment signed December 6, 2013.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P24_S0	Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market with cost being determined on a first-in, first-out (FIFO) basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P24_S1	The Company writes down its inventory for estimated obsolescence or unmarketable inventory equal to the difference between the cost of inventory and the estimated market value based upon assumptions about future demand and market conditions.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P24_S2	If actual market conditions are less favorable than those projected by management, additional inventory write-downs may be required.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P25_S0	Property and equipment are recorded at cost and depreciated using the straight-line method over the following estimated useful lives:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P26_S0	As required by the Property, Plant and Equipment topic of the FASB ASC, the Company reviews long-lived assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be fully recoverable.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P26_S1	The carrying amount of a long-lived asset is not recoverable if it exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition of the asset.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P26_S2	That assessment is based on the carrying amount of the asset at the date it is tested for recoverability.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P27_S0	An impairment loss is measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset exceeds its fair value.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Intangibles Goodwill and Other topic of the FASB ASC requires that goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite useful lives should not be amortized but rather be tested for impairment at least annually or sooner whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that they may be impaired.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P28_S1	The Company performs its annual goodwill and intangible asset impairment tests in the fourth quarter of each year.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P28_S2	If the carrying amount of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value as determined by a discounted cash flow model in step one of the impairment analysis, the second step of the analysis will be performed.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P29_S0	Each of the Company s operating segments (auto PND, auto OEM, aviation, marine, outdoor, and fitness) represents a distinct reporting unit.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P29_S1	The Company did not recognize any material goodwill or intangible asset impairment charges in 2016, 2015, or 2014, and step two was not considered necessary in any of those periods as fair value was substantially in excess of the carrying amount for all reporting units in the respective periods.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P30_S0	As noted above, the PND market has declined as competing technologies have emerged and market saturation has occurred.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P30_S1	This has resulted in, and is expected to continue to result in, periods of lower revenues and profits for the Company s auto PND reporting unit.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P30_S2	Consequently, if operating results and/or market conditions deteriorate significantly faster or more drastically than the forecasts utilized in our estimation of fair value, the goodwill associated with the Company s auto PND reporting unit may be at risk of impairment in the future.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P31_S0	Accounting guidance also requires that intangible assets with finite lives be amortized over their estimated useful lives and reviewed for impairment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P31_S1	The Company is currently amortizing its acquired intangible assets with finite lives over periods ranging from three to ten years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P32_S0	Under Swiss corporate law, dividends must be approved by shareholders at the general meeting of the Company s shareholders.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P33_S0	On June 10, 2016, the shareholders approved a dividend of $2.04 per share (of which, $1.53 was paid in the Company s 2016 fiscal year) payable in four equal installments on dates determined by the Board of Directors.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P33_S1	The dates determined by the Board were as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P34_S0	The Company paid dividends in 2016 in the amount of $481,452.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P34_S1	Both the dividends paid and the remaining dividend payable were reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P35_S0	On June 5, 2015, the shareholders approved a dividend of $2.04 per share (of which, $1.02 was paid in the Company's 2015 fiscal year) payable in four equal installments on dates determined by the Board of Directors.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P35_S1	The dates determined by the Board were as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P36_S0	The Company paid dividends in 2015 in the amount of $378,117.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P36_S1	Both the dividends paid and the remaining dividend payable were reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P37_S0	On June 6, 2014, the shareholders approved a dividend of $1.92 per share (of which, $0.96 was paid in the Company's 2014 fiscal year) payable in four equal installments on dates determined by the Board of Directors.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P37_S1	The dates determined by the Board were as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company paid dividends in 2014 in the amount of $360,075.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P38_S1	Both the dividends paid and the remaining dividend payable were reported as a reduction of retained earnings.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P39_S0	As of December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, approximately $304,674 of retained earnings was indefinitely restricted from distribution to stockholders pursuant to the laws of Taiwan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	At December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, the Company had patents, customer related intangibles and other identifiable finite-lived intangible assets recorded at a cost of $253,472 and $216,465, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Identifiable, finite-lived intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives on a straight-line basis over three to ten years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P41_S1	Accumulated amortization was $173,023 and $158,704 at December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P41_S2	Amortization expense on these intangible assets was $14,319, $7,115, and $8,362 for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P41_S3	In the next five years, the amortization expense is estimated to be $15,727, $14,502, $11,798, $9,301, and $4,931, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	The Company s excess purchase cost over fair value of net assets acquired (goodwill) was $224,553 at December 31, 2016 and $187,791 at December 26, 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	Management determines the appropriate classification of marketable securities at the time of purchase and reevaluates such designation as of each balance sheet date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	All of the Company s marketable securities were considered available-for-sale at December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P44_S1	Available-for-sale securities are stated at fair value, with the unrealized gains and losses, net of tax, reported in other comprehensive income (loss).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P44_S2	At December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, cumulative unrealized net losses of $27,350 and $16,321, respectively, were reported in accumulated other comprehensive income, net of related taxes.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	Investments are reviewed periodically to determine if they have suffered an impairment of value that is considered other than temporary.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P45_S1	If investments are determined to be impaired, a loss is recognized at the date of determination.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	Testing for impairment of investments requires significant management judgment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P46_S1	The identification of potentially impaired investments, the determination of their fair value and the assessment of whether any decline in value is other than temporary are the key judgment elements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P46_S2	The discovery of new information and the passage of time can significantly change these judgments.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P46_S3	Revisions of impairment judgments are made when new information becomes known, and any resulting impairment adjustments are made at that time.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	The economic environment and volatility of securities markets increase the difficulty of determining fair value and assessing investment impairment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	The amortized cost of debt securities classified as available-for-sale is adjusted for amortization of premiums and accretion of discounts to maturity, or in the case of mortgage-backed securities, over the estimated life of the security.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P48_S1	Such amortization is included in interest income from investments.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P48_S2	Realized gains and losses, and credit declines in value judged to be other-than-temporary are included in other income.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	Investments are discussed in detail in Note 3 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	The Company accounts for income taxes using the liability method in accordance with the FASB ASC 740 topic Income Taxes .
1121788_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	The liability method provides that deferred tax assets and liabilities are recorded based on the difference between the tax bases of assets and liabilities and their carrying amount for financial reporting purposes as measured based on the enacted tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the differences are expected to reverse.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P51_S2	The Company records a valuation allowance to reduce deferred tax assets to the amount that is believed more likely than not to be realized.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Company accounts for uncertainty in income taxes in accordance with the FASB ASC 740 topic Income Taxes .
1121788_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	The Company recognizes liabilities for tax audit issues in the U.S. and other tax jurisdictions based on our estimate of whether, and the extent to which, additional taxes will be due.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P52_S2	If payment of these amounts ultimately proves not to be required, the reversal of the liabilities would result in tax benefits being recognized in the period when the Company determines the liabilities are no longer necessary.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P52_S3	If the Company s estimate of tax liabilities proves to be less than the ultimate assessment, a further charge to expense would result.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P53_S0	Income taxes are discussed in detail in Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company recognizes revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred, the sales price is fixed or determinable, and collection is probable.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P54_S1	For the large majority of the Company s sales, these criteria are met once product has shipped and title and risk of loss have transferred to the customer.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P55_S0	The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of hardware products and software bundled with hardware that is essential to the functionality of the hardware in accordance with general revenue recognition accounting guidance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P55_S1	The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with industry specific software accounting guidance for standalone sales of software products and sales of software bundled with hardware not essential to the functionality of the hardware.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P55_S2	The Company generally does not offer specified or unspecified upgrade rights to its customers in connection with software sales.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P56_S0	For multiple-element arrangements that include tangible products that contain software essential to the tangible product s functionality and undelivered software elements that relate to the tangible product s essential software, the Company allocates revenue to all deliverables based on their relative selling prices.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P56_S1	In such circumstances, the accounting principles establish a hierarchy to determine the selling price to be used for allocating revenue to deliverables as follows: (i) vendor-specific objective evidence of fair value (VSOE), (ii) third-party evidence of selling price (TPE), and (iii) best estimate of the selling price (ESP).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P57_S0	VSOE generally exists only when the Company sells the deliverable separately, on more than a limited basis, at prices within a relatively narrow range.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P57_S1	In addition to the products listed below, the Company has offered certain other products including mobile applications, in-dash navigation solutions, aviation subscriptions and extended warranties that involve multiple-element arrangements that are immaterial.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P58_S0	The Company offers PNDs with lifetime map updates (LMUs) bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P58_S1	LMUs enable customers to download the latest map and point of interest information for the useful life of their PND.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P58_S2	In addition, the Company offers PNDs with traffic service bundled in the original purchase price.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P58_S3	The Company has identified multiple deliverables contained in arrangements involving the sale of PNDs which include the LMU and/or traffic service.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P59_S0	The first deliverable is the hardware along with the software essential to the functionality of the hardware device delivered at the time of sale.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P59_S1	The remaining deliverables are the LMU and/or traffic service.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P59_S2	The Company has allocated revenue between these deliverables using the relative selling price method.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P59_S3	Amounts allocated to the delivered hardware and the related essential software are recognized at the time of sale provided the other conditions for revenue recognition have been met.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P59_S4	The revenue and associated cost of royalties allocated to the LMU and/or the traffic service are deferred and recognized on a straight-line basis over the estimated life of the products.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	The Company has determined sufficient VSOE does not exist for LMU or traffic, and that third party evidence of selling price is not available as stand-alone and unbundled unit sales do not occur on more than a limited basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	Therefore, the Company uses the royalty cost plus a normal margin as the primary indicator to calculate relative selling prices of the LMU and traffic elements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P61_S0	For multiple-element software arrangements that do not include a tangible product, the Company allocates revenue to the various elements based on VSOE.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P61_S1	When VSOE cannot be established for undelivered elements, all revenue is deferred until the earlier point at which all elements of the arrangement are delivered or sufficient VSOE does exist, unless the only undelivered element is post-contract customer support.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P61_S2	If the only undelivered element is post-contract customer support, the entire arrangement consideration is recognized ratably over the support period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P61_S3	The Company offers navigation software licenses to certain customers, bundled with map updates to be provided periodically over the support period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P61_S4	The Company has determined sufficient VSOE of similar map updates does not exist for certain arrangements, and therefore revenue from these transactions is recognized ratably over the contractual map update period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	The Company records revenue net of sales tax, trade discounts and customer returns.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S1	The Company records estimated reductions to revenue for customer sales programs, returns and incentive offerings including rebates, price protection (product discounts offered to retailers to assist in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases), promotions and other volume-based incentives.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S2	The reductions to revenue are based on estimates and judgments using historical experience and expectation of future conditions.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S3	Changes in these estimates could negatively affect the Company s operating results.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S4	These incentives are reviewed periodically and, with the exceptions of price protection and certain other promotions, accrued for on a percentage of sales basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P62_S5	If market conditions were to decline, the Company may take actions to increase customer incentive offerings, possibly resulting in an incremental reduction of revenue at the time the incentive is offered.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	At December 31, 2016 and December 26, 2015, the Company had deferred revenues totaling $286,971 and $293,713, respectively, and related deferred costs totaling $103,546 and $87,945, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P64_S0	The deferred revenues and costs are recognized over their estimated economic lives, typically two to five years, on a straight-line basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P64_S1	In the next five years, the gross margin recognition of deferred revenue and cost for the currently deferred amounts is estimated to be $99,169, $49,605, $23,027, $8,255, and $3,369, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P65_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in cost of goods sold in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S0	The Company provides for estimated warranty costs at the time of sale.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S1	The Company s standard warranty obligation to retail partners generally provides for a right of return of any product for a full refund in the event that such product is not merchantable, is damaged or defective.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S2	The Company s historical experience is that these types of warranty obligations are generally fulfilled within 5 months from time of sale.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S3	The Company s standard warranty obligation to its end-users provides for a period of one to two years from date of shipment while certain aviation products have a warranty period of two years from the date of installation .
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S4	The Company s estimate of costs to service its warranty obligations are based on historical experience and expectations of future conditions and are recorded as a liability on the balance sheet.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S5	To the extent the Company experiences increased warranty claim activity or increased costs associated with servicing those claims, its warranty accrual will increase, resulting in decreased gross profit.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P66_S6	The following reconciliation provides an illustration of changes in the aggregate warranty reserve:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P67_S0	(1) Changes in cost estimates related to pre-existing warranties are aggregated with accruals for new warranty contracts in the accrual for products sold line .
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S0	The Company provides certain monthly and quarterly incentives for its dealers and distributors based on various factors including dealer purchasing volume and growth.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S1	Additionally, from time to time, the Company provides rebates to end users on certain products.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S2	Estimated rebates and incentives payable to dealers and distributors are regularly reviewed and recorded as accrued expenses on a monthly basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S3	In addition, the Company provides dealers and distributors with product discounts to assist these customers in clearing older products from their inventories in advance of new product releases.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S4	Each discount is tied to a specific product and can be applied to all customers who have purchased the product, or a special discount may be agreed to on an individual customer basis.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P68_S5	These rebates, incentives, and discounts are recorded as reductions to net sales in the accompanying consolidated statements of income in the period the Company has sold the product.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P69_S0	The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P69_S1	Advertising expense amounted to approximately $177,143, $167,166, and $146,633, for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P70_S0	A majority of the Company s research and development is performed in the United States.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P70_S1	Research and development costs, which are expensed as incurred, amounted to approximately $467,960, $427,043, and $395,121, for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P71_S0	Customer service and technical support costs are included as selling, general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of income.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P71_S1	Customer service and technical support costs include costs associated with performing order processing, answering customer inquiries by telephone and through Web sites, e-mail and other electronic means, and providing free technical support assistance to customers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P71_S2	The technical support is provided within one year after the associated revenue is recognized.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P71_S3	The related cost of providing this free support is not material.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P72_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Software requires companies to expense software development costs as they incur them until technological feasibility has been established, at which time those costs are capitalized until the product is available for general release to customers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P72_S1	Capitalized software development costs are not significant as the time elapsed from working model to release is typically short.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P72_S2	As required by the Research and Development topic of the FASB ASC, costs incurred to enhance our existing products or after the general release of the service using the product are expensed in the period they are incurred and included in research and development costs in the accompanying consolidated statements of income.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P73_S0	The Company currently sponsors four stock based employee compensation plans.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P73_S1	The FASB ASC topic entitled Compensation Stock Compensation requires the measurement and recognition of compensation expenses for all share-based payment awards made to employees and directors including employee stock options and restricted stock based on estimated fair values.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P74_S0	Accounting guidance requires companies to estimate the fair value of share-based payment awards on the date of grant using an option-pricing model.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P74_S1	The value of the portion of the award that is ultimately expected to vest is recognized as stock-based compensation expense over the requisite service period in the Company s consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P75_S0	As stock-based compensation expenses recognized in the accompanying consolidated statements of income are based on awards ultimately expected to vest, they have been reduced for estimated forfeitures.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P75_S1	Accounting guidance requires forfeitures to be estimated at the time of grant and revised, if necessary, in subsequent periods if actual forfeitures differ from those estimates.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P75_S2	Forfeitures were estimated based on historical experience and management s estimates.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P76_S0	Stock compensation plans are discussed in detail in Note 9 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P77_S0	In May 2014, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update ( ASU ) No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) ( ASU 2014-09 ), which supersedes previous revenue recognition guidance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P77_S1	ASU 2014-09 requires that a company will recognize revenue at an amount that reflects the consideration to which the company expects to be entitled in exchange for transferring goods or services to a customer.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P77_S2	The new standard may be applied retrospectively to each prior period presented or in a modified retrospective approach in which the cumulative effect will be recognized as of the date of adoption.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P77_S3	Additional updates to Topic 606 issued by the FASB in 2015 and 2016 include the following:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P78_S0	ASU No. 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Deferral of the Effective Date ( ASU 2015-14 ), which defers the effective date of the new guidance such that the new provisions will now be required for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P78_S1	The Company does not intend to early adopt, and adoption will therefore occur in the fiscal year ending December 28, 2018.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P79_S0	ASU No. 2016-08, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Principal versus Agent Considerations ( ASU 2016-08 ), which clarifies the implementation guidance on principal versus agent considerations (reporting revenue gross versus net).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P80_S0	ASU No. 2016-12, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Narrow-Scope Improvements and Practical Expedients ( ASU 2016-12 ), which clarifies the implementation guidance in a number of other areas.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P81_S0	ASU No. 2016-20, Technical Corrections and Improvements to Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ( ASU 2016-20 ), which affects narrow aspects of Topic 606 such as providing incremental guidance around contract costs.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P82_S0	We currently anticipate we will adopt the new revenue standards using the full retrospective method to restate each prior reporting period presented.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P82_S1	Our decision to adopt using the full retrospective method is dependent on the finalization of our analysis of information necessary to restate prior period financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P83_S0	We continue to make progress in evaluating all potential impacts of adopting the new revenue standards on the Company s consolidated financial statements, the materiality of which is not yet known.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P83_S1	This evaluation includes monitoring the work of standard setters, including any impacts from the recently issued amendments, and considering the interpretive efforts of non-authoritative groups.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P84_S0	Refer to the discussion above regarding the Company s current revenue recognition policies.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P85_S0	Adoption of the new standards is expected to affect the manner in which the Company determines the unit of account for certain products (i.e. performance obligations), as well as the allocation of consideration (i.e. revenue) to certain obligations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P85_S1	We have completed our grouping of the Company s homogenous revenue streams and are continuing to specify and allocate consideration to the associated obligations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P86_S0	In January 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-01, Financial Instruments Overall (Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities ( ASU 2016-01 ).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P86_S1	The standard addresses certain aspects of recognition, measurement, presentation, and disclosure of financial instruments.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P86_S2	ASU 2016-01 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P86_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting the new standard on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P87_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842) ( ASU 2016-02 ), which sets out the principles for the recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of leases for both lessees and lessors.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P87_S1	ASU 2016-02 requires lessees to present a right-of-use asset and a corresponding lease liability on the balance sheet.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P88_S0	Lessor accounting is substantially unchanged compared to the current accounting guidance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P89_S0	ASU 2016-02 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2018.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P89_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting the new standard on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P90_S0	In March 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-09, Compensation Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting ( ASU 2016-09 ), which is intended to simplify the accounting for share-based payment awards.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P90_S1	The standard includes provisions addressing income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities, and classification on the statement of cash flows.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S0	ASU 2016-09 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S1	The Company does not intend to early adopt ASU 2016-09, rather, adoption will occur in the fiscal year ending December 30, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S2	ASU 2016-09 requires that tax effects from stock-based compensation be recognized in the income tax provision, as these amounts are currently recognized in additional paid-in capital.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S3	The Company believes this aspect of the standard may have a material effect on the income tax provision within the consolidated statements of income in future periods.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S4	Furthermore, under ASU 2016-09, excess income tax benefits from stock-based compensation arrangements are classified as a cash flow from operations, rather than as a cash flow from financing activities.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S5	The Company will apply both changes prospectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P91_S6	The Company is currently unable to reasonably estimate the impact of these changes due to the dependency of these items on the underlying share price of the Company.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P92_S0	In August 2016, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments ( ASU 2016-15 ), which adds or clarifies guidance on the classification of certain cash receipts and payments in the statement of cash flows.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P92_S1	The standard addresses eight specific cash flow issues with the objective of reducing diversity in practice.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P93_S0	ASU 2016-15 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P93_S1	The Company is currently evaluating the impact of adopting the new standard on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P94_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2017-01, Business Combinations (Topic 805): Clarifying the Definition of a Business ( ASU 2017-01 ), which narrows the scope of Topic 805 by revising the definition of a business.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P94_S1	When substantially all of the fair value of gross assets acquired or disposed of is concentrated in a single asset (or group of similar assets), the asset(s) would not represent a business in the context of Topic 805.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P95_S0	ASU 2017-01 should be applied prospectively and is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P95_S1	The Company does not expect the adoption of the new provisions to have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P96_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2017-04, Intangible Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Simplify the Test for Goodwill Impairment ( ASU 2017-04 ) which simplifies the accounting for goodwill impairment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P96_S1	ASU 2017-04 removes Step 2 of the goodwill impairment test, such that a goodwill impairment will now be the amount by which a reporting unit s carrying value exceeds its fair value.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P96_S2	ASU 2017-04 should be applied prospectively and is effective for fiscal years, or any goodwill impairment tests in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P96_S3	Early adoption is permitted for any impairment tests performed after January 1, 2017.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P96_S4	The Company does not expect the adoption of the new provisions to have a material impact on its consolidated financial statements.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P97_S0	The FASB ASC topic entitled Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date (exit price).
1121788_17_ITEM8_P98_S0	The accounting guidance classifies the inputs used to measure fair value into the following hierarchy:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P99_S0	The Company endeavors to utilize the best available information in measuring fair value.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P99_S1	Financial assets and liabilities are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P100_S0	Valuation is based on prices obtained from an independent pricing vendor using both market and income approaches.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P100_S1	The primary inputs to the valuation include quoted prices for similar assets in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets in markets that are not active, contractual cash flows, benchmark yields, and credit spreads.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P101_S0	The method described above may produce a fair value calculation that may not be indicative of net realizable value or reflective of future fair values.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P101_S1	Furthermore, while the Company believes its valuation methods are appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of different methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value of certain financial instruments could result in a different fair value measurement at the reporting date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P102_S0	Available-for-sale securities measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized below:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P103_S0	Marketable securities classified as available-for-sale securities are summarized below:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P104_S0	(1) Represents impairment not related to credit for those investment securities that have been determined to be other-than-temporarily impaired.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P105_S0	(2) Represents unrealized losses on investment securities that have not been determined to be other-than-temporarily impaired.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P106_S0	The Company s investment policy targets low risk investments with the objective of minimizing the potential risk of principal loss.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P106_S1	The fair value of our securities varies from period to period due to changes in interest rates, in the performance of the underlying collateral and in the credit performance of the underlying issuer, among other factors.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P106_S2	The Company does not intend to sell the securities that have an unrealized loss shown in the table above, and it is not more likely than not that the Company will be required to sell a security before recovery of its amortized cost basis, which may be maturity.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P107_S0	The Company recognizes the credit component of other-than-temporary impairments of debt securities in Other Income and the noncredit component in Other comprehensive income (loss) for those securities that we do not intend to sell and for which it is not more likely than not that we will be required to sell before recovery.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P107_S1	During 2016 and 2015, the Company did not record any material impairment charges on its outstanding securities.

1121788_17_ITEM8_P108_S1	Approximately 64.7% of securities in our portfolio were at an unrealized loss position at December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P108_S2	We have the ability to hold these securities until maturity or their value is recovered.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P108_S3	We do not consider these unrealized losses to be other than temporary credit losses because there has been no material deterioration in credit quality and no change in the cash flows of the underlying securities.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P108_S4	We do not intend to sell the securities and it is not more likely than not that we will be required to sell the securities; therefore, no material impairment has been recorded in the accompanying condensed consolidated statement of income.

1121788_17_ITEM8_P116_S3	Our purchase orders are based on our current needs and are fulfilled by our suppliers, contract manufacturers, and logistics providers within short periods of time.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P117_S0	In the normal course of business, the Company and its subsidiaries are parties to various legal claims, investigations and complaints, including matters alleging patent infringement and other intellectual property claims.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P117_S1	The Company evaluates, on a quarterly basis, developments in legal proceedings, investigations or claims that could affect the amount of any accrual or disclosure.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P117_S2	The assessment regarding whether a loss is probable or a reasonable possibility, and whether the loss or a range of loss is estimable, often involves a series of complex judgments about future events.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P118_S0	Management of the Company currently does not believe there is at least a reasonable possibility the Company may have incurred a material loss, or a material loss in excess of recorded accruals, with respect to loss contingencies individually and in the aggregate, for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P118_S1	The results of legal proceedings, investigations and claims, however, cannot be predicted with certainty.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P118_S2	Although management considers the likelihood to be remote, an adverse resolution of one or more of such matters in excess of management s expectations could have a material adverse effect on the Company s results of operations in a particular quarter or fiscal year.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P119_S0	The Company settled or resolved certain matters during the fiscal year ended December 31, 2016 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial condition or results of operations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P120_S0	GII and the Company s other U.S.-based subsidiaries sponsor a defined contribution employee retirement plan under which their employees may contribute up to 50% of their annual compensation subject to Internal Revenue Code maximum limitations and to which the subsidiaries contribute a specified percentage of each participant s annual compensation up to certain limits as defined in the retirement plan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P120_S1	Additionally, GEL has a defined contribution plan under which its employees may contribute up to 7.5% of their annual compensation.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P120_S2	During the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, expense related to these and other defined contribution plans of $40,844, $37,489, and $29,267, respectively, was charged to operations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P121_S0	Certain of the Company s foreign subsidiaries participate in local defined benefit pension plans.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P121_S1	Contributions are calculated by formulas that consider final pensionable salaries.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P121_S2	Neither obligations nor contributions for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014 were significant.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P122_S0	The Company s income tax provision (benefit) consists of the following:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P123_S0	The income tax provision differs from the amount computed by applying the U.S. statutory federal income tax rate to income before taxes.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P123_S1	The sources and tax effects of the differences, including the impact of establishing tax contingency accruals, are as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P124_S0	In the third quarter of 2014, the Company initiated an inter-company restructuring that realigned our corporate entity structure.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P124_S1	This change in corporate structure provides access to historical earnings that were previously permanently reinvested and allows us to efficiently repatriate future earnings.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P124_S2	As a result of the change in corporate structure, the Company recorded tax expense of $307,635.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P124_S3	Approximately $265,000 of this amount has been paid.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P124_S4	The remainder of the accrued tax is expected to be paid incrementally as the cash is repatriated.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P125_S0	The holding company s statutory federal income tax rate in Switzerland, the Company's place of incorporation since the Redomestication, effective June 27, 2010, is 7.83%.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P125_S1	If the Company reconciled taxes at the Swiss holding company federal statutory tax rate to the reported income tax for 2016 as presented above, the amounts related to tax at the statutory rate would be $171,000 lower, or $49,000, and the foreign tax rate differential would be adjusted by a similar amount to $55,000.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P125_S2	For 2015, the amounts related to tax at the statutory rate would be approximately $154,000 lower, or $44,000, and the foreign tax rate differential would be adjusted by a similar amount to approximately $52,000.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P125_S3	For 2014, the amount related to tax at the statutory rate would be approximately $197,000 lower, or $57,000, and the foreign tax differential would be reduced by a similar amount to approximately $44,000.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P125_S4	All other amounts would remain substantially unchanged.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P126_S0	The Company s income before income taxes attributable to non-U.S. operations was $453,729, $403,242, and $546,790, for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P126_S1	The Taiwan tax holiday benefits included in the table above reflect $0.01, $0.02, and $0.02 per weighted-average common share outstanding for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P126_S2	The Company currently expects to benefit from these Taiwan tax holidays through 2017, at which time these tax benefits will likely expire.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P127_S0	Income taxes of $22,139, $21,085, and $20,606 at December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively, have not been accrued by the Company for the unremitted earnings of several of its foreign subsidiaries because such earnings are intended to be reinvested in the subsidiaries indefinitely.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P128_S0	Deferred income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for income tax purposes.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P128_S1	Significant components of the Company s deferred tax assets and liabilities are as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P129_S0	Included in the share based compensation deferred tax asset of $29,632 are stock options that will begin to expire over the next several years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P129_S1	Given the exercise price of the options expiring over the next 12 months compared to the current market price it is possible that these options will expire unexercised, resulting in a potential increase to income tax expense.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P130_S0	At December 31, 2016, the Company had $5,012 of tax credit carryover compared to $3,906 at December 26, 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P131_S0	At December 31, 2016, the Company had a deferred tax asset of $5,403 related to the future tax benefit on net operating loss (NOL) carryforwards of $35,843.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P131_S1	Included in the NOL carryforwards is $22,968 that relates to Switzerland and expires in 2023, $1,462 that relates to Finland and expires in varying amounts between 2025 and 2026, $1,991 that relates to the United States and expires in varying amounts between 2035 and 2036, and $9,422 that relates to various other jurisdictions and has no expiration date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P132_S0	The Company has recorded a valuation allowance for a portion of its deferred tax asset relating to various tax attributes that it does not believe are more likely than not to be realized.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P132_S1	In the future, if the Company determines, based on existence of sufficient evidence, that it should realize more or less of its deferred tax assets, an adjustment to the valuation allowance will be made in the period such a determination is made.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P133_S0	The total amount of gross unrecognized tax benefits as of December 31, 2016 was $115,090.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P133_S1	A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of gross unrecognized tax benefits for years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014 is as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P134_S0	Accounting guidance requires unrecognized tax benefits to be classified as non-current liabilities, except for the portion that is expected to be paid within one year of the balance sheet date.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P134_S1	The entire balance of net unrecognized benefits of $109,667, $93,654 and $74,205 are required to be classified as non-current at December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P134_S2	The net unrecognized tax benefits, if recognized, would reduce the effective tax rate.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P134_S3	None of the unrecognized tax benefits are due to uncertainty in the timing of deductibility.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P135_S0	Interest and penalties, if any, accrued on the unrecognized tax benefits are reflected in income tax expense.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P135_S1	At December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, the Company had accrued approximately $3,901, $2,479, and $2,159, respectively, for interest.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P135_S2	The interest component of the reserve increased (decreased) income tax expense for the years ending December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, by $1,422, $320, and ($2,953), respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P135_S3	The Company had no amounts accrued for penalties as the nature of the unrecognized tax benefits, if recognized, would not warrant the imposition of penalties.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P136_S0	The Company files income tax returns in Switzerland and U.S. federal jurisdictions, as well as various state, local and foreign jurisdictions.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P136_S1	With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state, or local tax examinations by tax authorities for years 2012 and prior.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P136_S2	The Company is no longer subject to Taiwan income tax examinations by tax authorities for years 2010 and prior.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P136_S3	The Company is no longer subject to United Kingdom tax examinations by tax authorities for years 2013 and prior.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P136_S4	The Company is no longer subject to Switzerland tax examinations by tax authorities for years 2011 and prior.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P137_S0	The Company recognized a reduction of income tax expense of $11,151, $6,971, and $83,006 in fiscal years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014, respectively, to reflect the expiration of statutes of limitations and releases due to audit settlement in various jurisdictions.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P138_S0	The Company believes that it is reasonably possible that approximately $15,000 to $20,000 of its reserves for certain unrecognized tax benefits will decrease within the next 12 months as the result of the expiration of statutes of limitations.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P138_S1	This potential decrease in unrecognized tax benefits would impact the Company s effective tax rate within the next 12 months.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P139_S0	As required by the Financial Instruments topic of the FASB ASC, the following summarizes required information about the fair value of certain financial instruments for which it is currently practicable to estimate such value.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P139_S1	None of the financial instruments are held or issued for trading purposes.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P139_S2	The carrying amounts and fair values of the Company s financial instruments are as follows:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P140_S0	For certain of the Company s financial instruments, including accounts receivable, loan receivable, accounts payable and other accrued liabilities, the carrying amounts approximate fair value due to their short maturities.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P141_S0	The Company has identified five reportable segments for external reporting purposes auto, aviation, marine, outdoor and fitness.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P141_S1	There are two operating segments (auto PND and auto OEM) that are not reported separately but aggregated within the auto reportable segment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P141_S2	Each operating segment is individually reviewed and evaluated by the Chief Operating Decision Maker (CODM), who allocates resources and assesses performance of each segment individually.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P142_S0	All of the Company s reportable segments offer products through the Company s network of independent dealers and distributors as well as through OEMs.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P142_S1	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the five reportable segments vary.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P143_S0	The Company s marine, auto, outdoor, and fitness segments include portable global positioning system (GPS) receivers and accessories sold primarily to retail outlets.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P143_S1	These products are produced primarily by the Company s subsidiary in Taiwan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P144_S0	The Company s aviation products are portable and panel mount avionics for Visual Flight Rules and Instrument Flight Rules navigation and are sold primarily to aviation dealers and certain aircraft manufacturers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P145_S0	The Company s Chief Executive Officer has been identified as the CODM.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P145_S1	In 2015, the measure of segment profit or loss used by the CODM to assess segment performance and allocate resources changed from income before income taxes to operating income.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P145_S2	This change did not impact the measurement methods used to determine reported segment profit or loss in all years presented.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P146_S0	Operating income represents net sales less costs of goods sold and operating expenses, including certain allocated general and administrative costs.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P146_S1	The accounting policies of the reportable segments are the same as those described in the summary of significant accounting policies.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P146_S2	There are no inter-segment sales or transfers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P147_S0	The Company s reportable segments share many common resources, infrastructures and assets in the normal course of business.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P147_S1	Thus, the Company does not report accounts receivable, inventories, property and equipment, intangible assets, or capital expenditures by segment to the CODM.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P148_S0	Revenues, gross profit, and operating income for each of the Company s reportable segments are presented below.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P148_S1	In 2016 the Company moved action camera related revenue and expenses from the outdoor segment to the auto segment, allowing for alignment and synergies with other camera-based efforts occurring within the auto segment.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P148_S2	The overall impact of the move was immaterial.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P148_S3	However, action camera related operating results for the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014 have been recast to conform to the current year presentation.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P149_S0	Net sales, long-lived assets (property and equipment), and net assets by geographic area are as shown below for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015, and December 27, 2014.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P149_S1	Note that APAC refers to the Asia Pacific region, and EMEA includes Europe, the Middle East and Africa.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P150_S0	(1) The U.S. is the only country which constitutes greater than 10% of net sales to external customers.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P151_S0	(2) Americas and APAC net assets are primarily held in the United States and Taiwan, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P152_S0	The various Company stock compensation plans are summarized below.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P153_S0	For all stock compensation plans, the company s policy is to issue treasury shares for option/stock appreciation right (SAR) exercises, restricted stock unit (RSU) releases and employee stock purchase plan (ESPP) purchases.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P154_S0	In June 2011, the stockholders adopted an equity incentive plan for non-employee directors (the 2011 Directors Plan ) providing for grants of stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares, pursuant to which up to 122,592 shares were available for issuance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P154_S1	The term of each award cannot exceed ten years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P154_S2	Awards may vest over a minimum two-year period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P154_S3	In 2016, 2015, and 2014, 12,984, 12,008, and 7,120 RSUs were granted under this plan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P155_S0	In June 2005, the shareholders adopted an equity incentive plan (the 2005 Plan ) providing for grants of incentive and nonqualified stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares to employees of the Company and its subsidiaries, pursuant to which up to 10,000,000 common shares were available for issuance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P155_S1	In 2013, the shareholders approved an additional 3,000,000 shares to the plan, making the total shares authorized under the plan 13,000,000.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S0	Option and SAR grants vest evenly over a period of five years or as otherwise determined by the Board of Directors or the Compensation Committee and generally expire ten years from the date of grant, if not exercised.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S1	RSUs granted prior to December 10, 2012 vested or are vesting evenly over a period of five years, while RSUs granted on and after that date vested or are vesting evenly over a period of three years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S2	In addition to time-based vesting requirements, the vesting of certain RSU grants is also contingent upon the Company s achievement of certain financial performance goals.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S3	During 2016, 2015, and 2014, 1,228,427, 1,171,905, and 425,347 RSUs were granted under the 2005 Plan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S4	No SARs were granted under the 2005 Plan in 2016 and 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P156_S5	During 2014, 47,095 SARs were granted under the 2005 plan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P157_S0	In October 2000, the shareholders adopted an equity incentive plan (the 2000 Plan ) providing for grants of incentive and nonqualified stock options, SARs, RSUs and/or performance shares to employees of the Company and its subsidiaries, pursuant to which up to 7,000,000 common shares were available for issuance.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P157_S1	The stock options and SARs vest evenly over a period of five years or as otherwise determined by the Board of Directors or the Compensation Committee and generally expire ten years from the date of grant, if not exercised.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P157_S2	The Company did not grant any stock awards from the 2000 Plan in 2016, 2015, or 2014.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P158_S0	Also in October 2000, the stockholders adopted a stock option plan for non-employee directors (the 2000 Directors Plan ) providing for grants of options for up to 100,000 common shares.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P158_S1	In 2009, the stockholders approved an additional 150,000 shares to the plan, making the total shares authorized under the plan 250,000.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P158_S2	The term of each award is ten years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P158_S3	All awards vest evenly over a three-year period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P158_S4	Following the June 2011 approval of the 2011 Directors Plan, the Company will no longer issue options to purchase shares under this plan.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P159_S0	A summary of the Company s stock-based compensation activity and related information under the 2011 Directors Plan, the 2005 Plan, the 2000 Plan and the 2000 Directors Plan for the years ended December 31, 2016, December 26, 2015 and December 27, 2014 is provided below:
1121788_17_ITEM8_P160_S0	The weighted-average remaining contract life for stock options and SARs outstanding and exercisable at December 31, 2016 was 1.21 and 1.09 years, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P160_S1	The weighted-average remaining contract life of restricted stock units at December 31, 2016 was 1.47 years.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P161_S0	The fair value of awards is determined at the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing model.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P161_S1	The fair value of RSUs is calculated using the closing price of the Company s common stock on the date of grant, reduced by the present value of estimated dividends over the vesting period, which are not accrued.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P161_S2	The fair value of stock options and SARs was calculated with the following weighted-average assumptions for 2014.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P161_S3	No options or SARs were granted in 2016 or 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P162_S0	The Black-Scholes option valuation model was developed for use in estimating the fair value of traded options and SARs which have no vesting restrictions and are fully transferable.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P162_S1	In addition, option valuation models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected stock price volatility.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P163_S0	The total fair value of awards vested during 2016, 2015, and 2014 was $22,429, $23,351, and $19,127, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P163_S1	The aggregate intrinsic values of options and SARs outstanding and exercisable at December 31, 2016 were $942 and $884, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P163_S2	The aggregate intrinsic values of options and SARs exercised during 2016, 2015, and 2014 were $1,632, $3,714, and $18,885, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P163_S3	The aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs outstanding at December 31, 2016 was $88,449.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P163_S4	The aggregate intrinsic values of RSUs released during 2016, 2015, and 2014 were $27,386, $20,787, and $28,119, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P164_S0	Aggregate intrinsic value of options and SARs represents the applicable number of awards multiplied by the positive difference between the exercise price and the Company s closing stock price on the last trading day of the relevant fiscal period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P164_S1	Aggregate intrinsic value of RSUs represents the applicable number of awards multiplied by the Company s closing stock price on the last trading day of the relevant fiscal period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P164_S2	The Company s closing stock price was $48.49 on December 31, 2016.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P164_S3	As of December 31, 2016, there was $55,802 of total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested share-based compensation awards granted to employees under the stock compensation plans.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P164_S4	That cost is expected to be recognized over the weighted average remaining vesting period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S0	The shareholders also adopted an ESPP.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S1	Up to 6,000,000 shares of common stock have been reserved for the ESPP with shareholders approving an additional 2,000,000 shares in June 2015.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S2	Shares will be offered to employees at a price equal to the lesser of 85% of the fair market value of the stock on the date of purchase or 85% of the fair market value on the first day of the ESPP period.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S3	The ESPP is intended to qualify as an employee stock purchase plan under Section 423 of the Internal Revenue Code.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S4	During 2016, 2015, and 2014, 541,018, 488,753, and 349,982 shares, respectively were purchased under the plan for a total purchase price of $18,157, $16,789, and $14,634, respectively.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S5	During 2016, 2015, and 2014, the purchases were issued from treasury shares.
1121788_17_ITEM8_P165_S6	At December 31, 2016, approximately 1,459,610 shares were available for future issuance.

1121788_17_ITEM8_P167_S0	There were 3,547,738, 4,086,983, and 2,240,005 outstanding stock options, stock appreciation rights and restricted stock units (collectively equity awards ) excluded from the computation of diluted earnings per share for the fiscal years of 2016, 2015, and 2014, respectively, because the effect would have been anti-dilutive.
