1121788_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations focuses on and is intended to clarify the results of our operations, certain changes in our financial position, liquidity, capital structure and business developments for the periods covered by the consolidated financial statements included in this Form 10-K. This discussion should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified by reference to, the other related information including, but not limited to, the audited consolidated financial statements (including the notes thereto), the description of our business, all as set forth in this Form 10-K, as well as the risk factors discussed above in Item 1A.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	As previously noted, the discussion set forth below, as well as other portions of this Form 10-K, contain statements concerning potential future events.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P1_S1	Readers can identify these forward-looking statements by their use of such verbs as expects, anticipates, believes or similar verbs or conjugations of such verbs.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P1_S2	If any of our assumptions on which the statements are based prove incorrect or should unanticipated circumstances arise, our actual results could materially differ from those anticipated by such forward-looking statements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P1_S3	The differences could be caused by a number of factors or combination of factors including, but not limited to, those discussed above in Item 1A. Readers are strongly encouraged to consider those factors when evaluating any such forward-looking statement.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P1_S4	Except as may be required by law, we do not undertake to update any forward-looking statements in this Form 10-K.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	Garmin s fiscal year is a 52-53 week period ending on the last Saturday of the calendar year.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	Fiscal year 2017 contains 52 weeks compared to 53 weeks for 2016 and 52 weeks for 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P2_S2	Unless otherwise stated, all years and dates refer to the Company s fiscal year and fiscal periods.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P2_S3	Unless the context otherwise requires, references in this document to we, us, our and similar terms refer to Garmin Ltd. and its subsidiaries.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P3_S0	Unless otherwise indicated, dollar amounts set forth in the tables are in thousands, except per share data.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P4_S0	We are a leading worldwide provider of navigation, communications and information devices, most of which are enabled by Global Positioning System, or GPS, technology.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P4_S1	We operate in five business segments, which serve the marine, outdoor, fitness, auto, and aviation markets.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P4_S2	Our segments offer products through our network of subsidiary distributors and independent dealers and distributors.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P4_S3	However, the nature of products and types of customers for the five segments can vary significantly.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P4_S4	As such, the segments are managed separately.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P5_S0	Since our first products were delivered in 1991, we have generated positive income from operations each year and have funded our growth from these profits.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	Garmin s discussion and analysis of its financial condition and results of operations are based upon Garmin s consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P6_S1	The presentation of these financial statements requires Garmin to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P6_S2	On an on-going basis, Garmin evaluates its estimates, including those related to customer sales programs and incentives, product returns, bad debts, inventories, investments, intangible assets, income taxes, warranty obligations, and contingencies and litigation.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P6_S3	Garmin bases its estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying value of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P6_S4	Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P7_S0	For information on each of the following critical accounting policies and/or estimates, refer to the discussion in the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements as indicated in the table below:
1121788_18_ITEM7_P8_S0	Our net sales are primarily generated through sales to our retail partners, dealer and distributor network and to original equipment manufacturers.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P8_S1	Refer to the Revenue Recognition discussion in Note 2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P9_S0	Our sales are largely of a consumer nature; therefore, backlog levels are not necessarily indicative of our future sales results.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P9_S1	We aim to achieve a quick turnaround on orders we receive, and we typically ship most orders within 72 hours.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P10_S0	Net sales are subject to seasonal fluctuation.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P10_S1	Typically, sales of our consumer products are highest in the fourth quarter, due to increased demand during the holiday buying season, and in the second quarter, due to increased demand during the spring and summer season.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P10_S2	Our aviation and auto OEM products do not experience much seasonal variation, but are more influenced by the timing of aircraft certifications and the release of new products when the initial demand is typically the strongest.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P11_S0	Raw material costs are our most significant component of cost of goods sold.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P11_S1	Our existing practice of performing the design and manufacture of our products in-house has enabled us to source components from different suppliers and, where possible, to redesign our products to leverage lower cost components.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P11_S2	We believe that our flexible production model allows our Xizhi, Jhongli, and LinKou manufacturing plants in Taiwan; Yangzhou manufacturing plant in China; and our Olathe, Kansas, and Salem, Oregon manufacturing plants in the U.S. to experience relatively low costs of manufacturing.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P11_S3	In general, products manufactured in Taiwan have been our highest volume products.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P11_S4	Our manufacturing labor costs historically have been lower in Taiwan and China than in Olathe and Salem.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P12_S0	Sales price variability has had and can be expected to have an effect on our gross profit.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P12_S1	In the past, prices of our devices sold into the auto market have declined due to market pressures and introduction of new products sold at lower price points.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P12_S2	In recent years, pricing has stabilized in auto allowing for relatively stable gross margins excluding the impact of deferred revenues and costs.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P13_S0	The average selling prices of our aviation, outdoor, fitness, and marine products have historically been stable due to product mix and the introduction of more advanced products sold at higher prices.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P13_S1	The effect of the sales price differences inherent within the mix of products sold could have a significant impact on our gross profit.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	Our advertising expenses consist of costs for media advertising, cooperative advertising with our retail partners, point of sale displays, and sponsorships.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	Our selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of:
1121788_18_ITEM7_P16_S0	The majority of our research and development costs represent salaries for our engineers and costs of test equipment and components used in product and prototype development.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P17_S0	We are committed to increasing the level of innovative design and development of new products as we strive for expanded ability to serve our existing consumer and aviation markets as well as new markets for active lifestyle products.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P18_S0	We have experienced a relatively low effective corporate tax rate due to the proportion of our revenue generated by entities in tax jurisdictions with low statutory rates.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P18_S1	In particular, the profit entitlement afforded our Swiss-based companies based on their intellectual property rights ownership of our consumer products have contributed to our relatively low effective corporate tax rate.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P19_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations as a percentage of net sales during the periods shown (the table may not foot due to rounding):
1121788_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	In 2016, the Company moved action camera related revenue and expenses from the outdoor segment to the auto segment, allowing for alignment and synergies with other camera-based efforts occurring within the auto segment.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	The overall impact of the move was immaterial.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P20_S2	However, action camera related operating results for the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015 has been recast to conform to the 2017 and 2016 presentation.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	The following table sets forth our results of operations through operating income for each of our five segments during the period shown.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	For each line item in the table the total of the segments amounts equals the amount in the consolidated statements of income data included in Item 6.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P22_S0	Net sales increased 2% in 2017 when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P22_S1	Outdoor, marine, and aviation segments had an increase in revenue, while fitness and auto segments had a decrease in revenue.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P22_S2	Fitness revenue represented the largest portion of our revenue mix at 25% in 2017, which was a slight decline from 27% in 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P22_S3	Auto revenue represented the largest portion of our revenue mix in 2016 at 29% and declined to 24% in 2017.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P23_S0	Total unit sales decreased 8% to 15.4 million units in the 52-weeks ended 2017 from 16.8 million units in the 53-weeks ended 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S0	Auto segment revenue decreased 15% from the year-ago period, primarily due to the ongoing PND market contraction.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S1	Fitness segment revenue decreased 7% from the year-ago period, primary driven by the general decline of the basic activity tracker market.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S2	Outdoor, marine, and aviation revenues increased 28%, 13%, and 14%, respectively when compared to the year-ago period.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S3	Growth in outdoor was driven by growth in our wearables and subscriptions categories.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S4	Our marine segment revenue increased primarily due to growth in chartplotters, fishfinders, and entertainment systems, and the newly acquired Navionics.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P24_S5	Aviation revenues increased due to growth in both OEM and aftermarket sales.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P25_S0	Cost of goods sold decreased 3% in absolute dollars for the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 when compared to the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P26_S0	The auto segment cost of goods decline was largely consistent with the segment revenue decline.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P26_S1	In the outdoor, fitness, and marine segments, the decrease in cost of goods sold as a percent of revenues was a result of a shift in product mix toward higher margin products.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P26_S2	The aviation segment increase in cost of goods sold was generally consistent with the segment revenue increase.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P27_S0	Gross profit dollars in the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 increased 6% while gross profit margin increased 210 basis points compared to the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P27_S1	Growth in sales of higher margin segments contributed to the increase in gross profit dollars and gross margin percentage.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P27_S2	Outdoor, fitness, and marine segment increases to gross profit margin were primarily due to product mix within those segments.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P27_S3	Auto and aviation segment gross margin rates were relatively consistent between fiscal periods.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P28_S0	Advertising expense decreased 7% in absolute dollars and was relatively flat as a percent of revenues in the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 compared to the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P28_S1	The decrease in absolute dollars is primarily attributable to decreases in spend on media advertising.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P29_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense increased 7% in absolute dollars and was relatively flat as a percent of revenues in the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 compared to the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P29_S1	The absolute dollar increase is primarily attributable to legal-related costs and information technology costs.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P29_S2	As a percent of revenues, selling, general, and administrative expenses in all segments except marine were relatively consistent on a year over year basis.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P29_S3	The increase in the marine segment, as a percent of revenues, was primarily related to a litigation settlement.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P30_S0	Research and development expense increased 9% due to ongoing development activities for new products and the addition of engineering personnel throughout the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P30_S1	In absolute dollars, research and development costs increased $43.7 million when compared with the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016, and increased 100 basis points as a percent of revenue.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P30_S2	Our research and development spending is focused on product development, improving existing software capabilities, and exploring new categories.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P31_S0	As a result of the above, operating income increased 7% in absolute dollars and 100 basis points as a percent of revenue when compared to the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P31_S1	The growth in operating income, both in absolute dollars and as a percent of revenue, was primarily due to an increase in revenue growth and increase in gross margin percentage, which was partially offset by increased operating expenses, as discussed above.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P32_S0	The average returns on cash and investments, including interest and capital gain/loss returns, during the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 and the 53- weeks ended December 31, 2016 were 1.5% for both periods.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P32_S1	Interest income increased in fiscal 2017 primarily due to slightly higher yields on fixed-income securities, while other income decreased in fiscal 2017 primarily due to higher net capital gains realized in fiscal 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P33_S0	Foreign currency gains and losses for the Company are typically driven by movements in the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling in relation to the U.S. Dollar.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P33_S1	The Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin Corporation, the U.S. Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin (Europe) Ltd., and the Euro is the functional currency of most of our other European subsidiaries, although some transactions and balances are denominated in British Pounds.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P33_S2	The majority of the Company s consolidated foreign currency gain or loss is typically driven by the significant cash and marketable securities, receivables and payables held in a currency other than the functional currency at a given legal entity.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P33_S3	Due to the relative size of the entities using a functional currency other than the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling, currency fluctuations related to these entities are not expected to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P34_S0	The $22.6 million currency loss recognized in fiscal 2017 was primarily due to the weakening of the U.S. Dollar against the Taiwan Dollar, partially offset by the U.S. Dollar weakening against the Euro and the British Pound Sterling.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P34_S1	During fiscal 2017, the U.S. Dollar weakened 9.4% against the Taiwan Dollar, resulting in a loss of $55.9 million, while the U.S. Dollar weakened 14.1% against the Euro and 9.5% against the British Pound Sterling, resulting in gains of $27.2 million and $3.1 million, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P34_S2	The remaining net currency gain of $3.0 million is related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P35_S0	The $31.7 million currency loss recognized in fiscal 2016 was primarily due to the weakening of the U.S. Dollar against the Taiwan Dollar and the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar against the Euro and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P35_S1	During fiscal 2016, the U.S. Dollar weakened 1.7% against the Taiwan Dollar, resulting in a loss of $9.2 million, while the U.S. Dollar strengthened 4.2% against the Euro and 16.8% against the British Pound Sterling, resulting in losses of $13.0 million and $5.1 million, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P35_S2	The remaining net currency loss of $4.4 million is related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P36_S0	Our income tax benefit for the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 was $12.7 million compared to income tax expense of $118.9 million for the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016, resulting in a net change of $131.6 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P36_S1	Contributing to the decrease in tax expense was:
1121788_18_ITEM7_P37_S0	Increased income tax expense of $21.0 million related to the Company s election to align certain Switzerland corporate tax positions in the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	On December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was passed by United States Congress, reducing the United States federal corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21%.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	The effects of U.S. tax reform, including revaluation of deferred tax assets and liabilities, had an immaterial impact on the 2017 income tax benefit, on a provisional basis, as discussed in Note 6.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income increased 36% to $695.0 million for the 52-weeks ended December 30, 2017 compared to $510.8 million for the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	Net sales increased 7% in 2016 when compared to the prior year period.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P41_S1	All segments had an increase in revenue except for auto.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P41_S2	Auto revenue remains the largest portion of our revenue mix at 29% in the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 compared to 38% in the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	Total unit sales increased 4% to 16.8 million units in 2016 from 16.2 million units in 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	Auto segment revenue decreased 17% from the prior year period, primarily due to the ongoing PND market contraction.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	Outdoor, fitness, marine, and aviation revenues increased 33%, 24%, 16%, and 10%, respectively, when compared to the prior year period, primarily due to increases in sales volumes.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P43_S2	Growth in outdoor was driven by wearables and the newly acquired DeLorme product lines.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P43_S3	The increase in fitness was driven by wearables with Garmin Elevate TM wrist heart rate technology.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	Our marine segment increased due to growth in chartplotters, fishfinders, and entertainment systems.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P44_S1	Aviation revenues increased due to growth in both OEM and aftermarket sales.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	Cost of goods sold increased 4% in absolute dollars for the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 when compared to the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P46_S0	In the auto segment, the cost of goods decline was largely consistent with the segment revenue decline.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P46_S1	In the outdoor and fitness segments, the increases of 32% and 29% in cost of goods sold, respectively, primarily reflect strong volume growth.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P46_S2	In the marine and aviation segments, the increases of 16% and 6%, respectively, primarily reflect volume growth.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P47_S0	Gross profit dollars in the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 increased 9% while gross profit margin increased 100 basis points compared to the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P47_S1	Growth in sales of higher margin segments contributed to the increase in gross profit dollars and gross margin percentage.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P47_S2	Fitness margin declined to 53% due to product mix.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P47_S3	All other segment gross margin rates are relatively consistent between fiscal periods.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P48_S0	Advertising expense increased 6% in absolute dollars and was relatively flat as a percent of revenues in the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 compared to the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P48_S1	The increase in absolute dollars is primarily attributable to outdoor and fitness, partially offset by auto.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P49_S0	Selling, general and administrative expense increased 4% and was relatively flat as a percent of revenues in the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 compared to the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P50_S0	The absolute dollar increase is primarily attributable to information technology costs and salaries and benefits.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P50_S1	Variances by segment are primarily due to the allocation of certain selling, general and administrative expenses based on percentage of total revenues with the exception of the marine segment, as expenses decreased as a percentage of revenue due to prior year specific litigation matters.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P51_S0	Research and development expense increased 10% due to ongoing development activities for new products and additional engineering personnel throughout the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P51_S1	In absolute dollars, research and development costs increased $40.9 million when compared with the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015, and increased 40 basis points as a percent of revenue.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P51_S2	Our research and development spending is focused on product development, improving existing software capabilities, and exploring new categories.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P52_S0	As a result of the above, operating income increased 14% in absolute dollars and 120 basis points as a percent of revenue when compared to the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P52_S1	Revenue growth with a slight increase in gross margin percentage contributed to the growth, slightly offset by increased operating expenses, as discussed above, with the exception of the marine segment, as operating expenses decreased as a percentage of revenue due to prior year specific litigation matters.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P53_S0	The average returns on cash and investments, including interest and capital gain/loss returns, during the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 and the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015 were 1.5% and 1.2%, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P53_S1	Interest income increased primarily due to slightly higher yields on fixed-income securities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P54_S0	Foreign currency gains and losses for the Company are typically driven by movements in the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling in relation to the U.S. Dollar.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P54_S1	The Taiwan Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin Corporation, the U.S. Dollar is the functional currency of Garmin (Europe) Ltd., and the Euro is the functional currency of most of our other European subsidiaries, although some transactions and balances are denominated in British Pounds.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P54_S2	The majority of the Company s consolidated foreign currency gain or loss is typically driven by the significant cash and marketable securities, receivables and payables held in a currency other than the functional currency at a given legal entity.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P54_S3	Due to the relative size of the entities using a functional currency other than the Taiwan Dollar, Euro, and British Pound Sterling, currency fluctuations related to these entities are not expected to have a material impact on the Company s financial statements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P55_S0	The $31.7 million currency loss in fiscal 2016 was primarily due to the weakening of the U.S. Dollar against the Taiwan Dollar and the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar against the Euro and British Pound Sterling.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P55_S1	During fiscal 2016, the U.S. Dollar weakened 1.7% against the Taiwan Dollar, resulting in a loss of $9.2 million, while the U.S. Dollar strengthened 4.2% against the Euro and 16.8% against the British Pound Sterling, resulting in losses of $13.0 million and $5.1 million, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P55_S2	The remaining net currency loss of $4.4 million was related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P56_S0	The $23.5 million currency loss in fiscal 2015 was primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar against the Euro and British Pound Sterling, partially offset by a gain associated with the strengthening of the U.S. Dollar against the Taiwan Dollar.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P56_S1	During fiscal 2015, the U.S. Dollar strengthened 10.0% against the Euro and 4.6% against the British Pound Sterling, resulting in losses of $31.2 million and $2.1 million, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P56_S2	This was largely offset by the U.S. Dollar strengthening 3.8% against the Taiwan Dollar, resulting in a gain of $19.5 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P56_S3	The remaining net currency loss of $9.7 million was related to other currencies and timing of transactions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P57_S0	During the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016, Garmin recorded other income of $4.0 million compared to $11.4 million in the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P57_S1	The decrease in fiscal 2016 relates primarily to a legal settlement received in fiscal 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P58_S0	Our income tax expense increased by $7.9 million, to $118.9 million for the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016, from $111.0 million for the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P59_S0	As a result of the various factors noted above, net income increased 12% to $510.8 million for the 53-weeks ended December 31, 2016 compared to $456.2 million for the 52-weeks ended December 26, 2015.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P60_S0	As of December 30, 2017, we had $2,313.2 million of cash and cash equivalents and marketable securities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P60_S1	We primarily use cash flow from operations, and expect that future cash requirements will be used, to fund our capital expenditures, support our working capital requirements, pay dividends, fund share repurchases, and fund strategic acquisitions.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P60_S2	We believe that our existing cash balances and cash flow from operations will be sufficient to meet our long-term projected capital expenditures, working capital and other cash requirements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	It is management s goal to invest the on-hand cash in accordance with the investment policy, which has been approved by the Board of Directors of each applicable Garmin entity holding the cash.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P61_S1	The investment policy s primary purpose is to preserve capital, maintain an acceptable degree of liquidity, and maximize yield within the constraint of low credit risk.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P61_S2	Garmin s average interest rate returns on cash and investments during fiscal 2017, 2016, and 2015 were approximately 1.6%, 1.5%, and 1.2%, respectively.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P61_S3	The fair value of our securities varies from period to period due to changes in interest rates, in the performance of the underlying collateral and in the credit performance of the underlying issuer, among other factors.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P61_S4	See Note 3 for additional information regarding marketable securities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	The $44.8 million decrease in cash provided by operating activities in fiscal year 2017 compared to fiscal year 2016 was primarily due to a decrease of cash provided by working capital of $133.2 million (which included increases of $52.2 million in accounts receivable and $31.5 million in cash paid for inventory) and income taxes payable of $16.5 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P62_S1	The decrease was partially offset by an increase in net income of $184.1 million, reduced by other non-cash adjustments to net income of $79.3 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P63_S0	The $425.2 million increase in cash provided by operating activities in fiscal year 2016 compared to fiscal year 2015 was primarily due to an increase in cash provided by working capital of $223.5 million (which included decreases of $122.5 million in cash paid for inventory and $109.6 million in cash paid for prepaid royalties and other assets) and income taxes payable of $154.0 million, primarily attributable to cash taxes paid related to a 2015 intercompany restructuring.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P63_S1	The increase was also impacted by an increase of net income of $54.6 million, reduced by other non-cash adjustments to net income of $6.9 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P64_S0	The $73.0 million increase in cash used in investing activities in fiscal year 2017 compared to fiscal year 2016 was primarily due to increased cash payments for net purchases of property and equipment of $49.1 million and net cash paid for acquisitions of $12.5 million.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P65_S0	The $9.6 million increase in cash used in investing activities in fiscal year 2016 compared to fiscal year 2015 was primarily due to increased net cash paid for acquisitions of $39.3 million and net purchases of property and equipment of $17.6 million, partially offset by an increase of $49.0 million in net redemptions of marketable securities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P66_S0	We have budgeted approximately $140 million to $150 million of capital expenditures during fiscal 2018 to include some facility expansion, along with normal ongoing capital expenditures and maintenance activities.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P66_S1	Approximately half of the budgeted capital expenditures in fiscal 2018 are attributable to Olathe, KS facilities, including the expansion project described in Item 2.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P67_S0	The $113.3 million decrease in cash used in financing activities in fiscal year 2017 compared to fiscal year 2016 was primarily due to decreased dividend payments of $98.5 million associated with an additional payment made in the 53-week fiscal year 2016 and a decrease of purchases of treasury stock of $18.7 million under our share repurchase authorization.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P68_S0	The $61.6 million increase in cash used in financing activities in fiscal year 2016 compared to fiscal year 2015 was primarily due to increased dividend payments of $103.3 million associated with an additional payment made in the 53-week fiscal year 2016 and the year-over-year increase of our dividend rate, partially offset by a decrease of purchases of treasury stock of $38.2 million under our share repurchase authorization.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P69_S0	Our declared dividend has increased from $0.48 per share for the four calendar quarters beginning in June 2014 to $0.51 per share for the twelve calendar quarters beginning in June 2015.

1121788_18_ITEM7_P71_S0	The Company is party to certain other commitments, which include purchases of raw materials, advertising expenditures, and other indirect purchases in connection with conducting our business.

1121788_18_ITEM7_P71_S2	We cannot determine the aggregate amount of such purchase orders that represent contractual obligations because purchase orders may represent authorizations to purchase rather than binding agreements.
1121788_18_ITEM7_P72_S0	Our purchase orders are based on our current needs and are typically fulfilled within short periods of time.
